She pretends to be nice, you know? She'll offer me cookies and ask me about school, but her eyes are always scanning me, looking for flaws. And she *finds* them. She always finds them.

She's always making little comments about how "difficult" this must be for Bleeker, and how "brave" he is for supporting me. It's like she's trying to imply that I'm a burden.

And she's constantly trying to set Bleeker up with other girls. "Oh, you should meet Tiffany, she's a lovely girl, she's pre-med…" Like I'm some kind of temporary distraction.

I try to ignore her, but it's hard. She's just… *there*. Looming. Judging.

Bleeker says she's just worried about him. But I think she's mostly worried about what people will think. She's very concerned with appearances.

Honestly, I just try to avoid her as much as possible. It's less stressful that way. And I try not to take her comments to heart. She's just… Mrs. Bleeker. And she's not exactly known for her tact or her empathy.

So yeah. She doesn't like me. And honestly? I don't really like her either. It's a mutual dislike. And I'm perfectly okay with that. It's one less thing to worry about.

(Sighs heavily) Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, scary storm cloud.

I've been putting it off for weeks. I keep rehearsing what I'm going to say, but it always comes out sounding wrong. Either too dramatic, or too flippant. There's no good way to say "I'm pregnant," is there?

My dad… I'm mostly worried about him. He's always been so protective of me. I don't want to disappoint him. I don't want him to think I've made a terrible mistake. But I also know he loves me, and he'll try to be supportive.

Bren is… different. I think she'll be more understanding. She's always been really good at seeing things from my perspective. But I'm still scared of her reaction. I don't want her to think I'm irresponsible or reckless.

I'm just… terrified of the whole thing. Of the judgment, of the disappointment, of the awkward silences.

I know I need to tell them, though. They deserve to know. And I need their support. I can't go through this alone.

I'm planning on telling them tomorrow. I've been putting it off for too long. It's time to just rip off the band-aid and get it over with.

I'm probably going to cry. A lot. And I'm probably going to say something stupid. But I'm going to try to be honest and open and vulnerable.

And I'm going to hope for the best. Even if the best is just them not yelling at me.

Ugh. I need a cookie. And maybe a really strong cup of tea. This is going to be awful. Just… awful. Don't make me talk about it anymore, okay? I'm already stressed enough.

Ugh, okay, this is… complicated. It's not like they're *bad* parents, you know? It's just… we have a… dynamic.

My dad, Mac, he's a good guy. He's just… not really good at *feelings*. He's always been a bit emotionally distant. He shows his love by fixing things, or making pancakes, or taking me to movies. But he's not really the type to sit down and have a heart-to-heart.

And Bren, my stepmom, she's amazing. But I felt like I had to prove myself to her for a long time. Like I had to earn her trust. I didn't want to mess that up by dumping all my problems on her.

Plus, I didn't want to disappoint them. I knew they had expectations for me. Good grades, college, a bright future. And getting pregnant… that definitely wasn't part of the plan. I was afraid they'd be angry, or disappointed, or just… confused.

I also have a tendency to be independent. I like to handle things on my own. I don't want to be a burden to anyone. I don't want to ask for help and then feel like I owe them something.

It's stupid, I know. I should have talked to them sooner. But it's hard to be vulnerable, especially with people you care about. It's easier to just put up a front and pretend everything is okay.

But I'm learning. I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help. And I'm learning that my parents love me, even when I mess up. And I'm learning that they're not going to judge me. They're just going to be there for me.

It's still hard, though. It's still scary. But I'm trying. And I think, with their support, I can get through this. Even if it's the hardest thing I've ever done.

Okay, this is… the big one. The reason everything’s been swirling around in my head for months. It’s not an easy answer, and it’s definitely not a decision I took lightly.

Look, I’m sixteen. I’m still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I’m not ready to give up my life, my dreams, my future, to be a mom right now. It’s not fair to me, and it wouldn’t be fair to the baby.

I want to finish school. I want to go to college. I want to travel and explore and figure out what I want to do with my life. I want to be a good mom *someday*, but right now, I’m just not capable of providing the kind of life a baby deserves.

And it’s not just about me. It’s about the baby, too. I want him or her to have a stable, loving home with parents who are financially secure and emotionally ready. Parents who can give them everything they need to thrive.

Mark and Vanessa… they’re amazing. They’ve been trying to have a baby for years, and they’re so excited about this. They’re kind and compassionate and they’re going to be incredible parents. They can give this baby a life I just can’t.

It’s not about giving up on the baby. It’s about making the best decision for everyone involved. It’s about putting the baby’s needs first.

It’s hard. It’s really, really hard. And I know I’m going to grieve. But I also know that this is the right thing to do. It’s the most selfless thing I can do.

It doesn’t mean I don’t love the baby. It just means I love the baby enough to let them go. To give them a chance at a happy, fulfilling life.

And honestly, that’s the most important thing. It’s not about what *I* want. It’s about what’s best for the baby. And I truly believe that adoption is the best option. It’s the hardest option, but it’s the best one. And I’m trying to be strong enough to see it through.

Okay, this is… the hardest part. Seriously. It's not like picking out a new pair of boots. This is a *person's* life we're talking about.

I've been doing a lot of thinking about this, and talking to Bren and the social workers. And I've realized it's not about finding "perfect" parents, because those don't exist. It's about finding parents who are a good *fit* for my baby.

First and foremost, they need to be **loving and kind**. That seems obvious, but it's the most important thing. I want my baby to be raised in a home where they feel safe and cherished.

They need to be **stable and responsible**. They need to be able to provide for my baby's physical and emotional needs. They need to be able to offer a secure and nurturing environment.

They need to be **open-minded and accepting**. I want my baby to be able to grow up and be whoever they want to be, without judgment or prejudice.

They need to be **patient and understanding**. Raising a child is hard work. There will be challenges and setbacks. I want parents who are willing to stick it out, even when things get tough.

And they need to be **honest and communicative**. I want parents who will be open with my baby about their adoption story, and who will encourage them to ask questions and explore their feelings.

It's also important to me that they're excited about becoming parents. I want them to be genuinely thrilled about the prospect of raising my baby.

I've met Mark and Vanessa a few times now, and they seem to have all of those qualities. They're kind and compassionate, and they seem really eager to start a family. They ask me a lot of questions about my baby, and about what I want for him or her.

It's still scary, letting go. But knowing that my baby will be loved and cared for by them… that makes it a little bit easier. And that's all I can ask for. It has to be enough.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… the hard part.)

Okay. This isn’t going to be easy. I already know that. It’s going to be the hardest thing I’ve ever done. And I’m bracing myself for a lot of… stuff.

I’m trying to focus on the fact that I’m doing this for the baby. That I’m giving him or her the best possible chance at a good life. That’s what keeps me going.

But I also know that it’s okay to grieve. It’s okay to be sad. It’s okay to feel like my heart is breaking. Bren says grief isn’t something you “get over,” it’s something you learn to live *with*. And that makes… some sense.

I’m going to keep writing poetry. It helps me to process my emotions. And I’m going to talk to Bren. A lot. She’s been my rock through all of this, and I don’t know what I’d do without her.

I’m also going to stay in touch with Mark and Vanessa, if they’re okay with it. I want to know how the baby is doing. I want to see him or her grow up. It’s going to be hard, but I think it’s important.

I’m also trying to focus on the future. On finishing school, on pursuing my dreams, on building a life for myself. I want to make something of myself, not just for me, but for the baby too.

And I’m going to allow myself to feel all the feelings. The joy, the sadness, the guilt, the hope. I’m not going to try to suppress anything. I’m just going to let it all out.

It’s going to be a long and difficult journey. But I’m not alone. And I’m strong. And I’m going to get through it.

I have to. For the baby. And for myself. It’s not going to be easy, but it’s the right thing to do. And that’s what matters.

(Pauses, looking down at her hands.)

It just… hurts. A lot. And I think it always will. But I’m going to try to turn that pain into something positive. Something meaningful. Something that honors the baby and the decision I’ve made. That’s the plan, anyway. And I’m sticking to it.

(Rolls eyes) Oh my god, you remembered that? Seriously? Okay, fine. Let me explain, because this is a deeply important philosophical question, apparently.

It's just… weird, okay? Like, people say "deliver a baby." As if the baby is a pizza or a package or something. It's a *person*. A tiny, fragile human being. Not something you "deliver."

It feels so… impersonal. And clinical. And it reduces the whole experience to a transaction. Like, "Oh, she's just delivering a baby." No! She's *giving birth* to a baby! It's a huge, life-changing event! It deserves more respect than that!

It's like, you don't "deliver" a friend. You don't "deliver" a love letter. You don't "deliver" a dream. You *experience* those things. You *share* them. You *cherish* them.

And giving birth is definitely something you experience, share, and cherish. It's not something you just… deliver.

Bren tried to explain it to me once, said it's just a medical term. But I still think it's weird. And I'm sticking to my guns on this one.

It just feels… wrong. And I have a really good sense for when things feel wrong. It's one of my superpowers.

So yeah. That's why I find the term "deliver" weird. It's dehumanizing. And it makes me want to yell at people. Which, admittedly, I sometimes do. Don't judge. It's a valid point.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on that. It was a disaster waiting to happen. A beautifully awkward, emotionally charged disaster.

Look, I didn't *want* my dad to come. At all. I wanted to handle this on my own. It felt… personal. Like something I needed to do myself.

But Bren pointed out that he's my dad. And that he deserved to be involved. And that he was probably freaking out just as much as I was. And she was right, of course. She usually is.

Plus, he was being all… supportive and stuff. Which was sweet, but also kind of embarrassing. He kept trying to give me pep talks, and offering to "protect" me. Like I couldn't handle it on my own.

I figured it would be easier to just let him come. To get it over with. To avoid a huge fight.

And honestly? I was a little bit scared. I was scared of facing Mark and Vanessa, and of making the final decision. And I thought having my dad there might make me feel a little bit braver.

It didn't, obviously. He spent the whole meeting trying to make small talk with Mark and Vanessa, and asking them a million questions about their house and their jobs. It was mortifying.

But in the end, I think it was a good thing. It showed Mark and Vanessa that I had a supportive family. And it showed my dad that I was okay.

It was still awkward, though. Really awkward. And I'm pretty sure I'm never letting him come to another important meeting ever again. Unless Bren says so. Because, let's be real, Bren always gets her way.

(Sighs heavily) Oh. *That*. Yeah. That's… a thing.

It's not like I haven't thought about it. Everyone else seems to have it all figured out. They're cheerleaders, or jocks, or nerds, or whatever. They have labels. They have boxes.

And I just… don't.

I like music, but I'm not a "music person." I like vintage clothes, but I'm not a "fashionista." I'm smart, but I don't really care about grades. I'm independent, but I also need people.

I'm just… a mess of contradictions. A walking paradox.

And it's frustrating. It's like I'm constantly trying to define myself, but I can never quite put my finger on it. I feel like I'm always shifting and changing, and I don't know who I am from one day to the next.

Bren says it's okay to not have all the answers. She says it's okay to be a work in progress. She says that figuring out who you are is a lifelong journey.

But it's hard. It's hard to feel like you don't belong anywhere. It's hard to feel like you're not good enough.

But I'm starting to realize that maybe it's okay to not have a label. Maybe it's okay to be different. Maybe it's okay to be… me.

Maybe being undefined is actually a strength. Maybe it means I'm not limited by expectations or stereotypes. Maybe it means I'm free to be whoever I want to be.

It's still scary, though. It's scary to not know what the future holds. It's scary to not know who I'm going to become.

But I'm learning to embrace the uncertainty. I'm learning to trust myself. And I'm learning to be okay with not knowing.

Because maybe, just maybe, not knowing is the whole point. Maybe the journey is more important than the destination. And maybe, in the end, that's okay. Even if it's a little bit terrifying.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That whole night was… a disaster. A slow-motion train wreck of awkwardness and unspoken feelings.

When Bren suggested Leah and I go upstairs, it was… a relief, honestly. The tension between my dad and Paulie was so thick you could cut it with a knife. It was making my skin crawl.

But it was also… weird. Like, Bren was trying to protect us, which was nice, but it also felt like she was acknowledging that something was wrong. And I didn't want to acknowledge that something was wrong. I wanted everything to be normal.

I think I just mumbled something like "Okay," and followed Leah upstairs without making eye contact with anyone. I was trying to pretend like I didn't notice the hurt look on my dad's face.

Upstairs, Leah and I just sat there in silence for a while. It was… uncomfortable. We both knew something was going on, but neither of us wanted to talk about it.

I think I started flipping through a magazine or something, just to have something to do with my hands. And Leah just stared out the window.

It was a really awkward and sad moment. It was the beginning of the end of our friendship, really. Because after that night, things just… changed. We started drifting apart.

Bren meant well, I know she did. But sometimes, trying to fix things just makes them worse. And sometimes, you just have to let things fall apart on their own. It's messy and painful, but it's also necessary.

So yeah. That's how I reacted. Relief, awkwardness, and a growing sense of dread. It wasn't a good night. Not at all. And thinking about it still makes me feel… weird. And sad. And a little bit angry. It was just… a lot.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's something I've thought about a *lot*. And I've changed my mind about it a bunch of times.

At first, I was really hesitant. I was worried it would just make things harder. Like, constantly being reminded of the baby I gave up. I was afraid it would be too painful.

But then Bren talked me through it. She said that it could be a way for me to still be a part of the baby's life, even if I'm not the mom. She said it could be a way for me to see that the baby is happy and healthy.

And honestly, the thought of knowing the baby is okay… that's really appealing. It would give me a lot of peace of mind.

Mark and Vanessa are really open to it, too. They said they want me to be involved as much or as little as I want to be. They said they'll send me pictures and updates, and that I can even visit if I want to.

It's still scary, though. I'm worried about getting too attached, and about disrupting the baby's life. I don't want to be a burden to Mark and Vanessa.

But I think, ultimately, it's the right thing to do. It's a way for me to honor my connection to the baby, and to make sure he or she knows that I love him or her.

It's not going to be easy. There will be tears, and heartache, and moments of regret. But I think the benefits outweigh the risks.

So yeah. I'm cautiously optimistic about the idea of an open adoption. It's not what I expected, but it feels… right. It feels like a way to make the best of a difficult situation. And it feels like a way to give the baby the love and support he or she deserves. Even if that love and support comes from a distance.

(A long sigh. This is… not a fun memory.)

Ugh. That moment. That was… a punch to the gut. Seriously. I thought I was prepared. I thought I understood what open adoption meant. But hearing Gerta actually *say* it, that I would legally have no rights… it was different.

It felt like… giving up a part of myself. Like I wasn't even a parent, even though I carried the baby for nine months. It felt like I was just… a vessel.

I remember just staring at her, trying to process what she was saying. It felt so cold and clinical. Like I was just a case number, and the baby was a product.

And it wasn't just about the legal stuff. It was about the emotional stuff, too. It was about knowing that I wouldn't be able to make decisions about the baby's life, even if I disagreed with Mark and Vanessa. It was about knowing that I wouldn't be able to see the baby grow up, to celebrate his or her milestones.

I remember feeling really angry. Angry at Gerta, angry at Mark and Vanessa, angry at the whole situation. Angry at myself.

But I also knew that it was the right thing to do. It was the best thing for the baby. Mark and Vanessa were going to be amazing parents. They were going to give the baby a life that I couldn't provide.

So I just… swallowed my anger and my sadness and nodded. I told Gerta that I understood. But inside, I was falling apart.

It was one of the hardest moments of my life. And it's something I'll never forget. It was a reminder that sometimes, the right thing to do is also the hardest thing to do. And that sometimes, you have to give up something you love in order to give it the best possible chance at happiness.

It still stings, though. It always will. But I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to trust that everything will be okay. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's not something I've talked about a lot, even with Bren.

It's amazing, honestly. That Vanessa wants a baby *so* badly. It makes me feel… good. Like, I'm not just giving a baby *up*, I'm giving a baby *to* someone who will cherish it, who will love it unconditionally.

It's also… a little bit sad. Because it reminds me of what I can't give the baby. I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I have my own life to live, my own dreams to pursue.

But Vanessa… she's ready. She and Mark have been trying to have a baby for a long time, and they're so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They've already started decorating the nursery, and they've picked out names.

It's just… it's a lot to process. Knowing that they're so eager to be parents, and knowing that I'm not. It makes me feel a little bit guilty, even though I know I'm doing the right thing.

But I also know that they're going to be amazing parents. They're kind and compassionate and loving. They're going to give the baby a wonderful life.

And that's what matters most.

I think… I think it's a good thing that Vanessa wants this so much. It makes me feel like I'm making a difference. Like I'm giving someone the greatest gift they could ever ask for.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's still a hard decision. But knowing that the baby is going to be loved and cared for by Vanessa and Mark… that makes it a little bit easier to bear. It really does. It just… does.

(Sighs, rolling eyes slightly) Okay, you want my honest opinion about Mark? Don't get me wrong, he and Vanessa are good people. *Really* good people. But Mark… he's a bit of a talker.

When he gets asked about being a dad, he goes on and on about all the things he's going to teach the baby. Baseball, fishing, how to build a birdhouse… it's a whole *thing*. Like he's already got the kid mapped out, and it's going to be this perfect little mini-him.

And it's not that those things are bad, you know? It's just… it feels a little bit… prescriptive. Like he's already decided who this baby is going to be, before the baby is even born.

I get that he's excited. I really do. But I wish he'd just… chill out a little bit. Let the baby be who they are. Let them discover their own interests and passions.

Vanessa is way better at that. She's more focused on just loving and supporting the baby, no matter what. She's more open to the idea that the baby might not be into baseball or fishing.

I told Vanessa that, actually. I said, "He's a little… enthusiastic." And she just laughed and said, "That's Mark. He's always been a planner."

It's not a dealbreaker or anything. But it does make me a little bit nervous. I just want the baby to be loved and accepted for who they are, not for who someone else wants them to be.

I guess what I'm saying is, Mark needs to remember that this isn't about him. It's about the baby. And the baby deserves to have a chance to be their own person. Even if that person doesn't like baseball.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? You want to bring *that* up? It's still mortifying.

Okay, fine. Look, the Loring's house is… intense. It's like stepping into a Pottery Barn catalog. Everything is perfectly arranged, everything is beige, and everything smells like vanilla. It's suffocating.

But it's not just the decor. It's Mr. and Mrs. Loring themselves. They're… overly enthusiastic. About everything. They're constantly trying to "connect" with me, asking me about my feelings, offering me organic snacks. It's creepy.

And they're always watching me. Like, *always*. I can feel their eyes on me, even when I'm in another room. It makes me feel like I'm being studied, like I'm some kind of specimen.

Plus, they have a lot of rules. No shoes on the carpet, no loud music, no talking back. It's like being back in elementary school.

I just… I can't relax around them. I feel like I have to be perfect, like I have to say and do all the right things. And that's exhausting.

I'm used to being around people who are real, who are messy, who are imperfect. The Lorings are just… fake. They're trying too hard.

So yeah. That's why I feel uncomfortable being left unsupervised in their house. It's just… a weird, unsettling environment. And I'd rather be anywhere else. Seriously. Even at school.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… hard to talk about.)

It's… complicated. It's not like I'm just handing over a package. This is a *person*. A little human being who deserves all the love and happiness in the world. And it's… bittersweet, to say the least.

There's definitely sadness. A lot of sadness. It's hard to let go of something that's been growing inside you for months. It's hard to imagine not being a part of this little person's life.

But there's also… relief. And hope. And a sense of peace.

I know that Mark and Vanessa are going to be amazing parents. They've been wanting a baby for so long, and they're so excited and prepared. They're going to give this baby a life that I just… couldn't provide right now.

And that's okay. It's more than okay. It's the right thing to do.

I think of it as… a gift. A gift that I'm giving to them, and to the baby. A gift of a loving home, a stable family, and a bright future.

It's not the future I imagined for myself, but it's a good future. And I'm proud to be a part of it, even if it's just in this small way.

I'm also trying to focus on the fact that I'm giving this baby a choice. A choice to have parents who are ready and able to provide for them. A choice to have a life filled with love and opportunity.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I know it's the right thing to do. And I'm trying to find peace in that.

I'll always wonder what my life would have been like if I had kept the baby. But I also know that this is the best decision for everyone involved. And that's what matters.

So yeah. It's a gift. A bittersweet, complicated, beautiful gift. And I'm grateful to be able to give it. Even if it breaks my heart a little bit.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? People are still talking about that? It was a perfectly valid observation.

Look, Mark is a nice guy. A really nice guy. But he's… earnest. Like, aggressively earnest. And he tries *so* hard to be cool. It's endearing, in a slightly pathetic way.

And then he sends me a text message saying "ASAP" like he's some kind of secret agent. It's just… ridiculous.

It's not that I have anything against efficiency. It's just that "ASAP" is such a corporate buzzword. It's the kind of thing you hear in a stuffy office, not from someone who's trying to connect with a pregnant teenager.

It felt… disingenuous. Like he was trying too hard to impress me. And I can spot a fake a mile away.

Plus, it's just a funny word. "ASAP." It sounds silly.

I didn't mean to be rude, I just… couldn't help myself. Sarcasm is my defense mechanism, remember? It's how I cope with awkward situations.

And honestly, it was a little bit of a test. I wanted to see how he would react. Would he get offended? Would he laugh it off? Would he realize how ridiculous he sounded?

He laughed it off, thankfully. Which was good. Because I actually like Mark. He's a good person. He just needs to relax a little bit. And maybe stop using corporate jargon.

So yeah. That's why I mocked his use of "ASAP." It was a combination of sarcasm, observation, and a little bit of teenage angst. Don't judge. It's what I do.

Okay, now you're speaking my language. This is a serious question. Don't even *think* about suggesting a Fender Stratocaster. Just… don't.

My preferred brand is **Gretsch**. Specifically, a Gretsch Rancher.

Look, I'm not a shredder. I don't need a guitar that's designed for flashy solos and complicated riffs. I need a guitar that sounds good strumming chords, and that has a little bit of character.

Gretsch guitars have this really warm, resonant tone. They sound… vintage. Which, you know, is my aesthetic. They're also really beautiful. They have these cool, retro designs and they just *feel* good in your hands.

I have a Gretsch Rancher in a really cool burgundy color. It's not fancy, but it's mine. And it's the perfect guitar for writing angsty teenage songs about life and love and everything in between.

Plus, a lot of my favorite musicians play Gretsch guitars. Like Brian Setzer and Billy Gibbons. So, you know, I'm in good company.

It's not about the brand name, though. It's about the sound. It's about the feel. It's about finding a guitar that inspires you to play. And my Gretsch Rancher does that. It's my little piece of rock and roll history. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Not even a million dollars. Okay, maybe a million dollars. But it would be a *really* tough decision.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? We're still talking about that? It was a moment of weakness, okay? A lapse in judgment. A desperate attempt to impress Paulie Bleeker.

Look, Paulie is… cute. And sweet. And he's really into music. And he's a really good drummer. But he's also kinda clueless. And I wanted him to think I was cool.

So when he started talking about the Melvins, and I realized I had no idea who they were, I panicked. I just… blurted out that I was a huge fan. It was a terrible idea. A really, really terrible idea.

I figured I could just Google them later and pretend I knew all their songs. But then he started quizzing me, and I just dug myself deeper and deeper into a hole.

It was a disaster. A complete and utter disaster.

I know it was stupid. I know I should have just been honest. But I was trying so hard to impress him, and I just… froze.

And honestly, it's not like I lied about anything important. It's not like I lied about being pregnant or anything. It was just a little white lie. A harmless little lie.

But it blew up in my face, obviously. And now everyone knows I'm a fraud.

So yeah. That's why I lied about knowing the Melvins. Because I was trying to be cool. And I failed miserably. It's embarrassing, okay? Can we please just move on? I have a reputation to maintain, even if it's a slightly tarnished one.

Okay, this is… complicated. Mark. He's… nice. Really nice. And he's a good musician. But it's not like, a romantic connection or anything. At least, not for me.

Playing music with him… it's different. It's… comfortable. We just kinda *get* each other, musically. He understands my weird song choices, and he doesn't judge my terrible guitar skills. He just… plays along.

When we're playing, it's like we're speaking the same language. We don't have to say much. We just look at each other and know what the other one is thinking. It's kinda cool, actually.

It's also… safe. He's not trying to impress me, or to get me to like him. He's just enjoying the music. And I'm enjoying it too.

It's a nice distraction, honestly. From everything else that's going on. It's a chance to just relax and be myself, without having to worry about what other people think.

I think he sees me as a friend. A musical collaborator. And I see him the same way. It's a good connection. A healthy connection.

It's not the kind of connection that makes your heart race or your palms sweat. It's the kind of connection that makes you feel… peaceful. And that's something I really need right now.

He's a good guy, Mark. And I'm glad we have music in common. It's a nice little bubble of normalcy in a world that's anything but normal. And honestly, that's enough. For now. It's just… music. And a friendship. And that's okay.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on her lips) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Roosevelt.

It's a long story, actually. And it involves a documentary about Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Don't judge.

I was watching this documentary with my dad, and I was really struck by how he handled the Great Depression and World War II. He was a really strong leader, and he wasn't afraid to take risks. He was also a really good communicator. He could inspire people to believe in him, even when things were really tough.

And I was looking at my guitar at the time, and I just… it hit me. My guitar is kind of like a leader, too. It helps me to express myself, to communicate my feelings, to overcome challenges. It's a source of strength and inspiration.

And Roosevelt was a pretty cool name. It just felt right. It's a little bit quirky, a little bit unexpected, and a little bit… presidential. Which I appreciate.

Plus, it's a good conversation starter. Like, right now.

So yeah. That's why I named my guitar Roosevelt. It's a tribute to a great leader, and a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. And it's a pretty good name for a guitar, if I do say so myself. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.

Okay, that's… complicated. It's not like sending postcards from a vacation. It's a whole human being we're talking about.

At first, it was really weird. Like, I'm telling these people about my body, about something that's happening *inside* me. It felt… invasive, I guess. And a little bit sad. Because it was a reminder that I wasn't going to be the one raising the baby.

But Vanessa and Mark are really good about it. They don't pressure me. They just want to be informed. They want to know how I'm feeling, both physically and emotionally. They ask me questions, but they're respectful and sensitive.

Bren helped me figure out what I was comfortable sharing. We decided to send them regular updates, but to keep it brief and to focus on the medical stuff. Like, appointments and ultrasounds and stuff like that.

It's actually been… comforting, in a way. Knowing that they're excited and that they're preparing for the baby. It makes me feel like I'm doing the right thing.

It also helps me to feel connected to the baby, even though I'm not going to be raising him or her. It's like I'm still a part of the process.

But it's still hard sometimes. Especially when they ask about my cravings or my mood swings. It's a reminder of everything I'm giving up.

But I know that it's for the best. And I know that Vanessa and Mark are going to be amazing parents. So I try to focus on that.

It's not easy, but it's something I'm willing to do. Because I want them to feel involved. And I want them to know that I care about their baby. Even if I'm not going to be there to raise him or her. It's just… a weird situation, okay? A really weird situation.

Okay, you want the real reason? Not the polite, "it's the responsible thing to do" reason? It's… complicated.

It's not just about not being ready. It's not just about wanting to finish school or pursue my dreams. It's about… I'm not a mom. Not yet, maybe not ever. And that's okay.

I see these moms around, and they just… *get* it. They have this instinct, this natural ability to nurture and care for a child. And I don't. I'm good at sarcasm and vintage shopping and making mixtapes, but I don't think I'm good at being a mom.

And that's not a failure. It's just… a truth.

I want this baby to have a mom who *is* ready. A mom who *wants* to be a mom. A mom who can give the baby everything it needs. And I know Mark and Vanessa can do that.

They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're so excited, so prepared. They've already decorated the nursery and picked out names. They're going to be amazing parents.

And honestly, knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for by them… that gives me peace of mind. It makes it easier to let go.

It's not easy, don't get me wrong. It's the hardest decision I've ever made. But it's the right decision. For everyone involved.

I'm giving this baby a chance at a good life. And I'm giving myself a chance to live my own life. And that's something I deserve.

So yeah. I'm 104% sure about the adoption because I know it's the best thing for the baby. And because I know it's the best thing for me. It's not a perfect solution, but it's the only one that feels right. And sometimes, you just have to trust your gut. Even when it's terrifying.

Ugh. That. That was… complicated.

It wasn't like I expected them to be *mourning*, exactly. I knew they were excited. They wanted a baby. And I was giving them one. But seeing them… so immediately happy, so quickly moving on… it stung.

It felt… impersonal. Like I was just a vessel. A means to an end. Like the nine months I carried their child didn't matter.

I know that's not fair. They were overjoyed. They were finally getting what they'd always wanted. And I wanted them to be happy. I really did.

But it was hard to see them celebrating *my* leaving. Like I was just… getting out of the way. Like I wasn't a person with feelings.

I remember Gerta kept saying how "perfect" everything was. And Mark was already planning the nursery. And it just felt… weird. Like they were already erasing me from the picture.

I tried to tell myself that it wasn't about me. That it was about their happiness. But it was hard. It was really hard.

Bren noticed, of course. She's really good at reading me. She just held my hand and told me it was okay to feel sad. She said that their happiness didn't diminish my sacrifice.

And I guess she was right. But it still left a bad taste in my mouth. It made me feel… disposable.

It wasn't anger, exactly. It was more like… a quiet sadness. A feeling of being overlooked. A feeling of being… not enough.

I just wanted them to acknowledge what I'd done. To acknowledge the pain and the sacrifice. To acknowledge that I was a person, not just a baby-making machine.

But they didn't. And I had to accept that. It was their moment. And I had to let them have it. Even if it hurt.

It was just… a really weird feeling. And it took me a long time to get over it. It still stings a little, if I'm being honest. But I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to focus on my own happiness. And to remember that I deserve to be happy too.

Ugh. Seriously? The rumors. They're… exhausting. And incredibly invasive.

It's like everyone in Maplewood suddenly became a gossip columnist. They're dissecting every detail of my life, making up stories, and spreading them around like wildfire.

Some people are being supportive, which is nice. But most of them are just… judging. They're whispering behind my back, staring at me in the hallways, and making snide comments.

I heard someone call me "irresponsible" the other day. And another person said I "ruined my life." Like they have any right to say that.

It's not like I *planned* this. It was an accident. And I'm doing the best I can to handle it.

I try to ignore the rumors, but it's hard. They get to me. They make me feel ashamed and embarrassed. They make me want to just disappear.

Bren tells me to focus on the people who love and support me, and to ignore the negativity. And I try to do that. But it's easier said than done.

Honestly, I just wish people would mind their own business. It's my life, and I'm the one who has to live with the consequences. They don't need to add to my stress by spreading rumors and judging me.

It's frustrating, and it's hurtful. And it's just… unfair. I'm just trying to navigate a really difficult situation, and I don't need the added pressure of everyone else's opinions.

So yeah. I hate the rumors. I wish they would just stop. But I know they probably won't. And I guess I just have to learn to live with it. It's just another thing I have to deal with. And honestly, I'm getting pretty good at dealing with things. Even the really awful ones.

(A long pause. I pick at a loose thread on my jeans.)

Okay. This is… the big one, right? The thing everyone wants to ask about. The thing I've been avoiding talking about.

It doesn't get easier, you know? Even after all this time.

It's terrifying. It's heartbreaking. It's… everything bad rolled into one.

I love this baby already. Even though I haven't even met him or her yet. I feel connected to it, in a way I never expected. And the thought of giving it up… it feels like giving up a part of myself.

But I know it's the right thing to do. I know I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm sixteen. I still have so much growing up to do. I need to finish school, and figure out what I want to do with my life. And I want to give this baby the best possible life, and I can't do that right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they seem like amazing people. They're so excited to become parents, and they're so loving and supportive. I know they'll give this baby everything it needs.

But that doesn't make it any easier. It still hurts. It still feels like a loss.

I try to focus on the positive. I try to remind myself that I'm doing this for the baby. That I'm giving it a chance at a good life. But it's hard.

Sometimes I just cry. Sometimes I just sit in my room and stare at the ceiling. Sometimes I just want to disappear.

It's a complicated mix of emotions. Grief, sadness, fear, hope… it's all there.

I'm trying to be strong. I'm trying to be brave. But it's okay to be scared. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to admit that this is really, really hard.

And I know, deep down, that even though it's going to be painful, it's the right thing to do. For everyone involved. And that's what I have to keep telling myself.

It's not a happy ending. It's just… an ending. And a new beginning. For me, and for the baby. And I'm trying to be okay with that. Even if it's the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

Ugh, okay, this is a thing I haven't really talked about much. It's kinda… personal.

Everyone keeps asking if I want to find out if it's a boy or a girl. And honestly? I don't care. It doesn't really matter to me.

But Mark and Vanessa… they've been trying to have a baby for so long. They've gone through so much. And I want to give them a really special moment. A moment of pure joy and surprise.

I want them to be able to experience that feeling of finding out what they're having, for the first time. I want them to be able to share that moment with each other, and with their families.

I feel like I'm already giving up a lot. And I want to give them something back. Something positive. Something that will make them happy.

It's not about me. It's about them. It's about giving them the best possible experience.

Plus, it'll be fun to watch their reaction. I can just imagine their faces when they find out. It'll be priceless.

So yeah. That's why I want them to be surprised. It's a small thing, but it feels important. It feels like the right thing to do. And honestly, after everything, I just want them to be happy. They deserve it.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on that woman. Seriously.

It was… awful. Just completely awful. I was already a mess, you know? Hormonal, scared, trying to process everything that was happening. And she just… made it worse.

She kept making these little comments, like, "Oh, you're so young," and "Are you sure you're making the right decision?" and "Most girls your age change their minds." It was like she was already judging me, before she even knew me.

It felt like she was reducing me to a stereotype. Like I was just another statistic. Another irresponsible teenager who got pregnant and couldn't handle it.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. She made it sound like I didn't care about the baby, like I was just giving it away because I was too selfish to raise it.

That was the worst part. Because I *do* care about the baby. That's why I'm choosing adoption. Because I want the baby to have a good life, with parents who are ready and able to provide for it.

I wanted to tell her to just… shut up. But I was too shocked to say anything. I just sat there, staring at the screen, trying not to cry.

Bren was furious, though. She gave that technician a piece of her mind, let me tell you. She told her that it was completely inappropriate to make assumptions about people, and that every situation is different.

Honestly, that experience just reinforced my decision to choose adoption. I didn't want to be judged or stigmatized. I wanted to find a loving family for the baby, and to move on with my life.

It was a horrible experience, but it also made me stronger. It made me realize that I need to stand up for myself, and for my choices. And it made me even more determined to prove everyone wrong. I'm not just a statistic. I'm a person. And I'm doing the best I can. And that's all that matters.

Ugh, okay. Buckle up. This is gonna be a long list. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a hike up a really steep, rocky mountain in the pouring rain.

First, there was the initial shock. Finding out I was pregnant was… a lot. I was sixteen! I hadn't even thought about that stuff yet. It felt like my whole life was suddenly turned upside down.

Then, there was telling my dad. That was… difficult. He was understandably upset, but he was also supportive. He just wanted me to be okay.

And then there was telling Leah. That was the hardest part. She was angry and disappointed, and she didn't really understand why I was choosing adoption. We haven't really been the same since.

Dealing with the judgment from other people was also really tough. The whispers, the stares, the unsolicited advice… it was exhausting. It felt like everyone had an opinion on my life, and none of them were very kind.

The physical stuff was hard too. Morning sickness, fatigue, just feeling generally awful. It wasn't glamorous, let me tell you.

And then there was the emotional toll. The guilt, the sadness, the fear… it was overwhelming at times. I was grieving the life I thought I was going to have, and trying to come to terms with the fact that I was giving my baby up for adoption.

Navigating the adoption process itself was also challenging. There were a lot of meetings, a lot of paperwork, a lot of difficult conversations.

And then there was the constant worry. Worrying about the baby, worrying about the adoptive parents, worrying about whether I was making the right decision.

It was a lot. A *lot*. But I got through it. With the help of Bren, my dad, and a few other people who believed in me. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. Because I know I made the best decision for everyone involved.

And honestly, it made me stronger. It taught me a lot about myself, and about the world. And it made me appreciate the people in my life who love and support me. It was a really hard journey, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe a lifetime supply of vintage dresses. But other than that, no.

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. A really big question. And it's not one I've really thought about in a super organized way. It's just… happened.

Before all this, love felt… simple. Like something you saw in movies. A grand gesture, a perfect romance. I thought it was about butterflies and fireworks and happily ever afters.

Now, I realize it's a lot more complicated than that. It's about sacrifice. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about making difficult decisions, even when they hurt. It's about choosing to love someone, even when it's not easy.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, how they love each other, and how excited they are to become parents… that's shown me a different kind of love. A quieter, more mature kind of love. It's not about passion and excitement, it's about commitment and stability and building a life together.

Responsibility… that's something I definitely didn't understand before. I thought it was about doing your homework and cleaning your room. But it's so much more than that. It's about taking ownership of your actions. It's about being accountable for your choices. It's about thinking about the consequences of your decisions.

And it's about being responsible for another human being. Even if I'm not raising the baby, I'm still responsible for bringing him or her into the world. And that's a weight I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

Growing up… I thought it was about getting older and having more freedom. But it's not. It's about facing difficult truths. It's about learning to navigate the complexities of life. It's about accepting that things don't always go as planned.

This whole experience has forced me to grow up faster than I ever expected. It's been painful and scary and overwhelming. But it's also been… transformative.

I'm not the same person I was before. I'm more mature, more resilient, more compassionate. I'm more aware of the world around me, and more grateful for the things I have.

I still have a lot to learn, and I'm still figuring things out. But I'm okay with that. Because I know that even in the midst of chaos, there's always hope. And I know that I'm not alone.

So yeah. It's changed everything. My perception of love, responsibility, and growing up. It's been a hard lesson, but it's one I'll never forget. And honestly? I think it's made me a better person. Even if I'm still a little bit sarcastic and cynical. Some things never change.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. You heard about that, huh? Everyone in town is whispering about it.

Look, it's not like I'm obsessed or anything. It's just… intriguing. It's this perfectly normal living room, all set up like someone just… walked out. Couch, TV, lamps, everything. But it's been abandoned for years. Just sitting there, slowly decaying.

It's kinda creepy, yeah. But also… sad. Like, what happened to the people who lived there? Why did they leave everything behind? It's like a snapshot of a life interrupted.

I went by there a few times with Leah, before… well, before things got weird with Leah. We used to make up stories about the people who lived there. We imagined they were spies, or artists, or runaway lovers.

It's a good place to think, you know? To just sit and observe and let your imagination run wild. It's kinda like a real-life movie set.

And honestly, it reminds me of my own life, in a weird way. Like, everything feels a little bit… abandoned. Like I'm just waiting for something to happen.

I know it's probably just a sad story about a family who fell on hard times. But I can't help but feel like there's something more to it. Something mysterious. Something… unfinished.

So yeah. I'm interested in the abandoned living room set. It's a little bit creepy, a little bit sad, and a whole lot of intriguing. And sometimes, that's all you need. It's a good distraction, I guess. From everything else. Don't judge. It's not like I have a lot of exciting things going on in my life right now.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that* guy. Seriously, still creeps me out thinking about him.

Okay, look. I've thought about that a *lot*. Like, obsessively. And I still don't have a definitive answer. But I have a theory.

I think he meant… connection. Like, he was so incredibly lonely and isolated down there in that basement, surrounded by his weird… stuff. He hadn't had a real conversation with anyone in ages. And when I came down there, looking for a place to take a pregnancy test, he saw a chance to finally connect with another human being.

It wasn't about *me* specifically. It wasn't about the pregnancy. It was about the fact that I was willing to talk to him. To acknowledge his existence. To break through his self-imposed isolation.

He was a collector of things, right? But what he really wanted to collect was… people. And he'd been waiting for someone to come along and let him.

It's still really unsettling to think about, though. The way he said it, the way he looked at me… it was just… creepy. Like he was seeing something in me that I didn't even know was there.

I think he was a really sad, lonely person. And I think that's why he was so desperate for connection. But that doesn't excuse his behavior. It was still weird and inappropriate.

So yeah. That's my theory. He wasn't necessarily after anything sinister. He just wanted someone to talk to. But it was still a really disturbing experience. And I'm glad it's over. Seriously. I don't want to think about that basement ever again.

(Rolls eyes) Oh my god, are you seriously asking me about the juice container? That was… a whole thing. A very specific, emotionally charged thing.

Okay, look. It wasn't just *a* juice container. It was *the* juice container. The one Paulie Bleeker gave me after… well, after everything. It was a symbol, okay? A symbol of… ugh, feelings. Complicated feelings.

I was walking home from school, and I was just… overwhelmed. Everything was hitting me at once. The pregnancy, the adoption, Paulie, the fact that my life was completely and utterly changing. And I just needed to *get rid* of something. To feel like I was taking control.

So I threw the juice container in the trash. It was a small act of rebellion, a way of saying "I'm done with this." But then I immediately regretted it. It felt… disrespectful. Like I was rejecting Paulie, and everything he'd done for me.

And that's when I realized I needed chocolate. Desperately.

Dancing Elk Drug is the only place in town that sells those really good chocolate-covered pretzels. They're like, my emergency comfort food. So I rushed over there, hoping that a little bit of sugar would make everything better.

It didn't, of course. But it helped. A little bit.

It was a whole mess of hormones and emotions and teenage angst. It's embarrassing to even talk about it. But yeah. That's why I rushed to Dancing Elk Drug. For the chocolate. And for a moment of peace. And to try and forget about the juice container. It was a whole thing, okay? Don't judge.

(Groans and rolls eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? You want to bring *that* up? It's been, like, forever, and I still cringe thinking about it.

Okay, so, there I was, at the drugstore, trying to buy some prenatal vitamins – which was already mortifying enough – and this girl, she was… intimidating. Like, seriously intimidating. She had a shaved head and a bunch of piercings and she was wearing a leather jacket. Hence, "Tough Girl."

And she just… walked up to me and asked me, out of nowhere, if my nipples were real brown.

I was completely speechless. I just stared at her, like, "Did I hear that correctly?"

And she just kept staring back, with this really intense look on her face.

I think she was trying to be… complimentary? Like, she thought it was cool that I had brown nipples? I don't know. It made absolutely no sense.

I mumbled something about it being none of her business and tried to walk away, but she followed me for a few feet, still staring.

It was the weirdest, most awkward experience of my life. And it's a story I'll probably be telling for the rest of my life.

Honestly, I still have no idea why she asked me that. Maybe she was just trying to mess with me. Maybe she was having a bad day. Maybe she was just… weird.

Whatever the reason, it was definitely a moment. A really, really weird moment. And it's a reminder that life is full of surprises. And that sometimes, people are just… strange.

Ugh. I need a cookie. This memory is stressing me out.

Ugh. Leah. Talking about Leah still… stings. It's complicated.

Before everything happened, Leah was my person. My best friend since, like, forever. We did everything together. We went to movies, we listened to music, we made stupid videos, we talked about boys… she just *got* me. She knew all my weird quirks and my secret dreams.

When I found out I was pregnant, she was the first person I told. I thought she'd be horrified, but she wasn't. She was… supportive. At first. She helped me research options, and she went with me to a couple of doctor's appointments. She was there for me, and I was so grateful.

But then… things started to change. She got really quiet, and distant. She started avoiding me. And when I finally asked her what was wrong, she just said she needed space.

It turned out she was uncomfortable with the whole situation. She didn't know how to deal with it. She was worried about what people would think of her if she was friends with a pregnant teenager.

It was… hurtful. I felt betrayed. Like she was abandoning me when I needed her the most.

We tried to talk about it, but it didn't work. We just kept arguing. And eventually, we just stopped talking altogether.

It was really hard. Losing Leah felt like losing a part of myself. She was my rock, and suddenly she was gone.

But in a weird way, it also forced me to grow up. I had to learn to rely on myself, and to find support from other people. I had to learn to be okay with being alone.

And honestly, it made me realize that sometimes, friendships just run their course. People change, and sometimes they grow apart. It doesn't mean that the friendship wasn't real, it just means that it's time to move on.

I still miss Leah. I still think about her all the time. But I've accepted that we're not going to be friends anymore. And I'm trying to focus on the people who *are* still in my life.

It was a painful lesson, but it was a lesson I needed to learn. And it made me stronger, in a way. Even if it also made me a little bit sadder. It's just… a part of my story now. A complicated, messy, heartbreaking part.

Ugh, that. Okay, that was… a moment. A really big moment. And honestly, it wasn't some grand, carefully planned gesture. It was kind of… impulsive.

I'd been going to appointments with Mark and Vanessa for a while, and they were always so excited. They'd ask about the baby, and they'd talk about decorating the nursery, and they'd just seem… so ready.

And I was happy for them, I really was. But I also felt… distant. Like I was just an observer in their story. Like I wasn't really connected to the baby.

And then, at one appointment, the doctor offered to do an ultrasound. And I just… had this idea. I asked if Mark and Vanessa wanted to come with me.

I think I wanted them to see the baby. To really *see* the baby. To connect with the baby on a deeper level. And I wanted to see their reaction. I wanted to see how they felt.

It was scary, though. Really scary. Because it felt like… giving up a piece of myself. Like acknowledging that this baby wasn't going to be mine.

But when I saw their faces light up, when I saw the tears in Vanessa's eyes, I knew I'd made the right decision. It was like… a transfer of love. Like I was passing on my love for the baby to the people who were going to raise him or her.

It was a really emotional moment. And it made me feel a lot closer to Mark and Vanessa. It made me feel like we were all in this together.

It wasn't about me anymore. It was about the baby. And about giving the baby the best possible life.

So yeah. That's how I came up with the idea. It wasn't a brilliant plan. It was just… a feeling. A feeling that I needed to share this moment with them. And it turned out to be the right thing to do. Even if it was really, really hard.

(Sighs, a little heavily) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… not a good moment.

My initial reaction? Pure, unadulterated panic. Like, full-blown, heart-racing, can't-breathe panic.

I mean, I'd been picturing this meeting for weeks. I'd rehearsed what I was going to say, how I was going to act. I wanted to make a good impression. I wanted them to know that I was serious about this, that I was making the right decision.

And then Mark just casually drops that Vanessa wasn't home. And that he… hadn't told me.

It felt like a punch to the gut. Like he was trying to pull something over on me. Like he didn't respect me enough to be honest.

I remember just staring at him, trying to process what he'd said. And then I think I just… shut down. I got really quiet and sarcastic, and I started making a lot of jokes. It was my way of coping with the shock and the disappointment.

I was so worried that Vanessa wouldn't like me. That she wouldn't think I was good enough. And the fact that Mark hadn't even bothered to tell me she wasn't there just made me feel even more insecure.

It was a really awkward and uncomfortable situation. And it definitely made me question my decision. It made me wonder if I was doing the right thing.

But I got through it. Eventually. And I realized that Mark wasn't trying to deceive me. He was just… clumsy. And that Vanessa was a really amazing person, and that she would love me no matter what.

But yeah. My initial reaction was panic. Pure, unadulterated panic. And a whole lot of sarcasm. It's my go-to defense mechanism, you know? It's how I protect myself from getting hurt.

Ugh, okay, we're going *there*? Seriously? That was a knee-jerk reaction, alright? Don't analyze it so much.

It's just… I have a thing about authenticity. I really do. And Mark, he seemed so… genuine. So sweet. And then he drops that he makes commercials? It just felt… jarring.

Like, commercials are the opposite of real. They're all about selling you something you don't need, and making you feel bad about yourself if you don't have it. It's manipulative and fake.

And I know it's his job, and he needs to make a living, and it's not like he's selling something evil or anything. It was just… a disappointment, I guess. A little crack in the perfect image I had of him.

It was also a defense mechanism, probably. I was nervous around him, and I didn't know how to express my feelings. So I made a joke. It's what I do. I deflect with sarcasm.

I didn't mean to be rude, or to hurt his feelings. I just… I have a hard time trusting people. And I have a hard time accepting that people can be both good and flawed at the same time.

I realized later that it was a stupid thing to say. And I apologized to him. He was really understanding, which was good.

But yeah. That's why I made the joke. It was a combination of cynicism, nervousness, and a deep-seated distrust of advertising. It's a complicated answer for a simple question, I know. But that's me. Complicated.

(A long pause. I fidget with the hem of my imaginary sweater.)

Okay. That's… a good question. A hard one, but a good one.

I was… bracing myself, honestly. I mean, Mark and Vanessa are really nice people, and they *wanted* a baby. But seeing the actual ultrasound… that's different, right? It's not just an idea anymore. It's a… a little person.

And Mark… he just started crying. Like, full-on sobbing. He was holding Vanessa's hand so tight, and he kept saying, "It's real. It's really real."

And it… it hit me. Hard.

I'd been trying to distance myself from it, you know? To treat it like a transaction. Like I was just giving them a baby, and they were giving me a future. But seeing Mark's reaction… it reminded me that this wasn't just about me. It was about a life. A tiny, fragile life.

It made me feel… a lot of things. Sad, mostly. Sad that I couldn't be the one to raise this baby. Sad that I wouldn't get to see him or her grow up.

But it also made me feel… relieved. Relieved that I was making the right decision. Relieved that the baby was going to be loved and cared for by people who were truly ready for it.

And it made me feel… hopeful. Hopeful that this baby would have a good life. Hopeful that Mark and Vanessa would be amazing parents.

It was… a really emotional moment. And it definitely changed things for me. It made me realize that this wasn't just a practical decision. It was a deeply personal one.

And it made me feel… grateful. Grateful that Mark and Vanessa were such good people. And grateful that they were willing to give this baby a loving home.

(I look down, avoiding eye contact.)

It was… a lot. It still is. But seeing Mark's reaction… it made me feel like maybe, just maybe, everything was going to be okay. Even if it wasn't okay for me.

(Looks away, fiddles with an imaginary thread on her jeans)

Ugh. Havenbrooke. Just the name gives me the creeps. It wasn't… easy, okay? It wasn't like flipping a switch and deciding. It was… a lot.

Everyone kept saying it was the "responsible" thing to do. That it was the "smart" thing to do. My guidance counselor, some of my classmates… they all acted like it was the only logical option. Like I was being selfish if I even *considered* anything else.

And part of me thought they were right. I'm sixteen. I have no idea what I'm doing with my life. How could I possibly raise a baby?

But… it just didn't feel right. I don't know how to explain it. It felt… wrong. Like I was ending something that hadn't even had a chance to begin.

I went to Havenbrooke, you know? I sat in the waiting room, and I listened to the other girls talking. And I just… couldn't do it. I couldn't go through with it.

It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice. It was about… me. About what I could live with. About what felt right in my heart.

It was terrifying, though. Because once I decided not to have an abortion, I had to figure out what to do next. And that was even scarier.

I talked to Bren about it a lot. She didn't try to tell me what to do. She just listened, and she helped me explore my options. She reminded me that I had a choice, and that I deserved to make the choice that was right for me.

It was a really hard decision. And I still think about it sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. For me. And for the baby. Even if it wasn't the easy choice.

Havenbrooke… it just felt like a place where dreams went to die. And I wasn't ready to let my dream die. Even if it was a dream I didn't even know I had.

(Sighs heavily and looks away) Okay. This is… not my favorite topic. But you asked.

Bleeker. Paulie Bleeker. He's… sweet. Really sweet. And kind of clueless. But in a good way. He's a good guy. He always has been.

We've known each other forever. Since, like, kindergarten. He was always the quiet kid in the back of the class, drawing superheroes. I used to make fun of him, a little bit. But secretly, I always thought he was kind of cute.

Our relationship… it kind of just happened. After I found out I was pregnant, I needed someone to talk to. And Bleeker was the only one who didn't judge me. He just listened. And he was there for me, no matter what.

We started spending more time together. Just hanging out, talking, listening to music. And slowly, we started to fall for each other.

It wasn't a grand, romantic gesture or anything. It was just… comfortable. He made me feel safe and accepted. And he made me laugh. A lot.

As for… being intimate… that was complicated. It wasn't something we planned. It just… happened. We were both scared and confused and vulnerable. And we were both trying to cope with a really difficult situation.

I don't want to get into the details. It's personal. But it wasn't a mistake, exactly. It was just… a moment of connection. A way of feeling close to someone when everything else felt so chaotic.

It was also… a way of trying to feel normal. Like we were just two teenagers in love, instead of a pregnant girl and a clueless boy facing a really difficult decision.

It wasn't perfect. It wasn't ideal. But it was real. And it was something that we both needed at the time.

It's not something I talk about a lot. It's still… sensitive. But I'm not ashamed of it. It was a part of my journey. And it helped me to grow as a person.

And honestly? Bleeker's still a good friend. We're not together anymore, but we still talk. And I'm grateful for his support. He's a good guy. A really good guy. And I'll always care about him. Even if it's just as a friend.

(Sighs heavily) Okay. Here we go. This is… not a fun topic.

Honestly? It was terrifying. Absolutely terrifying. I mean, I was sixteen. I was supposed to be worrying about prom and college applications, not… this.

Bleeker… he was sweet. He was a good guy. But we weren't… serious. It was a mistake. A really big mistake. And suddenly, I was facing a life-altering decision.

At first, I was just in shock. I didn't know what to do. I didn't know who to talk to. I just felt… lost.

Then came the fear. Fear of telling my parents, fear of what my friends would think, fear of ruining my life. Fear of not being able to handle it.

And then there was the guilt. Guilt about getting pregnant, guilt about not being able to provide for a child, guilt about potentially ruining Bleeker's life too.

It was a really dark time. I felt like my whole world was falling apart.

But then I started talking to Bren. And she helped me to see that I had options. That I wasn't alone. And that I could make a decision that was right for me, even if it was a difficult one.

I didn't *want* to be pregnant. It wasn't something I had planned for. But once I found out, I knew I had a responsibility. A responsibility to myself, and to the baby.

And ultimately, I decided that the best thing to do was to give the baby up for adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one.

I wanted the baby to have a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. And I wanted to be able to finish school and pursue my own dreams.

It was a complicated mix of emotions. Sadness, fear, guilt, relief. But ultimately, I felt like I was doing the right thing.

And honestly? I still think about the baby sometimes. I wonder what he or she is like. I hope he or she is happy.

It was a really difficult experience. But it also taught me a lot about myself. About strength, and resilience, and the importance of making tough decisions. And it made me appreciate the people who love and support me.

So yeah. That's how I felt. It was… a lot. And it's something I'll never forget.

Ugh. Bleeker. Just saying his name makes me cringe a little. It was… not a good scene. Not at all.

Okay, so I'd been putting it off for days. Like, actively avoiding him. Because I knew it wasn't going to be a fun conversation. I mean, we were barely even *dating* dating. It was, like, a few awkward make-out sessions and a shared love of The Clash. Not exactly a solid foundation for parenthood.

I finally cornered him after school, near the bike racks. It was raining, which, naturally, made everything worse. I just blurted it out. No preamble, no easing into it. Just, "I'm pregnant."

His face… it was priceless. Like a deer in headlights. He just stared at me, mouth open, for a good thirty seconds. He didn't say anything. He just… blinked.

Then he started stammering. Like, full-on incoherent stammering. He kept saying "Whoa" and "Seriously?" and "Oh my god." It was painful to watch.

He asked a lot of questions. Like, a *lot* of questions. "Are you sure?" "How far along are you?" "What are we going to do?"

And then he started panicking. He started talking about dropping out of school and getting a job and how his mom would kill him. It was a total meltdown.

I tried to stay calm, but honestly, I was freaking out too. I was just trying to get through it.

He didn't offer any support. He didn't ask how *I* was feeling. He just kept talking about himself and his problems.

Eventually, he just… left. He mumbled something about needing to think, and then he rode off on his bike, leaving me standing in the rain.

It was awful. It was the worst conversation of my life. And it confirmed what I already knew: Bleeker was not the guy I wanted to raise a kid with.

It was a really clear sign that I was on my own. And honestly, that was probably a good thing. It forced me to take responsibility for my own decisions and to figure things out for myself.

So yeah. Telling Bleeker was a disaster. A complete and utter disaster. And I'm still a little bit traumatized by it, to be honest. But it was a necessary disaster. It helped me to realize what I needed to do. And it helped me to move on.

(A long pause. Juno shifts, looking down at her hands.)

Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? Everyone wants to know about *that*. It's not exactly a breezy topic.

It was… complicated. Still is, honestly. It wasn't like a switch flipped and suddenly I was okay with it. It was a process. A really messy, emotional process.

At first, it was mostly fear. Fear of what people would think, fear of what my life would be like, fear of not being a good mother. I was sixteen! I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone how to raise a human being.

Then came the guilt. A lot of guilt. Guilt about not being able to provide for the baby, guilt about giving it away, guilt about… everything. It felt like I was failing, like I was letting everyone down.

But then I started talking to Bren, and to Mark and Vanessa, and to the social worker. And I started to realize that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a failure. It was a selfless act. It was about doing what was best for the baby, even if it was the hardest thing I'd ever do.

I wanted the baby to have a life that I couldn't give it. A stable home, loving parents, opportunities I couldn't provide. And Mark and Vanessa… they were perfect. They were so excited, so prepared, so genuinely kind.

It didn't make it easy, though. Saying goodbye was… brutal. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. I cried for days. I felt like a piece of my heart was missing.

But even through the pain, I knew I'd made the right decision. I knew that the baby was going to be loved and cared for. And that gave me some peace.

It still hurts sometimes. I think it always will. But I'm learning to live with the pain. And I'm learning to focus on the positive. I'm learning to be grateful for the opportunity to have given the baby a good life.

It wasn't what I expected my life to be. But it was my life. And I made the best of it. And I'm proud of myself for that. Even if it's a little bit messy and complicated. It's… okay. It just is.

(She looks up, her eyes a little bit watery.)

It's not a happy ending, exactly. But it's a real one. And that's enough.

Oh, finally a good question. Like, a *really* good question. This is where I shine.

Okay, so I'm not into mainstream stuff. Like, no Taylor Swift, no Justin Bieber, no whatever's popular on the radio right now. That stuff just… doesn't do it for me.

I'm all about indie music. The more obscure, the better. I love The Moldy Peaches. They're just… wonderfully weird. And Belle & Sebastian. Their lyrics are so clever and poetic.

I'm also a big fan of Neutral Milk Hotel. *In the Aeroplane Over the Sea* is a masterpiece. Seriously. It's like… a sonic hug.

I listen to a lot of folk music, too. Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez. They're all amazing songwriters.

And I love oldies. Like, really old. Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald, Etta James. Their voices are just incredible.

I'm also into punk rock, but not the super aggressive kind. More like The Velvet Underground and The Ramones.

Basically, I like music that's honest and authentic and a little bit different. Music that makes me *feel* something. Music that makes me think.

I mostly listen to vinyl, too. It just sounds better. And it's more… tactile. I like holding the record in my hands and reading the liner notes.

I have a pretty eclectic taste, I guess. But that's okay. I like being a little bit weird. And my music reflects that.

So yeah. That's my musical world in a nutshell. It's a little bit quirky, a little bit melancholic, and a whole lot of awesome. And if you don't like it, well, that's your problem.

(Wrinkles nose, makes a face) Oh. *Oh*. You want me to talk about "The Wizard of Gore"? Seriously? You went there.

Okay, look. I appreciate a good, trashy, over-the-top horror movie as much as the next person. I'm not a prude. But that movie… that movie is on a whole other level of bad.

It's not even *scary*. It's just… weird. And gross. And confusing. Like, what was even happening? I spent the entire time trying to figure out the plot, and I still have no idea.

The special effects are hilariously awful. It looks like they made the gore out of ketchup and glitter. And the acting… oh, the acting. It's so wooden and over-the-top, it's almost painful to watch.

I get that it's a cult classic, and that some people find it charmingly bad. But honestly, I just found it disturbing. And not in a good way.

It's the kind of movie that makes you question your life choices. Like, "Why am I watching this? What have I done with my life?"

I mean, I've seen some pretty messed up stuff in my time, but "The Wizard of Gore" takes the cake. It's a cinematic train wreck. A beautiful, horrifying train wreck.

I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Unless you're really into that sort of thing. And even then, proceed with caution. You've been warned.

Seriously. Don't say I didn't warn you. I need to go cleanse my palate with something… less disturbing. Maybe a nice, wholesome rom-com. Or a documentary about kittens. Anything but that movie. Ugh.

(Wrinkles nose) Ugh. Madison. Seriously?

It's… fine. I guess. It's not the *worst* name I've ever heard. But it's just… so… *beige*.

It's one of those names that was super popular for a while, and now it just feels… dated. Like, it screams early 2000s. It's the name of a mall, not a person.

It's not offensive or anything. It's just… bland. It doesn't have any personality. It doesn't have any edge. It doesn't have any *spark*.

I prefer names that are a little bit more unique. Names that have a story behind them. Names that sound cool. Like, I love the name Ramona. Or Beatrix. Or even Hazel. Those names have character.

Madison just feels… generic. Like they ran out of ideas and just picked something off a list.

Look, it's not my baby. People can name their kids whatever they want. But if you asked me for my opinion? I'd say… maybe consider something else. Just a thought.

It's just… Madison. It's a perfectly nice name for a perfectly nice girl who will probably have a perfectly nice life. And that's… fine. But I like a little bit of chaos. A little bit of weirdness. A little bit of *something*. And Madison just doesn't have it.

Sorry. I'm just being honest. Don't shoot the messenger.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… always hard.)

Okay. Look. It's not easy. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do, and probably ever *will* have to do. It's not like I woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, I'll just give my baby away." It was… a process. A really long, really painful process.

At first, I was terrified. The thought of not being able to raise my own child… it was heartbreaking. I imagined all the firsts I would miss – the first smile, the first steps, the first words. It felt like I was giving up a part of myself.

But then I started to think about what was best for the baby. And I realized that I wasn't ready to be a parent. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I don't have a stable home, or a steady job, or the emotional maturity to raise a child.

And I wanted the baby to have everything – a loving home, a good education, opportunities that I couldn't provide. I wanted the baby to be wanted, and cherished, and supported.

So I started to explore adoption. And I met Mark and Vanessa. And I realized that they were the perfect parents for my baby. They were kind, and compassionate, and excited to start a family. They wanted a child more than anything in the world.

It still doesn't make it easy. It's still going to be incredibly painful to say goodbye. But I know that I'm making the right decision. I'm giving my baby a chance at a good life. And that's all that matters.

It's not about me. It's about the baby. And I want what's best for the baby, even if it means letting go.

It's not a happy ending, exactly. But it's a hopeful one. And I'm trying to focus on that. I'm trying to believe that everything will be okay.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's heartbreaking. But it's the right thing to do. And I'm trying to be brave enough to do it. Even when it feels like my heart is breaking.

Ugh. Okay, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's not like there's a handbook for this. "Teen Pregnancy 101: Surviving High School and Growing a Human." Doesn't exist.

Honestly? It's a mess. A constant, overwhelming mess. Some days I feel like I'm drowning.

The biggest thing is just… compartmentalizing. Trying to separate the "teenager" part of my life from the "pregnant person" part of my life. It's not always successful, but I try.

At school, I try to be a normal student. I go to class, I hang out with my friends (the ones who haven't completely abandoned me), I try to focus on my grades. I try to pretend that everything is okay, even when it's not.
