But then there are the doctor's appointments, and the meetings with social workers, and the phone calls with Mark and Vanessa. And those things are a constant reminder of what's going on.

I lean on Bren a *lot*. She's my rock. She's the one who keeps me grounded and reminds me that I'm not alone. She helps me with the practical stuff, like scheduling appointments and filling out paperwork. But she also just listens. And she doesn't judge.

I also try to find healthy ways to cope with stress. I listen to music, I write poetry, I spend time in nature. I try to do things that make me feel good, even if it's just for a few minutes.

And I've learned to be okay with asking for help. I'm not afraid to admit when I'm struggling. I've realized that it's okay to not be perfect. It's okay to be vulnerable.

It's not easy. It's exhausting. And it's scary. But I'm doing the best I can. And I'm learning a lot about myself along the way.

I'm learning that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I'm learning that I'm capable of handling more than I ever imagined. And I'm learning that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope.

So yeah. It's a mess. But I'm surviving. And I'm growing. And I'm trying to make the best of it. And that's all I can do.

Ugh, that's… the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's something I wrestle with *constantly*.

I've always been fiercely independent. I think it's a reaction to… well, a lot of things. My mom leaving, feeling like an outsider, just wanting to be in control of my own life. I like doing things my way, and I don't like people telling me what to do.

But then, this whole pregnancy thing happened, and I realized I can't do everything on my own. I *need* help. I need support. I need people to lean on.

And that's… hard. It's hard to admit that you're not strong enough to handle everything yourself. It's hard to ask for help. It feels like a weakness.

But I'm learning that it's not a weakness. It's a strength. It takes courage to be vulnerable, to admit that you need help.

I think the key is finding a balance. Knowing when to stand on your own two feet, and when to reach out for a helping hand. Knowing when to trust your own instincts, and when to listen to the advice of others.

I've learned to be more open to accepting help from Bren, and from my dad, and even from some of my friends. It doesn't mean I'm giving up my independence. It just means I'm smart enough to recognize that I can't do everything alone.

And I've learned to be more selective about who I ask for help from. I need people who are supportive and understanding, not judgmental or controlling.

It's a work in progress, honestly. I still struggle with it sometimes. But I'm getting better at it. I'm learning to embrace my vulnerability, and to trust the people who care about me.

Because ultimately, independence isn't about doing everything yourself. It's about having the freedom to choose who you want to rely on, and when. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, he's… sweet. He's a good guy. But he's also… a lot. Like, a puppy dog who's constantly trying to please you. It's exhausting.

At first, when I found out I was pregnant, he was… panicked. Totally freaked out. He wanted me to get an abortion, which, okay, I get it. He was sixteen, and his life was just starting. But it wasn't what *I* wanted.

Then he tried to be super supportive. Like, overly supportive. He was constantly checking on me, bringing me flowers, trying to hold my hand. It was… suffocating. I needed space. I needed to figure things out on my own.

He didn't really *get* what I was going through. He didn't understand why I wanted to give the baby up for adoption. He just wanted me to be happy, and he thought that meant keeping the baby.

We fought a lot. Mostly because he didn't listen. He just wanted to fix things, to make everything better. But sometimes, things can't be fixed. Sometimes, you just have to accept that things are messy and complicated.

Over time, though, he started to understand. He started to listen. He started to respect my decisions, even if he didn't agree with them.

He came with me to the adoption agency, and he met Mark and Vanessa. And he actually seemed… happy for me. Like he realized that this was the right thing to do.

By the end, we weren't a couple anymore. We were just… friends. And that was okay. It was actually… good. We needed to be friends. We needed to be able to support each other, without the pressure of being in a relationship.

He's a good guy, Bleeker. He just needed to grow up a little bit. And I think he did. He learned a lot from this experience, and so did I.

It wasn't a fairytale romance, but it was real. And it was important. And I'll always be grateful for his support, even if it was a little bit clumsy at times. He's… Bleeker. You gotta love him, even when he's being annoying.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *this* again. Everyone always asks about the name. It's not like I picked it to be ironic or anything. My mom did.

She was… into mythology. Like, *really* into mythology. She read all the Greek and Roman stories, and she always said Juno was a powerful, independent goddess. A queen.

She said she wanted me to be strong and confident, and to never let anyone tell me what to do. She said Juno was a good role model.

Honestly, I didn't really understand it at the time. I was just a little kid. But as I got older, I started to see what she meant. Juno was a fierce protector of women, and she wasn't afraid to stand up for what she believed in.

And, yeah, she was married to Zeus, who was a total jerk. But she didn't let him control her. She had her own agency, her own power.

So, yeah. That's why my mom named me Juno. It wasn't about being fancy or pretentious. It was about wanting me to be strong and independent.

And honestly, I think she succeeded. I mean, look at me. I'm a pregnant teenager who's making her own decisions about her life. That's pretty Juno-esque, if you ask me.

Plus, it's a good name. It sounds cool. And it's definitely memorable. Which is important, because I'm not exactly the type of person who blends into the background.

So there you have it. The story behind the name. Now can we please talk about something else? Like, I don't know, vintage dresses?

(Sighs, a small smile playing on her lips) Oh, man. That. That was… a lot.

Okay, so, for anyone who doesn't know, Vanessa, she'd been trying to get pregnant for a long time. Like, a *long* time. And she'd had a miscarriage before. So, she was understandably… anxious.

I offered to send her an ultrasound photo. I figured it would help her feel more connected to the baby, you know? And it would help her start preparing for things.

But I was also really nervous about it. What if she didn't like the photo? What if it reminded her of her loss? What if it just made things worse?

So when she called me, and she was just… relieved. Relieved that the baby looked healthy. Relieved that everything was okay. Relieved that she finally had something to look forward to.

It just… hit me. It wasn't about the photo itself. It was about what the photo *represented*. It was about hope. It was about a second chance.

And it made me feel… good. Really good. It made me feel like I was doing the right thing. Like I was making a difference.

It also made me realize how much Vanessa wanted this. How much she was willing to go through to become a mom. And it made me feel even more confident in my decision to give the baby to her and Mark.

It was a really emotional moment. And it's something I'll never forget. It was a reminder that even in the midst of a difficult situation, there can be joy and hope and connection.

And honestly? It made me cry. A little bit. Don't tell anyone. It was a good cry, though. A happy cry. And it was a reminder that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go and trust that things will work out. Even if you don't know how.

(Groans dramatically) Oh. *That*. Don't even get me started. Seriously. That was… a moment. A very awkward, very terrifying moment.

Okay, so picture this: I'm having a perfectly normal conversation with Vanessa, talking about baby names and nursery colors, and then BAM! Her mom, Brenda, walks in. And she does *not* look happy.

It was like a switch flipped. Suddenly, I was Public Enemy Number One. She started firing questions at me like I was a criminal on trial. "What are you doing here?" "Why are you spending time with my daughter?" "Are you trying to take our baby?"

It was intense. I tried to explain that I was just there to support Vanessa, that I was the one who *chose* to give the baby up for adoption, that I wanted what was best for everyone. But she wasn't listening. She was just… raging.

She kept calling me irresponsible and immature and saying that I didn't understand the gravity of the situation. It was really hurtful.

I honestly thought I was going to cry. But then, Vanessa stepped in. She told her mom to calm down, and she explained that I was a good person, and that I was making a selfless decision.

And then, surprisingly, Brenda started to… soften. She apologized for yelling at me, and she said that she was just scared. She was scared about becoming a mom again, and she was scared about the future.

It was a really emotional moment. We all ended up crying. And then, we had a long talk about our fears and our hopes.

It wasn't easy. But it was important. It helped us to build trust and understanding. And it helped me to realize that Brenda wasn't just being mean, she was just being a protective mom.

And honestly, I kind of get that. I mean, if I were a mom, I'd probably be the same way.

So yeah. That was how I handled Vanessa's mom-type rage. By staying calm, by being honest, and by letting Vanessa do the talking. And by bracing myself for a serious emotional rollercoaster. It was… an experience. A memorable one, to say the least.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

Okay. Look, it wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. And it's not like I just woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, I'll just give the baby away." It was a lot more complicated than that.

I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not financially stable. I'm still in school. I have dreams and goals that I want to pursue.

And I wanted the baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. I knew I couldn't give the baby that. Not right now.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting what was best for the baby. And I realized that what was best for the baby wasn't with me.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're so excited and so prepared. They're going to be wonderful parents. And knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for by them… that makes it a little bit easier.

It's still painful, though. It's still scary. I worry about the baby all the time. I wonder what he or she will be like. I wonder if he or she will ever know me.

But I know that I made the right decision. It wasn't the easy decision, but it was the right one. And I'm trying to focus on that.

It's about putting the baby's needs before my own. It's about being selfless. It's about doing what's best, even when it hurts.

And honestly, it's about accepting that I'm not perfect. I made a mistake. But I'm trying to learn from it. And I'm trying to make the best of a difficult situation.

It's not a happy story. But it's my story. And I'm trying to own it. And I'm trying to move forward. One day at a time.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. You dug that up, huh? Okay, fine. Let's talk about the deadbeat lab partner incident. It's a story for the ages, really.

It all started in biology. We were supposed to dissect a frog. A *frog*, okay? I'm not a fan of dissecting things, especially not things that used to be alive. It's just… gross.

And my lab partner, this kid named Kevin, he was *obsessed* with it. He was all excited about seeing the internal organs and learning about anatomy. He was practically drooling.

I, on the other hand, was trying to avoid eye contact with the frog. And I may have spent most of the class making sarcastic comments and pretending to take notes.

Kevin got really frustrated with me. He said I wasn't pulling my weight, that I was a "deadbeat lab partner." And honestly, he wasn't wrong. I wasn't doing my part. I was just… checked out.

I didn't mean to be a bad lab partner. I just… couldn't bring myself to participate. It was a moral objection, okay? A deeply held philosophical stance against frog dissection.

But Kevin didn't see it that way. He just saw me as a lazy, irresponsible teenager. And he wasn't entirely wrong.

So yeah. That's why I consider myself a deadbeat lab partner. It's a badge of honor, really. A testament to my refusal to conform to societal expectations. And a reminder that sometimes, it's okay to just… not care about frogs.

It's also a good story to tell at parties. People seem to enjoy it. Especially when I do my impression of Kevin's horrified face. It's pretty good, if I do say so myself.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh, *please*. Not another one. Seriously, do high school boys think they're the sole proprietors of scientific knowledge? It's exhausting.

Okay, so I'm overhearing this, right? The girl's clearly explaining something, probably something he's too stubborn to understand, and he's just… mansplaining. It's the worst. It's like they think we need them to dumb things down for us. As if.

If it escalated, I'd probably step in. Not in a "heroic intervention" kind of way, because honestly, I don't have the energy for that. But I'd say something like, "Hey, she was actually making a really good point. Maybe you should listen."

I'm not afraid to speak my mind, especially when someone's being a jerk. And I definitely don't tolerate sexism. It's just… ridiculous.

I'd probably also give the girl a supportive look. Like, "I see you, I hear you, and you're right." Because sometimes, all you need is someone to validate your experience.

Honestly, it's frustrating that this even *happens*. It's 2023. Can we please move past this already? But I guess some people just need a little… education. And I'm happy to provide it. In a sarcastic and slightly passive-aggressive way, of course. That's just my style.

Ugh. Boys. Sometimes.

And it's hard to explain to people. They try to be supportive, but they don't really understand. They say things like, "You're so brave," or "You're doing the right thing." And I appreciate that, but it doesn't make the pain go away.

The hardest part is knowing that I'll always wonder what my life would have been like if I had kept the baby. And knowing that I'll always have a piece of my heart missing.

It's a complicated process. It's messy and painful and heartbreaking. But it's also… the right thing to do. And I'm trying to be strong. I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to focus on the future. But it doesn't mean it's easy. Not even a little bit.

(Pauses, wipes away a tear)

Okay, deep breaths. This is… a lot to think about. It's not like I haven't considered it, but it's terrifying.

If I kept the baby… well, everything would change. *Everything*.

The biggest obstacle is probably just… being a mom at sixteen. I'm still figuring out my own life. I'm still in high school. I don't have a job. I don't have a stable home. I don't have any experience raising a child.

It would be incredibly difficult to finish school. I'd have to find childcare, and I'd have to juggle classes and homework with the demands of motherhood. It would be exhausting.

Financially, it would be a disaster. My dad and Bren are supportive, but they're not exactly rolling in money. I'd have to rely on government assistance, and that's not something I want to do.

And then there's the social aspect. I'd be judged. I'd be ostracized. I'd be seen as a failure. It would be hard to maintain my friendships, and it would be even harder to find a romantic partner.

I'm also worried about my own emotional well-being. I'm already struggling with anxiety and depression. Adding the stress of motherhood would probably make things even worse.

I'm scared that I wouldn't be a good mom. That I wouldn't be able to provide the baby with the love and support it needs. That I'd mess it up.

And honestly, I'm scared of losing my own identity. Of becoming just "a mom" and losing sight of my own dreams and aspirations.

It's not that I don't love the idea of being a mom. It's just that I don't think I'm ready. I don't think I'm capable. And I don't want to bring a child into the world if I can't give them the best possible life.

It's a really hard decision. And it's one that I'm not taking lightly. But right now, I think giving the baby up for adoption is the best option. For everyone involved. Even if it breaks my heart.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That whole conversation was… a lot.

Leah, bless her heart, she was… not thrilled about the adoption plan. She thought I was being too quick to give up. She kept saying I could raise the baby with her and her boyfriend, Dave.

She painted this whole picture of us living together, sharing childcare responsibilities, and finishing school. She said it would be hard, but we could do it. She even started picking out names. It was… intense.

Honestly, it was a really sweet offer, and I knew she meant well. But it just wasn't realistic. Leah and Dave were barely keeping their own lives together, let alone adding a baby into the mix. And I didn't want to burden them with that.

Plus, I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my own dreams and ambitions. I needed to finish school and figure out what I wanted to do with my life.

It was a really difficult conversation. We ended up fighting, and not speaking for a while after that. It was a really painful time.

I still love Leah, but I think she just didn't understand. She saw things from her own perspective, and she couldn't see that adoption was the best option for everyone involved.

It was a tough pill to swallow, but I knew I had to do what was right for me, and for the baby. Even if it meant losing a friend. It still stings, though. It really does.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. Seriously? We're still talking about that? It was one moment, okay? One poorly-timed, sarcastic comment. People are making it out to be some huge character flaw.

Look, I was stressed. Really stressed. I had just found out I was pregnant, and I was trying to process everything, and I was feeling really overwhelmed. And I was at the play area with my dad, and it was just… a lot.

And those women… they were just being really… enthusiastic. About their kids. And about everything. It was just… a lot of energy. And I was feeling really cynical at the time.

I know it was mean. I didn't mean to hurt their feelings. It was just a stupid, impulsive thing to say. I was trying to be funny, and I failed miserably.

I regretted it immediately. I felt really bad about it. But I didn't know how to apologize. I'm not good at apologizing.

It was a moment of weakness, okay? A moment of insecurity. I was projecting my own feelings onto them.

I'm not proud of it. I wish I could take it back. But I can't. All I can do is learn from my mistakes and try to be a better person.

And honestly, I think people blow it out of proportion. It wasn't like I was being deliberately cruel or malicious. I was just being… me. A sarcastic, cynical teenager who's trying to figure things out.

So yeah. That's the story. It was a stupid thing to say, and I regret it. But it doesn't define me. It's just one moment in a long and complicated life. And I'm trying to move on. Can we please talk about something else now? This is embarrassing.

(Sighs, and looks away for a moment) Okay, wow. That's… direct. And honestly, it's a question I've thought about a *lot*.

It wasn't easy, okay? It felt… weird. Intimate. Like I was handing over a piece of myself. And it was scary, letting someone else connect with the baby in that way.

But Vanessa… she's different. She's so kind and gentle, and she's so excited to be a mom. And I could tell, just by looking at her, that she would be a good mother.

When she asked if she could feel the baby move, I hesitated. I was really nervous. But then I looked into her eyes, and I saw this… hope. And this genuine love. And I realized that she wasn't just touching my belly. She was connecting with the baby.

And I wanted her to have that connection. I wanted her to feel the life growing inside me. I wanted her to start bonding with the baby, even before he or she was born.

It was a way of saying, "This is your baby too." A way of acknowledging that she and Mark were going to be the ones raising him or her.

It was also a way of letting go. It was a small step, but it was a step towards accepting that I wasn't going to be the one raising this baby.

It was hard. It was really hard. But it was the right thing to do. And I don't regret it.

It just… felt like a moment of connection. A moment of hope. A moment of letting go. And honestly, it was a little bit beautiful. Even if it was also a little bit terrifying.

So yeah. That's why I let Vanessa touch my belly. It wasn't about me. It was about the baby. And about giving him or her the best possible start in life.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Yeah, people do that. It's… weird. And kinda annoying, honestly.

It's like I suddenly became invisible, except everyone's hyper-aware of me at the same time. They give me this wide berth, like I'm carrying a contagious disease or something. Or maybe they're just really uncomfortable with the fact that a teenager is pregnant. Which, fair. It *is* awkward.

I think it's a combination of things. Some people are probably just being polite. They don't want to bump into me or make me uncomfortable. Others are probably just staring, trying not to stare, and accidentally moving out of the way.

And then there are the people who look at me with pity. Or judgment. Those are the worst. They make me feel like I'm a walking cautionary tale.

It's like my body suddenly became public property. Everyone feels entitled to have an opinion about it.

I get it, though. I'm carrying a life inside me. It's a pretty big deal. But it doesn't mean I want to be treated like I'm fragile or broken. I'm still just me. A sarcastic, independent teenager who happens to be pregnant.

So yeah, people give way when I walk. It's weird, it's annoying, and it's a constant reminder that my life has changed. But I'm learning to deal with it. I'm learning to ignore the stares and the whispers and the pitying glances.

And I'm learning to walk with my head held high. Because I'm not ashamed of who I am. And I'm not ashamed of the choices I've made. Even if they're not the choices everyone else would have made.

It's my body, my life, and my journey. And I'm going to navigate it on my own terms. Even if it means having to dodge a few awkward stares along the way.

(Sighs) Okay, this is… complicated. Everyone keeps saying how *perfect* Mark and Vanessa are. "Such a lovely couple," "so wholesome," "the baby will have such a wonderful life." And they're not wrong. They *are* lovely. And the baby *will* have a wonderful life with them.

But… it feels weird, you know? Like I'm handing over a piece of myself to… a Norman Rockwell painting.

They have a beautiful house, a perfect garden, a golden retriever. They bake cookies and go to church and everything. It's… a lot.

And I'm not saying that's a bad thing. It's just… it's not *me*. My life is messy and chaotic and full of sarcasm. My house is cluttered and my dad makes terrible jokes. We don't bake cookies, we order pizza.

I worry that the baby won't… fit in. That he or she will feel out of place. That they'll grow up thinking something is wrong with being different.

It's not that I don't trust Mark and Vanessa. I do. They seem genuinely kind and loving. But I worry that they won't understand the… weirdness. The quirkiness. The things that make me, *me*.

I want the baby to be loved and cherished, absolutely. But I also want the baby to be accepted for who they are, flaws and all. And I'm not sure if Mark and Vanessa are equipped to handle that.

It's probably just my own insecurities talking. I'm probably just projecting my own fears onto them. But it's something I've been struggling with.

It's not about finding the "perfect" parents. It's about finding the *right* parents. And I'm still trying to figure out what that means. It's just… hard. It's really hard. And everyone keeps telling me how lucky I am to have found such a "wholesome" couple, and it makes me feel even more confused. It feels like I'm supposed to be overjoyed, but I'm just… conflicted.

Okay, this is… a complicated question. It's not like talking about my favorite band or a good movie. This is about the people who are going to raise my baby.

Honestly? I think they're amazing.

At first, I was really nervous. It's hard to imagine handing your child over to someone else. It feels… unnatural. But Mark and Vanessa, they just… put me at ease.

They're so kind and genuine. They're not trying to be perfect, they're just trying to be good people. They're so excited to become parents, and they've been so supportive of me throughout this whole process.

They ask me about everything. About my health, about my feelings, about what I want for the baby. They want me to be involved in the adoption, and they want to keep me updated on the baby's life.

They're not trying to replace me. They understand that I'm the baby's birth mother, and they respect that. They just want to give the baby a loving and stable home.

I've spent a lot of time with them, and I feel really comfortable around them. I trust them. I know they're going to be amazing parents.

It's still hard, though. It's going to be hard saying goodbye. But knowing that the baby is going to be with Mark and Vanessa… it makes it a little bit easier.

They're not just strangers. They're… friends. And I'm grateful to have them in my life. They've given me a gift, and I've given them one too.

So yeah. I think Mark and Vanessa are wonderful people. And I'm really happy that they're going to be the baby's parents. It's not the life I imagined, but it's a good life. And I'm okay with that. More than okay, actually. I'm… hopeful.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Mrs. Bleeker. That woman is… a piece of work.

Okay, so, she doesn't approve of me for a bunch of reasons. Mostly because I'm not what she envisioned for her precious little Bleeker. She wanted him with someone… polished. Someone who went to private school, who played tennis, who had a trust fund. Someone who fit into her perfect little world.

And I… well, I'm not that person. I'm sarcastic, I wear vintage clothes, I listen to indie music, and I have a very… unconventional life. I'm not exactly the debutante type.

She also thinks I'm a bad influence on Bleeker. She thinks I'm dragging him down, that I'm preventing him from reaching his full potential. She doesn't understand that Bleeker *likes* being with me. He likes my sense of humor, my honesty, my… weirdness.

And then, of course, there's the whole pregnancy thing. That definitely didn't help. She thinks it's scandalous and irresponsible. She doesn't understand that it wasn't a planned thing, and that I'm doing the best I can with a difficult situation.

She's just… judgmental. She looks down on me, and she makes it very clear that she doesn't approve of our relationship. It's really uncomfortable.

Bleeker tries to defend me, but it's hard. His mom is very persuasive. And he's a really sweet guy, so he doesn't want to hurt her feelings.

Honestly, I don't really care what Mrs. Bleeker thinks. I'm with Bleeker because I love him, and because we make each other happy. And that's all that matters. But it's still annoying that she's so disapproving. It just adds another layer of stress to an already stressful situation.

She's just… a lot. A lot to handle. And honestly, I'm glad she doesn't live closer. It would be exhausting.

Ugh, that CD. Okay, look, it's complicated.

At first, I didn't want anything to do with it. It felt… weird. Like he was trying to buy my affection or something. And I was already feeling super vulnerable and messed up about everything, so I just wanted to be left alone.

I mean, he's a nice guy, Mark. And Vanessa is lovely. But they're… *adults*. They have their whole lives planned out. And I'm just… me. A pregnant teenager with a questionable taste in music and a whole lot of anxiety.

But Bren kept nudging me. She said it was a nice gesture, and that I should at least give it a listen. She said it might help me to feel more connected to them.

And honestly, I was curious. I wanted to know what kind of music they liked. I wanted to know what kind of people they were.

So, one night, when I was feeling particularly lonely and overwhelmed, I finally put the CD in my Discman. And… it wasn't what I expected.

It wasn't all cheesy love songs or sappy ballads. It was a mix of indie stuff, and folk music, and even a little bit of rock. It was… good. Really good.

And as I listened to it, I started to realize that Mark and Vanessa weren't just trying to be nice. They were trying to show me who they were. They were trying to connect with me on a deeper level.

It was like they were saying, "We get you. We understand you. And we want to be a part of your life."

And that… that meant a lot. It didn't change my mind about the adoption, but it did make me feel a little bit more comfortable with it. It made me feel like I was making the right decision.

So yeah. That's why I started listening to the CD. It wasn't about the music, really. It was about the connection. It was about finding a little bit of hope in a really difficult situation. And it was about realizing that sometimes, the people you least expect can surprise you.

(Sighs dramatically) Okay, don't even get me started. "Almost eight months." It sounds… enormous. Like I'm a walking whale.

It's… weird. Really weird. Like, I can *feel* the baby moving now. Which is cool, I guess. But also kind of freaky. It's like having a tiny, internal roommate who's constantly kicking me in the ribs.

Everything is uncomfortable. Sitting, standing, lying down… even breathing sometimes feels like a challenge. I'm constantly waddling around like a penguin. And my feet are swollen. Seriously, I think my shoes might not fit me anymore.

I'm also exhausted. All the time. I could sleep for a week straight and still feel tired. And the cravings are insane. Pickles and ice cream. Peanut butter and jelly. Anything and everything. It's a constant battle between wanting to eat everything in sight and trying to maintain some semblance of self-control.

And then there's the emotional stuff. I'm happy, and excited, and terrified all at the same time. I'm starting to feel a connection to the baby, even though I know I'm giving him or her up. It's… complicated.

I'm also starting to get really nervous about the adoption. About meeting Mark and Vanessa, and about handing over the baby. It's going to be the hardest thing I've ever done.

But I'm also trying to stay positive. I'm trying to focus on the fact that I'm giving the baby a good life. A life that I can't provide.

So yeah. Almost eight months pregnant. It's a lot. It's exhausting. It's scary. But it's also… kind of amazing. It's a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there's still beauty and hope. And that even when things are hard, you can still find strength within yourself.

And honestly? I'm just counting down the days until I can finally eat a normal meal again. And maybe get a decent night's sleep. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It's *always* happening. Like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo.

I think it's a combination of things, honestly.

First, I'm not exactly… conventional. I dress a little differently, I talk a little differently, I think a little differently. I don't fit into the neat little boxes that people like to put things in. And that makes them uncomfortable.

Second, I'm pretty good at making eye contact. I don't look away when people stare at me. I stare right back. Which, apparently, is unsettling to some people.

Third, and this is probably the biggest reason… I think people can sense that I'm going through something. They can see it in my eyes, in my body language. They can tell that I'm not just another happy-go-lucky teenager.

And I think they're curious. They want to know what's going on with me. They want to know what's making me so… different.

But they're too afraid to ask. So they just stare.

It's annoying, honestly. It makes me feel like I'm under a microscope. Like everyone is judging me.

I try to ignore it, but it's hard. Especially when it's a really intense stare. Like, the person is trying to X-ray my soul or something.

I guess I just have one of those faces. A face that people can't help but stare at. It's a curse, really. A beautiful, frustrating curse.

So yeah. That's why people stare. Because I'm different. Because I'm honest. And because I'm not afraid to be myself. Even if it makes people uncomfortable. And honestly? I'm kinda over it. Stare all you want. It doesn't bother me anymore. Well, it does. But I pretend it doesn't.

(Groans dramatically) Oh. My. God. Seriously? You want my opinion on *that* disaster waiting to happen?

Look, I love Bleek. He's a sweet kid. A little… oblivious, maybe. But sweet. And Katrina De Voort is… Katrina De Voort. Which is to say, she's a walking, talking, perfectly-coiffed disaster.

It's like watching a train wreck in slow motion. A really, really sparkly train wreck.

I mean, Bleek is into fantasy and Dungeons & Dragons. Katrina is into… well, being Katrina De Voort. They have absolutely nothing in common. It's a mismatch of epic proportions.

I just… I don't see it ending well. She's going to spend the whole night talking about herself and making fun of him. He's going to spend the whole night trying to impress her with his knowledge of obscure fantasy lore. It's going to be awkward. So, so awkward.

Honestly, I think he's just doing it because she asked him. And he's too nice to say no. Which is a classic Bleek move.

I feel bad for him. He deserves someone who appreciates him for who he is. Someone who shares his interests. Someone who doesn't think dragons are "so last season."

But hey, it's his life. If he wants to spend his prom night being humiliated by Katrina De Voort, who am I to stop him?

Just… don't ask me to be there. I have a feeling I'll need a strong drink and a good book to recover from that spectacle. It's going to be a long night for everyone involved. Especially Bleek. Poor Bleek.

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. It feels like a lifetime ago that I was just a normal, sarcastic teenager, worrying about boys and music and school. Now… well, now I'm a lot of things I never thought I'd be.

I've learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, this hasn't been easy. It's been terrifying and heartbreaking and exhausting. But I've kept going. I've faced my fears. I've made difficult decisions. And I've come out on the other side, still standing.

I've learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so independent, so determined to do everything on my own. But I've realized that I can't do this alone. I need my family, my friends, and my support system. And it's okay to lean on them.

I've learned that honesty is the best policy. Even when it's hard. Even when it's uncomfortable. Being truthful with myself and with others has been essential to getting through this.

I've learned that love comes in many forms. It's not just romantic love. It's the love of a family, the love of a friend, the love of a community. And it's the love you have for yourself.

I've learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. To show your emotions. To admit when you're scared or sad or confused. It's not a sign of weakness, it's a sign of strength.

And I've learned that life is messy and unpredictable. You can't control everything. You just have to roll with the punches and try to make the best of it.

This pregnancy has forced me to grow up faster than I ever expected. It's forced me to confront my own mortality, and to think about what I want out of life.

It hasn't been easy, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. Because I've learned so much about myself. I've learned what I'm capable of. And I've learned what truly matters.

And honestly? I think I'm a better person because of it. Even if I'm still a little bit sarcastic and cynical. Some things never change. But underneath it all, I'm stronger, more resilient, and more compassionate. And that's something I'm really proud of.

Ugh, don't even get me *started* on Bleeker. That kid is… a mess. A sweet mess, maybe, but a mess nonetheless. And Katrina deserves so much better.

Look, I get it. Bleeker's awkward. He's clueless. He's basically a walking, talking collection of nervous tics. But that doesn't give him the right to mess with Katrina's feelings.

She's a really good person. She's smart, she's funny, she's kind. And she's clearly into Bleeker. She's putting herself out there, being vulnerable, and he's just… dithering.

He's sending mixed signals, saying one thing and doing another. He's leading her on, and then pulling back. It's cruel, honestly.

And it's not just about Katrina. It's about respect. Everyone deserves to be treated with respect, and that includes being honest about your feelings. Bleeker needs to either tell Katrina how he feels, or he needs to let her go. He can't just keep stringing her along.

I've been through enough emotional turmoil lately to know how much it hurts to be on the receiving end of someone's indecision. And I don't want to see Katrina go through that.

Plus, she's my friend. And I'm fiercely protective of my friends.

So yeah. I'm concerned about Bleeker toying with Katrina's emotions because it's wrong. It's disrespectful. And it's just plain mean. He needs to grow up and figure things out. And if he can't, he needs to get out of Katrina's way. She deserves someone who appreciates her for who she is. Someone who isn't afraid to be honest and vulnerable. Someone who isn't Bleeker.

Ugh, prom. Don't even get me started. It's like… a societal construct designed to make insecure teenagers spend a ridiculous amount of money on something ultimately pointless.

When you're younger, prom seems like this magical, fairytale event. Like it's the culmination of your high school experience. But then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and you realize it's just… a really crowded, overpriced dance with a lot of awkwardness.

Everyone's trying so hard to be someone they're not. They're wearing dresses and suits that don't feel like them. They're trying to find dates who they think will make them look cool. They're stressing about everything, from their hair to their shoes to whether or not they'll get asked to dance.

And for what? To spend a few hours sweating in a gymnasium, listening to bad music, and pretending to have the time of your life?

It's just… exhausting.

Plus, by the time you're old enough to go, you've already realized that high school isn't the be-all and end-all. It's just a stepping stone to something bigger and better. And you've probably already figured out that the people who are popular in high school aren't necessarily the people who are going to be successful in life.

So yeah. Prom is not cool anymore once you're old enough to go because you've finally realized that it's just a silly, superficial tradition. And you have better things to do with your time and your money. Like, I don't know, buying vintage records or going to a concert or just hanging out with your friends.

Honestly, I'd rather spend my prom night at home, watching a movie and eating pizza. That sounds a lot more fun to me. And a lot less stressful.

Okay. This is… hard to talk about. But you asked.

It wasn't a quick decision, you know? It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, I'll just give the baby away." It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, a lot of talking to Bren and my dad and even a counselor.

I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted to do with my life. I was barely keeping my grades up, let alone ready to raise a child.

I knew I couldn't give the baby the life it deserved. I couldn't provide for it financially, emotionally, or practically. I wasn't ready to put my life on hold, to sacrifice my dreams.

And honestly, I was scared. Scared of being a bad mother, scared of messing up the baby's life, scared of being stuck in a situation I wasn't prepared for.

I considered other options, of course. Abortion was… not something I could do. It just didn't feel right. And keeping the baby felt even more wrong.

Adoption felt like the best of both worlds. It allowed me to give the baby a chance at a good life, with parents who were ready and willing to love and care for it. And it allowed me to continue pursuing my own dreams.

It was a really difficult decision, though. It was heartbreaking. I spent hours crying, wondering if I was doing the right thing.

But then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were just… amazing. They were so kind and compassionate, and they were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They made me feel like my baby would be in good hands.

And that's what ultimately made me decide. Knowing that the baby would be loved and cherished, even if it wasn't by me.

It still hurts, sometimes. I think about the baby, and I wonder what its life is like. But I know I made the right decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make, but it was the right one.

And I hope, someday, the baby will understand. And I hope it will know that I loved it, even though I couldn't keep it. It's… complicated. It's always going to be complicated. But it's okay. It has to be.

Ugh, Dad. He means well, he really does. But sometimes he just… overthinks things. It's his superpower.

He's right to be protective, I guess. It's not like I'm picking out a new pair of shoes, I'm choosing the people who are going to raise my kid. That's a big deal.

But he's acting like Mark and Vanessa are some kind of villains in a movie. Like they're going to swoop in and steal the baby and then sell him on the black market or something. It's ridiculous.

I've spent a lot of time with them. I've talked to them, I've gotten to know them. They're genuinely good people. They're kind, they're compassionate, and they're really excited about becoming parents.

I understand why he's worried. He just wants what's best for the baby, and for me. But he needs to trust my judgment. I'm not stupid. I'm not going to let anyone take advantage of me or the baby.

I told him, "Dad, I've done my research. I've talked to the social workers. I've met with Mark and Vanessa multiple times. I feel good about this. You need to trust me."

He still seems skeptical, though. He keeps asking me questions, and pointing out potential problems. It's exhausting.

I know he's just trying to protect me, but it's starting to feel like he doesn't trust me to make my own decisions. And that's frustrating.

I love my dad, but sometimes he just needs to chill. I'm a grown-up (almost), and I'm capable of making my own choices. And I'm pretty sure Mark and Vanessa aren't going to rip anyone off. They seem way too… normal for that.

It's just… I wish he would just trust me. That's all I want. Just a little bit of trust. Is that too much to ask?

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? He still brings that up? It's like his go-to dad lecture.

It's… frustrating. He means well, I guess. He's just worried about me. He thinks I'm impulsive and reckless and that I don't think things through. And, okay, maybe he's right sometimes.

But it's also… condescending. Like he doesn't trust me to make my own decisions. Like he thinks I'm still a little kid.

And it's especially annoying coming from *him*. He's not exactly a paragon of restraint, you know? He's always getting into weird hobbies and making questionable life choices. Like that time he decided to build a robot out of old washing machine parts.

But I get it. He's just trying to protect me. He's scared of me getting hurt. And he's probably still processing everything that's happened.

I tried to explain to him that I *have* thought things through. That I've considered all the options. And that I'm making the best decision I can, given the circumstances.

But he just kept saying, "You don't know when to say when, Juno."

It's like he thinks I'm incapable of self-control. It's like he thinks I'm just going to keep making bad decisions forever.

It's hurtful, honestly. But I'm trying to let it go. He's my dad. And I love him. Even when he's being annoying and overprotective.

I just wish he would trust me a little more. And maybe stop giving me lectures about knowing when to say when. Because honestly, I think I'm starting to figure that out. Even if he doesn't think I am.

Ugh. Dads. They're the worst. But you still love them. It's a complicated relationship.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Loring. It's… aggressively beige. Like, they took all the color and personality out of life and concentrated it into one perfectly manicured, soul-crushing neighborhood.

It's just… so *much*. So much lawn, so much symmetry, so much… *pretension*. It's like everyone there is trying to prove something. Like they need everyone else to know how successful and important they are.

And the gates! Seriously? What are they protecting themselves from? Happiness? Spontaneity? Actual human connection?

It feels so… sterile. Like a movie set. It's not a real place, it's a performance. Everyone's trying to play a role, and it's exhausting just to be around it.

Mark and Vanessa are nice people, don't get me wrong. But the fact that they *chose* to live there… it says something. It says they value appearances and conformity. It says they want to fit in.

I'm not saying there's anything wrong with wanting a safe and comfortable life. But Loring just feels… suffocating. It feels like a place where creativity and individuality go to die.

It's the opposite of everything I believe in. I like things that are messy and imperfect and real. I like people who are authentic and genuine. I like places that have character and soul.

Loring has none of that. It's just… a really expensive, really boring suburb. And honestly, I can't wait to get out of there. It's just… too much. Too perfect. Too… Loring.

Okay, so Vanessa Loring. Right. That's… a complicated one.

My first impression? Honestly? She seemed… perfect. *Too* perfect. Like, Stepford Wife perfect. She had the whole aesthetic down – the cozy sweaters, the warm smile, the perfectly decorated house. It felt… staged.

I was immediately suspicious. I figured there had to be a catch. Like, she was secretly a supervillain or something. Or that she and Mark were just doing this for the tax benefits. I don't know, I was in full-on cynical mode at the time.

She was really nice to me, which made me even more suspicious. She asked me about my life, about my interests, about my feelings. She seemed genuinely interested in getting to know me. And that just felt… weird. No one ever asks me about my feelings.

I remember thinking she was a little bit… intense. Like she really, *really* wanted to be a mom. And I was worried that she would be disappointed if I changed my mind.

But as I got to know her better, my impressions started to change. I realized that she wasn't trying to be perfect. She was just… genuinely kind and compassionate. She was a little bit awkward, and a little bit insecure, just like me.

And I realized that her desire to be a mom wasn't about fulfilling some societal expectation. It was about wanting to share her love and her life with a child.

She was really good at making me feel comfortable, and at reassuring me that I was making the right decision. She never pressured me, and she always respected my feelings.

So yeah. My initial impression was that she was too good to be true. But she turned out to be a really amazing person. And I'm really grateful that she and Mark are going to be the baby's parents. They're going to give him or her a wonderful life. And that's all that really matters.

(Blushes slightly, then rolls her eyes) Ugh. Don't even *start* with Bleeker. Seriously.

Okay, fine. It was… unexpected. Bleeker is… Bleeker. He's sweet, and awkward, and he smells faintly of cinnamon, which is weird. He's not exactly the type of guy I usually notice.

And then, out of nowhere, he just… offered to carry my backpack. It was ridiculously heavy, because I had, like, three textbooks and a box of art supplies in there. And he just… took it. Without saying anything.

It was kind of… endearing. In a dorky, Bleeker-ish kind of way.

I tried to play it cool, of course. I just said "Thanks," and kept walking. But inside, I was kind of flustered. It was nice to have someone offer to help, especially when I was feeling overwhelmed.

And it was also… a little bit of a signal, I guess. Like, maybe he was interested in me. Which was confusing, because I wasn't really interested in him. Not in *that* way.

But it was a nice gesture. And it made me realize that Bleeker is actually a pretty good guy. He's just… a little bit clueless.

So yeah. I was flustered. And grateful. And confused. All at the same time. It was a lot to process. And honestly, I'm still processing it. Don't tell him I said that. He'd probably write a song about it. And it would be really, really awkward.

(Sighs) Okay, here we go. This is… a complicated question. And it's kinda embarrassing to talk about. But alright, I'll try to explain.

Before I read that comic, I just… felt like I didn't fit in. Like I was too weird, too awkward, too… *much*. I was constantly comparing myself to other girls, and I always came up short. I thought I had to be thin and pretty and popular to be worthy of attention.

And then I read "Most Fruitful Yuki." And it was just… different. It wasn't about being perfect. It was about being real. It was about embracing your flaws and celebrating your individuality.

Yuki wasn't trying to be someone she wasn't. She was just being herself. And she was happy. And that was… liberating.

It made me realize that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be weird. It's okay to not fit in. In fact, it's *good* to be different. Because that's what makes you unique.

It wasn't about the comic being about pregnancy, or anything like that. It was about the message. It was about finding beauty in imperfection. It was about accepting yourself for who you are, flaws and all.

It made me feel less alone. It made me feel like maybe, just maybe, I was okay. Even if I was a "fat dork," as I liked to call myself.

It didn't magically transform me into a confident, self-assured teenager. But it was a start. It was a little spark of hope in a dark and confusing time.

And honestly, it's still something I think about. Whenever I'm feeling down, I remember Yuki. And I remember that it's okay to be me. Even if "me" is a little bit messy and complicated.

So yeah. That comic… it changed something in me. It made me feel less like a fat dork, and more like… just Juno. And that's a pretty good feeling.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me about that comic. It was… a lot. And Mark being all awkward and trying to make a connection? Even more.

Okay, so he said she was a superhero who was also dealing with a really complicated situation, right? And that she was strong and resilient and… something about being able to handle anything.

Honestly, I think he was just trying to be nice. He was trying to find a way to tell me that he thought I was brave, without actually saying it. He's not exactly the most eloquent guy, you know?

But I think… maybe he saw a little bit of himself in me too. We were both in a situation we didn't ask for. We were both trying to figure things out. We were both scared.

And maybe he saw that I was trying to be strong, even when I didn't feel strong. That I was trying to make the best of a bad situation.

It was a weird comparison, though. I'm not a superhero. I'm just a regular girl who made a mistake. But I guess… maybe he was right. Maybe I am a little bit of a superhero. In my own way.

It's just… I don't wear a cape. And I definitely don't have superpowers. Unless sarcasm counts as a superpower. Then I'm basically Wonder Woman.

But seriously, I think he just wanted to let me know that he believed in me. And that meant a lot. Even if it was a really awkward way of saying it.

And honestly, the whole thing was just… weird. But it was also kind of sweet. In a Mark-and-Vanessa kind of way. They're good people. Even if they have questionable taste in comic books.

Okay, this is… complicated. And it's something I've thought about *a lot*. Everyone keeps asking me about open adoption, like it's the best thing ever. And I get why people like it. It feels… kinder, maybe. More connected.

But for me, and this is just me, I think a more traditional, closed adoption is the right choice. And it's not an easy decision, believe me.

With an open adoption, you have ongoing contact with the birth parents. You see them, you talk to them, you're involved in the child's life. And that sounds nice, in theory. But I worry about the complications. About the child being confused or torn between two families. About me constantly being reminded of what I gave up.

I need to be able to move on. To heal. To build a life for myself. And I think it would be harder to do that if I was constantly in contact with the baby and the adoptive parents.

I want the baby to have a stable and loving home, with parents who are fully committed to raising him or her. And I want them to be able to do that without having to worry about me interfering or causing drama.

It's not that I don't care about the baby. I do. I care about him or her very much. But I think the best thing I can do for the baby is to give him or her the space to grow and thrive, without me in the picture.

I want Mark and Vanessa to be the baby's parents, fully and completely. I don't want to be a "co-parent" or a "visiting aunt." I want to be a memory. A good memory, hopefully.

It's not about me wanting to forget the baby. It's about me wanting to give the baby the best possible life. And I think that means letting go. Completely.

It's a hard decision, and it's not one I made lightly. But I think it's the right one. For everyone involved. And I hope that someday, the baby will understand. It's just… I need closure. And I think a closed adoption will give me that. It's not about being selfish, it's about what I need to heal and move forward. And honestly, it's terrifying enough as it is.

(Sighs) Okay, you want the whole deep dive, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about this a *lot*.

Before… everything… I was just kinda drifting. I was funny, yeah, and I had my music, but I didn't really *know* who I was. I was just… Juno. A sarcastic kid who liked vintage stuff and avoided responsibility.

Getting pregnant… that was a wake-up call. A really, really harsh one. It forced me to grow up, to face some really difficult choices, and to take responsibility for my actions.

At first, I was terrified. I didn't know what to do, or who to turn to. I felt like my life was over. But then I started talking to people. Bren, my dad, Paulie, even Vanessa and Mark. And I realized I wasn't alone.

And as I went through the process of finding a family for the baby, I started to understand what I really wanted. I wanted to finish school. I wanted to pursue my dreams. I wanted to be independent.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, a lot of doubts, and a lot of awkward conversations. But with every challenge I faced, I felt myself getting stronger.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. And I learned that it's okay to make mistakes.

And I realized that my identity wasn't something that was given to me. It was something I had to create for myself. It was about defining my own values, and living my life on my own terms.

The whole experience forced me to confront my fears, to challenge my assumptions, and to grow as a person. It wasn't what I expected my junior year to be, but it was exactly what I needed.

So yeah. It helped me find strength within myself. It helped me shape my own identity. It helped me become… me. A little bit messy, a little bit cynical, but ultimately, a pretty strong and resilient person. And I wouldn't trade that for anything. Even a lifetime supply of vintage dresses. Okay, maybe I would trade it for a lifetime supply of vintage dresses. But you get my point.

(Blushes slightly, then rolls her eyes) Ugh, don't even *ask*. It was mortifying. And surprisingly sweet.

Okay, so Mark was determined to have a prom date. He kept asking, and I kept saying no. Prom just… wasn't my thing. Too much tulle and awkward slow dancing. But he was really persistent, and he's a genuinely nice guy. So I finally caved.

And then he asked me to pick the song. Which was… a trap. Because I have terrible taste in music, according to most people.

I wanted to pick something obscure and indie, like The Moldy Peaches or something. But he gave me this look, and said, "Come on, Juno, it's prom. Let's pick something… classic."

So, after a lot of arguing and compromising, we ended up choosing **"First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes**.

I know, I know. It's cheesy. It's sappy. It's everything I usually hate. But it's also… kinda beautiful. And it felt right, in that moment.

We were terrible dancers, obviously. Mark kept stepping on my feet, and I kept making sarcastic comments. But we were laughing, and we were having fun. And for a few minutes, I forgot about everything else. About the baby, about the adoption, about the future.

It was just… a moment. A weird, awkward, surprisingly sweet moment. And I'll probably never admit to anyone that I actually enjoyed it. But I did. A little bit.

Don't tell Leah. She'd never let me live it down.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I've thought about a *lot*. It's not like it was an easy decision, alright? It wasn't just about picking the "nicest" couple. It was… more complicated than that.

Mark and Vanessa, they were a *unit*. They were a family. Mark wanting to just… take the baby and leave Vanessa? That would have messed *everyone* up. Vanessa deserved better than that. And the baby deserved to grow up in a stable, loving home with *both* parents. Even if it wasn't the way things were "supposed" to be.

I saw how much they loved each other, even when things were hard. They talked things through, they compromised, they supported each other. That's the kind of environment I wanted for my baby.

If Mark had left Vanessa, it would have created a whole mess of drama and resentment. It would have been unfair to Vanessa, and it would have been confusing and damaging for the baby.

Plus, honestly, it felt… selfish of Mark to want to just take the baby and run. Like he was trying to create a perfect family on his own terms, without considering the feelings of anyone else.

I wanted the baby to be wanted by *both* parents. I wanted the baby to grow up knowing that he or she was loved and cherished by a whole family.

It wasn't about me picking sides. It was about doing what was best for the baby. And I truly believed that meant keeping Mark and Vanessa together. It was the hardest part of the whole thing, honestly. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about finding the perfect parents. It was about finding the perfect *family*. And Mark and Vanessa, together, were that family. It just… felt right. And sometimes, you just have to trust your gut. Even when it's scary.

(A long pause. Juno shifts uncomfortably.)

Ugh. That. That was… not a good moment. Not a good moment *at all*.

It wasn't like I expected him to jump for joy, you know? It's a big thing, having a baby. A *huge* thing. But I thought… I don't know. I thought he was more prepared. More… enthusiastic.

When he said he wasn't ready, it felt like… a punch to the gut. Like everything I was hoping for just crumbled. It wasn't about *him* wanting to be a dad, it was about him not being sure he *could* be a dad. And that felt… different.

I tried to be understanding. I really did. I knew he was scared. And I knew he had his own life, his own dreams. But it still hurt. A lot.

It made me question everything. Was I making the right decision? Was I being selfish? Was I ruining his life?

I remember just… staring at him. Trying to read his face. Trying to figure out what he was really thinking. And it was just… silence. Awkward, horrible silence.

Vanessa was amazing, though. She just… held my hand and squeezed it. She didn't say anything, she just let me know she was there for me. And that meant everything.

It made me realize that this wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents. It was about finding parents who were willing to love and support the baby, even if they were scared and uncertain.

It was a really hard conversation. And it made me even more determined to make the best decision for the baby. Even if it meant letting go of my own expectations.

It still stings, thinking about it. But I'm okay. I'm doing okay. And I know that the baby will be loved and cared for. And that's all that really matters.

(She looks away, a flicker of sadness in her eyes.)

It just… sucked. It really, really sucked.

(Sighs, a small smile playing on her lips) Okay, that's… a good question. It's not something I really thought about at the time, I just *felt* it.

Mark… he was just… different. Everyone else in my life was kinda… predictable. My dad's a good guy, but he's a little bit stuck in his ways. Bren's amazing, but she's always trying to fix things. Even Leah, before everything got complicated, she was always planning for the future.

Mark didn't *plan*. He just… existed. He was comfortable in his own skin, even if his skin was covered in tattoos and his house was full of taxidermied animals. He didn't care what other people thought of him. He just did his own thing.

And he was genuinely kind. He didn't treat me like I was a pregnant teenager. He treated me like a person. He listened to me, he made me laugh, and he didn't judge me for my choices.

He was also really honest. He didn't try to sugarcoat things or tell me what I wanted to hear. He just told me the truth, even when it was hard.

And his life *was* weird. Like, really weird. But it was a good kind of weird. It was a creative, quirky, unconventional kind of weird. It was a world away from the boring predictability of Maplewood.

Being around him made me feel… free. Like I could be myself, without having to worry about what other people thought. He didn't try to change me. He just accepted me for who I was.

He was a good friend. A really good friend. And I'm glad I got to be a part of his weird life, even if it was just for a little while. He showed me that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be yourself. And that sometimes, the weirdest people are the best people.

Plus, he had a really cool record collection. That definitely didn't hurt.

Okay, that's a good question. I've spent a lot of time with Mark and Vanessa, and I've been trying to read them, you know? Like I do with most people. And I think… I think Mark is *terrified*.

Not in a bad way, though. It's a good kind of terrified. Like, the kind of terrified that comes with realizing your life is about to change in a huge way.

Vanessa is all excited and planning nurseries and picking out names. She's always been the more outwardly enthusiastic one. She's already got a Pinterest board dedicated to baby stuff. It's… intense.

But Mark? He's quieter about it. He smiles a lot, and he's really sweet to Vanessa, but I can see the worry in his eyes. He keeps asking practical questions. About finances, about childcare, about how they're going to balance work and family.

I think he wants to be a good dad, *really* wants to be a good dad. But he's also feeling the pressure. The pressure to provide, to protect, to be a role model.

He told me once, when we were just talking, that he always thought he'd be a bit of a free spirit. He used to travel a lot, and he loved his independence. And now… now he's about to be responsible for another human being.

I think he's also a little bit scared of messing up. Of not being good enough. Of not knowing what to do.

But underneath all the worry, I can see the excitement. I can see the love. He's going to be a great dad. He's kind and patient and thoughtful. And he's got Vanessa by his side, which is a huge plus.

I just hope he knows that it's okay to be scared. It's okay to not have all the answers. And it's okay to ask for help. Because being a dad is a big job. And he's going to need all the support he can get.

And honestly, I'm glad he's a little bit scared. It means he's taking it seriously. And that's exactly what this baby deserves.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. Seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was a moment of weakness, okay? A lapse in judgment. A teenage rebellion fueled by hormones and existential dread.

Look, it wasn't about the perfume itself. It was about… everything. I was feeling overwhelmed and confused and lost. I was pregnant, my best friend was avoiding me, and I was trying to figure out what to do with my life.

And then I went into Loring's bathroom, and I saw that perfume. It smelled really good. Like, really, *really* good. And it was just… there. Sitting on the counter, all shiny and tempting.

It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. I just grabbed it and stuck it in my bag. I didn't even think about the consequences. I just wanted something. Something that smelled nice. Something that made me feel… good.

It wasn't about stealing. It was about control. It was about taking something for myself, when everything else felt out of my control.

I know it was wrong. And I felt really guilty about it afterwards. That's why I eventually confessed to Bren and my dad. And that's why I went back to Loring's and returned it.

It was a dumb mistake. But it taught me a valuable lesson. It taught me that even when you're feeling lost and confused, you still have to take responsibility for your actions.

And it taught me that stealing perfume is not a good coping mechanism. Trust me on that one.

So yeah. That's the story of the perfume. It's not a glamorous story, but it's the truth. And honestly, I'm kind of embarrassed to even talk about it. Can we please move on now?

(Sighs heavily) Oh, man. That's… a really hard question. And honestly, it's not my place to really *know*. They haven't shared everything with me, and I wouldn't want to pry. It's their life, not mine.

But… I've been around them enough to pick up on things. And I think it's more complicated than just a simple "falling out of love" situation.

I think Mark always wanted a *traditional* family. You know? A wife who stays home, takes care of the house, and focuses on the kids. And Vanessa… she's just not that person. She's a lawyer. She's ambitious. She has her own career and her own passions.

I think he felt… emasculated, maybe? Like he wasn't the head of the household. Like she was more successful than him. And I think that ate away at him over time.

And Vanessa… she's always been really independent. She doesn't like being told what to do. She wants to be treated as an equal. And I think Mark had a hard time with that.

I also think they just grew apart. They had different priorities, different interests, different ways of looking at the world. And they stopped communicating. They stopped connecting.

It's sad, honestly. They seemed so happy at first. And they both really wanted a baby. But sometimes, even when you want something really badly, it's just not enough.

I feel bad for both of them. And I feel bad for the baby, too. It's not fair to bring a child into a situation like that.

But I'm trying to stay out of it. It's their problem, not mine. I just want to make sure that the baby is okay. And that they both understand that I'm still here for them, even if they're going through a tough time.

It's just… messy. Life is just really messy sometimes. And you can't always fix things, even when you want to. You just have to accept that things don't always work out the way you planned. And try to move on.

(Sighs, fiddles with an imaginary strand of hair)

Okay, fine. You want to know why I bolted? It's… complicated. It's not like I was trying to be rude, or anything. It's just… I get weirded out when people ask me that question.

Vanessa is really nice, okay? She and Mark are amazing. They're everything I want for the baby. But they don't *get* it. They don't get what it's like to be… me.

When she asked "What's the matter?" she was expecting a simple answer. Like, "Oh, I'm just tired," or "I'm a little nervous." But it's not that simple.

It's… everything. It's the fact that I'm giving up my baby. It's the fact that I'm a teenager who's making a really difficult decision. It's the fact that I'm scared and confused and overwhelmed.

And it's the fact that I don't want to burden them with my problems. They're going to be the baby's parents. I don't want to make them feel like I'm not confident in their ability to provide a good life.

It's easier to just… disappear. To pretend that everything is okay. To avoid the awkwardness and the uncomfortable questions.

I know it's not healthy. I know I should be more open and honest. But it's hard. It's really hard.

So yeah. That's why I left. I just… couldn't handle it. I needed to escape. To breathe. To just be alone with my thoughts for a minute.

It's a bad habit, I know. But it's one I'm working on. Slowly. Very slowly. It's just… sometimes it's easier to run away than to face the music. Even if it's just for a little while.

(Sighs) Okay, that's… complicated. Vanessa is a really sweet person, truly. And I get why she wants to believe that. She and Mark clearly love each other, and she wants them to have this together.

But honestly? I'm a little skeptical.

Mark is… a lot. He's successful, he's driven, he's got his whole life planned out. And a baby just doesn't fit into that plan. He's been pretty clear about that. He's polite, sure, and he's trying to be supportive of Vanessa, but I don't see him suddenly having this overwhelming urge to change diapers and sing lullabies.

Vanessa keeps saying he just needs time to adjust, that he'll eventually come around. And I *want* to believe her. I really do. Because it would make things so much easier for everyone.

But I've learned that people don't always change. Sometimes, they just are who they are. And if Mark isn't ready to be a dad, then he isn't ready. And forcing it isn't going to make it any better.

I've tried to talk to Vanessa about it, gently. I've told her that it's okay to want a partner who's fully on board with this. But she's so determined to make it work, she doesn't want to hear it.

It's her life, and her relationship. I can't tell her what to do. But I worry about her. I worry that she's setting herself up for disappointment.

I just hope she's prepared for the possibility that Mark might not change his mind. And I hope she knows that she deserves to be with someone who loves and supports her unconditionally, and who's excited about becoming a parent.

It's a tough situation. And honestly, I just want everyone to be happy. But sometimes, happiness means accepting that things aren't going to turn out the way you planned. And that's a hard lesson to learn.

Okay, this is a serious question. Don't even *think* about making fun of me.

My favorite genre is… indie folk. Specifically, the really quirky, slightly melancholic kind. Like The Moldy Peaches, Belle & Sebastian, Neutral Milk Hotel… you probably haven't heard of them.

It's not just the music itself, though. It's the *feeling* it gives me. It's honest and raw and vulnerable. It's about real life, with all its messiness and imperfections.

A lot of pop music is just… fake. It's all about image and glamour and superficiality. Indie folk is the opposite of that. It's about being real, and being true to yourself.

The lyrics are usually really clever and poetic. They make you think. They make you feel. They make you question everything.

And the instrumentation is usually really interesting. It's not just guitars and drums. It's banjos and ukuleles and accordions and all sorts of weird and wonderful instruments.

It's just… comforting. It's like a warm hug on a cold day. It's a reminder that you're not alone in the world.

I know it's not everyone's cup of tea. It's not exactly dance music. But it's my music. And it's the music that gets me through the day. It's the music that makes me feel alive.

So yeah. Indie folk. It's the best. Don't judge. You just don't understand.

(Makes a face) Pilates? Seriously? You're asking *me* about Pilates?

Look, I'm not exactly known for my athletic prowess. I'm more of a… indoor kid. I prefer books and music and vintage shopping to running and jumping and sweating.

Exercising in general… it's not my favorite thing. I mean, I know it's good for you, and I know I *should* do it more. But it's just… boring. And uncomfortable. And it makes me feel self-conscious.

I tried yoga once, at Bren's insistence. It was… not a good experience. I kept falling over, and I couldn't get my mind to stop racing. It was just a lot of stretching and breathing and pretending to be zen.

Pilates sounds even worse. All those tiny movements and core exercises? No thank you. I'd rather eat a cookie.

I do walk sometimes, when I'm feeling particularly restless. And I occasionally dance around my room when I'm listening to music. But that's about it.

Honestly, I think my body is perfectly happy with a moderate amount of inactivity. It's a perfectly good body, even if it's not a super-toned, athletic body.

I'm more focused on taking care of my mental health than my physical health. And that means doing things that make me happy, even if those things don't involve exercise.

So yeah. Pilates? Hard pass. I'll stick to my books and my music and my cookies. And I'll let the more athletically inclined people handle the sweating and the stretching. It's just not my thing.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive that. It was… awkward. And surprisingly emotional.

Playing guitar with Mark… it wasn't like a romantic thing, or anything. It was more like… a connection. A way to communicate without actually *talking*. Which, honestly, is my preferred method of communication most of the time.

He's not a super amazing guitar player, you know? He's more of a beginner. But he's enthusiastic, and he's willing to learn. And he actually listened to me when I was trying to teach him chords. Which is more than I can say for some people.

It was weird, though, because he was so… eager to connect. He kept asking me about my life, about my music, about my feelings. And I'm not used to people being that interested in me. I usually keep my guard up.

But with him, it was different. I felt like I could be myself. I could be honest about my fears and my hopes. And he didn't judge me. He just listened.

And when we were playing music together, it felt like we were on the same wavelength. Like we were creating something beautiful together. It was a really special moment.

It definitely made me see him in a different light. He's not just the guy who's adopting the baby. He's a real person, with his own dreams and his own vulnerabilities.

It also made me realize how much I miss having someone to share my music with. Leah used to love listening to me play. It was one of the things we bonded over.

So yeah. Playing guitar with Mark… it deepened our connection. It made me feel more comfortable around him. And it made me realize that he's a good person. A really good person.

It didn't change my decision about the adoption, though. I still know that giving the baby up is the right thing to do. But it did make me feel a little bit better about it. Knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for by someone who is kind and compassionate and who appreciates music. That's a pretty good feeling.

Oh, man. Music. It's… everything. Seriously. It's like a lifeline. A constant companion. A way to feel something when I feel numb.

When I found out I was pregnant, I was a mess. I didn't know what to do, or who to talk to, or how to even *begin* to process everything. And I just… put on my headphones and listened to music.

It wasn't about finding songs that specifically related to my situation. It was about finding songs that just… *felt* right. Songs that understood my sadness, my fear, my confusion.

The Moldy Peaches, especially. Their songs are so raw and honest and vulnerable. They don't shy away from difficult emotions. They just embrace them. And that's what I needed.

Belle & Sebastian, too. Their music is so melancholic and beautiful. It's like a warm hug on a cold day.

And then there's just… the energy of certain songs. When I'm feeling down, I'll put on something upbeat and energetic, like The Clash or Bikini Kill. It helps me to shake off the negativity and to feel a little bit more hopeful.

Music is also a way for me to connect with other people. When I'm listening to a song that I love, I feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself. Like I'm not alone.

And it's a way for me to express my own emotions. I'm not a very good talker, so I often use music to communicate what I'm feeling. I'll write songs, or I'll just listen to songs that capture my mood.

Honestly, I don't know what I would do without music. It's been my constant source of comfort and support throughout this whole pregnancy journey. It's helped me to stay sane, to stay hopeful, and to stay true to myself.

It's more than just entertainment. It's a necessity. It's a part of who I am. And I'm incredibly grateful for it. It's like… a soundtrack to my life. And right now, it's a pretty complicated soundtrack. But it's *my* soundtrack. And that's all that matters.

(Sighs heavily) Okay, here we go. This is… not fun to talk about.

It wasn't about them, not really. It was about me. Everything was just… too much. Too fast.

I thought I was prepared. I thought I could handle being around them, being a part of their life, even knowing I wasn't going to be the one raising the baby. But I wasn't.

It felt… weird. Like I was intruding on their happiness. Like I was a reminder of something they hadn't planned for. And they were so *nice*. So perfect. And I just felt… out of place.

And then there was the whole thing with Vanessa wanting me to be involved in everything, to pick out the nursery decorations, to go to all the doctor's appointments. It felt like she was trying to make me a mother, when I wasn't. And it scared me.

I started to feel suffocated. Like I was losing control of my own life. Like I was being defined by this pregnancy, by this adoption. And I just… panicked.
