I eventually went back and apologized to Vanessa and Mark. It was really hard, but I knew I had to. And they were surprisingly understanding. They said they just wanted me to be happy.

It was a mess. A really big mess. But I learned a lot from it. I learned that it's okay to ask for help, and it's okay to set boundaries. And I learned that sometimes, you just need to run away for a little while to find yourself.

It still makes me cringe to think about it, though. It was a really low point. But I'm trying to move on. And I'm trying to be a better person. And I'm trying to learn from my mistakes.

So yeah. I wrote "I'm pregnant" on a Jiffy Lube receipt. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. But it worked. And sometimes, that's all that matters.

(Sighs, looks down at her hands)

Okay. That. That was… rough. Still is, honestly.

It was… a relief. A huge relief. But it was also really sad. Because it meant that I was really doing this. That I was really giving up my baby.

I just stood there, watching her cry, and feeling a mix of emotions. Sadness, relief, gratitude, and a whole lot of fear.

It was one of the hardest moments of my life. And I'll never forget it. It was a reminder that even in the midst of loss, there can be beauty. And that even in the midst of pain, there can be hope.

And it was a reminder that Vanessa and Mark are really good people. And that my baby is going to be loved and cared for. And that's all I can ask for.

(Looks up, a small, sad smile on her face)

It was… a lot. Just a lot.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Ugh. That… that was a hard one. Really hard.

It was a relief, but it was also heartbreaking. It was the moment I knew that I was really going through with it. And it was the moment I knew that I was going to miss the baby more than anything in the world.

It was… a lot. It still is, honestly. Just thinking about it makes my throat tighten. But I know I made the right decision. And I know that Vanessa and Mark are going to be amazing parents. And that's all that matters.

(Looks down at her hands, then back up with a small, shaky smile)

It was… complicated. Everything about this is complicated.

(Eyes narrow, jaw tightens) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That Vijay. Seriously. The audacity.

It was… infuriating. Beyond infuriating. It was like, here I am, already dealing with the biggest, most complicated thing in my life, and this guy just waltzes in and throws a grenade into the situation.

(Rolls eyes so hard I almost pull a muscle) Oh. *Vijay*. Don't even get me started on Vijay.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh. *That* note. Seriously? You're bringing that up *now*? It's still mortifying.

So, yeah. That was the note. A recipe for peanut butter and pickle sandwiches. It's a long story, and it's a little bit embarrassing, but that's the truth.

And honestly, it's a pretty good representation of who I am. A little bit weird, a little bit unconventional, and always willing to try something new. Even if it's a peanut butter and pickle sandwich.

Oh, *that*. Right. Okay, so, that whole thing with Mark and Vanessa… it wasn’t about them not being nice people. They were lovely. Seriously. It was about… well, it was about them being *perfect*.

See, Mark and Vanessa, they had this… idyllic life. Perfect house, perfect jobs, perfect relationship. Everything was always calm and happy and predictable. And that scared me.

And I was worried that if things got hard, if they hit a rough patch, they wouldn’t be able to handle it. That they’d fall apart. That they’d realize they weren’t as perfect as they thought they were.

I was worried that they’d regret their decision to adopt, and that they’d give the baby back. Or that they’d resent the baby, or resent me.

I know it sounds cynical, but I’ve seen a lot of relationships fall apart. My parents, for example. And I didn’t want the baby to go through that.

I wanted the baby to have a stable and loving home, with parents who were committed to each other, no matter what. And I wasn’t sure if Mark and Vanessa were up to that challenge.

It wasn’t that I didn’t trust them. It was that I didn’t trust *perfection*. Because perfection doesn’t exist. And when you try to live up to an impossible standard, you’re just setting yourself up for disappointment.

So yeah. That was my biggest concern. Not that they weren’t good people, but that they were too good to be true. And that their perfect life wouldn’t be able to withstand the inevitable storms of reality. It was a dumb worry, probably. But it was a real one.

(A small, almost shy smile appears)

Okay, that's… a good question. A really good question. It's easy to focus on the stuff that's missing, you know? The people who don't understand. But there are people who do. People who always have.

So yeah. I have a lot of love in my life. More than I sometimes realize. And I'm grateful for that. Really grateful. It's what keeps me going, even when things are tough. It's what reminds me that I'm not alone. And it's what makes me believe that everything is going to be okay. Eventually.

So yeah. After the ultrasound, we finalize the adoption. I spend time with Mark and Vanessa. And then… I say goodbye. It's not a happy ending, but it's the ending that's right. And I'm trying to be okay with that. It's a work in progress.

Ugh. This again. It's… exhausting. Honestly.

It's the worst part, you know? Not the pregnancy, not the appointments, not even the morning sickness. It's the judgment. The whispers. The stares. The unsolicited advice.

People think they have the right to an opinion on my life. Like they know what's best for me. Like they can understand what I'm going through.

And it's not just strangers. Sometimes it's people I thought were my friends. People who should be supporting me, but instead are just… judging me.

I know I made the right decision. It wasn't easy, but it was the best thing for everyone involved. And I don't need anyone else's approval.

I also try to remind myself that people are often judgmental because they're afraid. They're afraid of things they don't understand. They're afraid of making their own difficult choices.

So I try to have compassion for them. Even when they're being cruel.

But it still sucks. It still stings. And it's something I'm going to have to deal with for a long time, I think.

But I'm strong. I'm resilient. And I'm not going to let anyone else's judgment define me. I know who I am, and I know what I believe in. And that's all that matters.

And honestly? If they don't like it, they can just… deal with it. I have more important things to worry about. Like finding the perfect vintage dress.

Okay, this is… hard to talk about. It's not that I don't *trust* Mark and Vanessa. They seem genuinely wonderful. It's just… it's my baby. You know? And letting go is terrifying.

One thing that worries me is… will they understand him or her? Will they get my sense of humor? Will they appreciate his or her quirks? I know that sounds silly, but it's important to me. I want my baby to be loved for who he or she is, not for who someone else wants him or her to be.

I also worry about whether they'll be open and honest about the adoption. I want my baby to know his or her story, to know where he or she came from. I don't want it to be a secret.

And I worry about whether they'll be able to handle the tough stuff. Raising a kid is hard. There will be challenges and setbacks. I want to make sure they're prepared for that.

I've talked to them about all of these things, of course. They've been really receptive and understanding. They've promised to be open and honest with the baby, and to support him or her through thick and thin.

But it's still hard to let go of those worries. It's hard to trust that someone else will love my baby as much as I do.

I know it's the right decision, though. I know that Mark and Vanessa will give my baby a good life. But that doesn't make it any easier.

I just want what's best for him or her. And I hope, with all my heart, that I'm making the right choice. It's just… a lot to process. And it's scary. Really scary. I just hope they remember to play The Moldy Peaches. That's all I ask.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on the ultrasound technician. Seriously. Like, I'm already dealing with a million emotions, and she thinks it's okay to give me the side-eye and make passive-aggressive comments about "the miracle of life"? It's infuriating.

With other people, it's a little more complicated. My dad's friends, for example. They keep asking me if I'm "sure" about this, and if I've "considered all my options." Like I haven't been thinking about this for months!

I usually try to explain my reasoning, calmly and rationally. I tell them that I'm doing what's best for the baby, and for myself. But sometimes, they just don't get it. They have their own preconceived notions about what's right and wrong, and they're not willing to listen.

When that happens, I just walk away. I don't have the energy to argue with people who are determined to judge me.

Bren has been really good about helping me with this. She tells me that I don't owe anyone an explanation. That my decision is my own, and that I don't need to justify it to anyone.

It's hard, though. It's hard to be constantly questioned and judged. It makes me feel like I'm doing something wrong, even though I know I'm not.

But I'm learning to trust my own instincts. And I'm learning to surround myself with people who support me, and who respect my decisions. And I'm learning to ignore the haters. Because honestly, they're not worth my time.

It's my life, and my decision. And I'm going to do what's right for me, even if it means disappointing some people along the way. And that's something I have to remember. Every. Single. Day.

Okay. Wow. That's… a hard question. It's not like anything I've ever felt before.

It was… a lot. It was the most emotional moment of my life, I think. And it changed me. It made me realize that this wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little person, and about giving him or her the best possible life.

It's still hard to talk about. But it's something I'll never forget. That blurry black and white image. That flickering heartbeat. And the overwhelming mix of emotions that washed over me. It was… everything.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It's been, like, forever.

Ugh. Bleeker. Don't even get me started. That whole thing was… a mess. A beautifully awkward, emotionally stunted mess.

I still think about him sometimes. I wonder what he's doing, and if he ever thinks about me. But I've accepted that we're not meant to be together.

And honestly, I'm okay with that. I've learned a lot from the experience. I've learned that it's okay to be vulnerable, even if it's scary. And I've learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is to let go.

So yeah. That's how our relationship changed. It went from potential romance to awkward friendship to… nothing. It wasn't the ending I wanted, but it was the ending I needed. And I'm moving on. Slowly, but surely. And with a lot of sarcasm. Because that's what I do.

(Sighs) Oh, Bleeker. That guy. Okay, look, that whole thing was… complicated. And probably a really dumb idea in retrospect.

The chalk message… it was a way of saying something I couldn't say out loud. I was scared, okay? Terrified. I was pregnant, and I didn't know what to do. And Bleeker… he was just *there*. He was kind of a blank slate. A safe space.

I knew he was into me, and I knew I wasn't into him in *that* way. But he was a good listener, and he didn't judge me. So I went to his stoop, and I wrote that message – "Please don't bother me" – because I needed him to back off. I needed space.

But it wasn't just about him. It was about everything. It was about my life falling apart, and about feeling completely lost and alone. It was about trying to regain some control in a situation where I had none.

It was a really passive-aggressive thing to do, I know. I'm not proud of it. But it was the only way I could think of to communicate what I was feeling at the time.

And honestly, it worked. He got the message. He left me alone. And that's all I wanted.

It was a stupid, childish thing to do. But it was also a desperate act of self-preservation. And sometimes, when you're feeling overwhelmed, you just do stupid things. You just try to survive.

So yeah. That's the significance of the chalk message. It was a cry for help, disguised as a rejection. And it was a reminder that even the smallest actions can have a big impact. Especially when you're a messed-up teenager trying to navigate a really complicated life.

Ugh, Bleeker. Don't even get me started. He's… a lot. A sweet lot, but a *lot*.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I get a lot. And honestly, it's kinda personal. But alright, I'll explain.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And I still have moments where I question myself, where I wonder if I'm doing the right thing.

It's not about what *I* want. It's about what's best for the baby. And that's what matters most.

It's… complicated. It's painful. But it's also the right thing to do. And I'm trying to find peace with that. It's a process. And I'm still working on it. But I know, deep down, that I'm making the best decision I can. For the baby. And for myself.

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. It feels like a lifetime ago, and also like yesterday, all at the same time.

I learned… a lot. More than I ever thought possible.

I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself pretty independent and resilient, but this was a whole different level. Dealing with the pregnancy, the adoption, the judgment… it was exhausting. But I kept going. I found a way to survive.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, my dad, even Leah, even when things were complicated.

I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. I spent so much time trying to figure everything out, trying to control the situation. But I realized that life is messy and unpredictable, and you just have to roll with the punches.

I learned that compassion is really important. Not just for others, but for yourself. I was so hard on myself for a long time. But I realized that I deserved kindness and understanding, just like everyone else.

I learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about the people who love and support you, no matter what. Bren showed me that. Mark and Vanessa showed me that.

And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. Even when things feel hopeless, there's always a reason to keep going.

Honestly, this whole experience changed me. It forced me to grow up, to confront my fears, to figure out what really matters to me.

I'm not the same person I was before I got pregnant. I'm more mature, more compassionate, more resilient. And I'm grateful for that. Even though it was a really difficult journey.

It taught me a lot about myself. And it taught me a lot about life. And I think, in the long run, that's a good thing. Even if it doesn't always feel like it.

Okay, that's… a good question. It's not like it was an instant connection, you know? It started off really formal. Lots of meetings with social workers, lots of awkward small talk. They were… nice. Very nice. But they were also strangers. And I was giving them my baby. That's a lot to process.

At first, I was mostly just trying to figure out if they were good people. If they were going to love and care for the baby the way he or she deserved. I grilled them with questions. About their jobs, their home, their values. I wanted to know everything.

And they were really patient with me. They answered all my questions honestly, and they never got offended by my skepticism. They understood that I was scared and uncertain.

As we spent more time together, though, things started to change. We started talking about things other than the baby. About our lives, our interests, our dreams. I learned that Mark was a really talented woodworker, and Vanessa was a kindergarten teacher. They were just… normal people.

I started to see them not as potential parents, but as people I actually liked. They were kind and compassionate and funny. They made me feel comfortable and safe.

And they started to see me as more than just a pregnant teenager. They saw me as a person with feelings and hopes and fears. They listened to me, they supported me, and they never judged me.

By the end of the process, we weren't just going through an adoption. We were building a relationship. A really special relationship.

It wasn't like they were replacing the baby's real parents, or anything. It was more like we were all becoming a family. A different kind of family, but a family nonetheless.

I still get emotional thinking about it. It's hard to give up a baby, even when you know it's the right thing to do. But knowing that he or she is going to be loved and cared for by Vanessa and Mark… that makes it a little bit easier.

They're good people. Really good people. And I'm grateful to them for everything. They've changed my life in ways I never could have imagined. And I hope I've changed theirs, too.

Regrets… yeah. I have a few. It's not like it was all sunshine and rainbows, you know? Even though I knew adoption was the right thing to do, it didn't make it easy.

I regret letting the judgment of others get to me. It was hard to ignore the whispers and the stares. It made me feel ashamed and isolated.

And I regret not being able to raise the baby myself. It's a bittersweet feeling, knowing that I gave him or her a chance at a good life, but also knowing that I won't be a part of their everyday life.

But… I don't regret the decision to choose adoption. I still believe it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

I've learned a lot from this experience. I've learned about strength, and resilience, and the importance of making difficult choices. I've learned about love, and loss, and the complexities of life.

And I've learned that it's okay to have regrets. It's part of being human. It's part of growing up.

I try not to dwell on the past. I try to focus on the future. And I try to learn from my mistakes.

So yeah. I have regrets. But I'm also grateful for the lessons I've learned. And I'm hopeful for what the future holds. Even if it's not the future I expected. It's *my* future. And that's all that matters.

Okay. That's… a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, even with Bren. It still feels… raw.

Okay. This is… important. If someone is listening, and they're going through something similar… I want them to know they're not alone. It feels like it, I know. It *really* feels like it. But you're not.

First, **don't be afraid to talk to someone.** Anyone. Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Just… someone you trust. Keeping it bottled up inside will only make things worse.

Second, **know that you have options.** You don't have to do anything you don't want to do. You have the right to choose what's best for you and for the baby. And there are people who will support you, no matter what you decide.

Third, **be kind to yourself.** This is a really difficult situation. You're going to have good days and bad days. You're going to feel a lot of different emotions. And that's okay. Don't beat yourself up over it.

Fourth, **don't let anyone tell you what to do.** This is *your* life, and *your* decision. Listen to advice, but ultimately, you have to do what feels right for you.

Fifth, **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of handling this. You are resilient. You are worthy of love and happiness.

And sixth, **don't give up on your dreams.** Just because you're pregnant doesn't mean you have to put your life on hold. You can still go to school, you can still pursue your passions, you can still have a future.

It's not going to be easy. It's going to be hard work. But you can do it. I believe in you.

And if you need someone to talk to, or just someone to listen, please reach out. There are people who care. And you deserve to be supported.

You're not alone. And you're going to get through this. I promise. It might not feel like it right now, but you will. Just keep breathing. And keep believing in yourself.

Ugh, blogging. It sounds so… performative. But Bren thought it was a good idea. She said it would be “therapeutic” and a way to “connect with others.” Which basically translated to “stop moping and do something productive.”

I started getting messages from other pregnant teenagers, from people who had gone through similar experiences. They told me I wasn’t alone. They offered me support and encouragement. They made me feel less ashamed.

And I realized that maybe, just maybe, my story could help someone else. Maybe it could make someone else feel less alone. Maybe it could challenge some of the stereotypes about teenage pregnancy.

So I kept writing. I wrote about the good days and the bad days. I wrote about my fears and my hopes. I wrote about the challenges of making a difficult decision.

I tried to be honest and authentic. I didn’t sugarcoat anything. I didn’t pretend everything was perfect. I just wrote about my experience, as it was happening.

It wasn’t always easy. There were trolls and haters and people who just didn’t understand. But the positive feedback outweighed the negative.

And it helped me to process my own emotions. Writing things down made them feel less overwhelming. It helped me to make sense of everything that was happening.

So yeah. That’s why I started blogging. It started as a way to shut Bren up, but it turned into something more. It turned into a way to connect with others, to share my story, and to make a difference. Even if it’s just a small one. It’s still… something. And honestly, it’s been a lot better than just sitting around feeling sorry for myself.

So yeah. Strength. That's the biggest lesson I learned. And it's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's not a lesson I *wanted* to learn, but it's a lesson I needed to learn. And I'm grateful for it, in a weird, complicated way.

Okay. This is… the big one. The reason I've been doing all this talking in the first place, I guess.

Wow. Okay. That's… a big question. It's not something I've spent a lot of time thinking about, honestly. It's hard to picture a future with a kid I won't be raising. But… I've thought about it.

I want them to find something they're passionate about, something that makes them excited to get out of bed in the morning. And I want them to have the freedom to pursue that passion, without anyone telling them they can't.

I want them to be **kind and compassionate**. To treat others with respect, and to stand up for what they believe in.

I want them to be **independent and resilient**. To be able to handle challenges and setbacks, and to learn from their mistakes.

I want them to be **true to themselves**. To not be afraid to be different, to embrace their individuality, and to live their life on their own terms.

I want them to have a strong support system, people who love and care about them unconditionally. Mark and Vanessa seem like they'll provide that.

And I want them to know that they're loved. Even though I won't be their mom in the traditional sense, I want them to know that I'm always thinking about them, and that I want the best for them.

It's not about controlling their future. It's about giving them the tools they need to create their own. It's about empowering them to be the best version of themselves.

It's a lot to ask for, I know. But that's my hope. That's my ideal vision. And I'm going to do everything I can to help make it a reality. Even if it's just from a distance. Because every kid deserves a chance to be happy. And I want my kid to have that chance. More than anything.

Ugh, okay. This is important. People have *so* many misconceptions about teen moms. It's infuriating.

The biggest one, the one that really gets under my skin, is that we're all irresponsible and unintelligent and just… ruined our lives. Like we didn't think things through, or that we don't care about the future.

Yes, it was a mistake. Yes, it was unplanned. But it doesn't mean I'm stupid or careless. It doesn't mean I don't have dreams or ambitions. It doesn't mean I don't love this baby.

We're just… young. We're still figuring things out. We're still growing up. And we're dealing with a lot of pressure and judgment.

It's easy to look at us and see a failure. But it takes a lot of courage to make a difficult decision, like choosing adoption. It takes a lot of strength to face the consequences of your actions.

We're not all the same. We all have different stories, different circumstances, different goals. And we all deserve to be treated with respect and compassion.

We're not defined by our mistakes. We're defined by how we respond to them. And we're capable of amazing things, even when the odds are stacked against us.

So, yeah. That's the biggest misconception. We're not irresponsible. We're just… young women who made a mistake. And we're trying to do the best we can. And we deserve a little bit of understanding. Is that too much to ask?

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

It wasn't a decision I made lightly, okay? It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, yeah, I'll just give my baby away." It was a lot more complicated than that.

Honestly, the biggest thing was… I wasn't ready. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I was still in high school, still trying to figure out what I wanted to do with my life. I didn't have a stable job, or a stable home, or a stable anything.

I knew I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved. I couldn't provide for it financially, or emotionally, or practically. It wouldn't be fair to the baby.

I know some people think that's selfish. But I don't think it is. I think it's responsible. I think it's better to admit that you're not ready, and to make a plan that's best for everyone involved.

And honestly, meeting Mark and Vanessa… that made the decision a lot easier. They were just… amazing. They were so kind and loving and excited about becoming parents. I knew that my baby would be in good hands with them.

It wasn't about finding "perfect" parents. It was about finding parents who could give my baby a life that I couldn't.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know it was the right decision. For me, and for the baby. And I hope, someday, the baby will understand.

It wasn't about giving up on my baby. It was about giving my baby a chance. A chance at a good life. And that's something I'll always be grateful for.

Okay, this is… the big one. The one I've thought about a million times. It wasn't easy, and it wasn't something I took lightly. It wasn't like picking out a pair of shoes.

The agency showed me a lot of profiles. Lots of couples, all wanting a baby. It was… overwhelming. They all seemed nice, but none of them felt *right*.

I didn't want someone rich and fancy. I didn't want someone who was trying to fill a void in their life. I wanted someone who genuinely wanted a child, and who would love and care for him or her unconditionally.

And then I met Vanessa and Mark.

They weren't flashy or glamorous. They were just… normal. They had a cozy little house, a dog named Buster, and a really warm and welcoming vibe. They weren't trying to be perfect, they were just being themselves.

They asked me a lot of questions, not just about the pregnancy, but about me. About my interests, my dreams, my fears. They wanted to know who I was as a person.

And they didn't judge me. They didn't try to tell me what to do. They just listened. And they were so kind and understanding.

It wasn't a logical decision, it was a gut feeling. It was like my heart was telling me, "These are the people who will love and care for your baby."

It was still scary, though. Giving up my baby is the hardest thing I've ever done. But knowing that he or she is going to a loving and supportive home makes it a little bit easier.

Vanessa and Mark aren't just adopting my baby, they're becoming a family. And I'm grateful to them for that. They're good people, and I trust them with my whole heart. And that's all that really matters.

Oh. Music. Don't even get me started. It wasn't just *a* role, it *was* my life. Like, seriously. It was the soundtrack to everything.

When I was little, my dad played a lot of classic rock – The Beatles, The Who, stuff like that. It was okay, but it wasn't really *my* thing. I needed something… more.

Then I discovered indie music. The Moldy Peaches, Belle & Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie… it was like someone finally understood how I felt. All the awkwardness, the angst, the confusion… it was all in the lyrics.

I spent hours listening to music in my room, just escaping into another world. It was a way to cope with everything that was going on in my life. It was a way to feel less alone.

I also started playing guitar. I'm not amazing, but it was a good outlet for my creativity. I'd write my own songs, mostly about heartbreak and frustration and the general absurdity of life.

Music was also a way to connect with other people. I went to a lot of concerts with Leah, and we'd spend hours talking about our favorite bands. It was a way to bond and to feel like we belonged somewhere.

And then, when things got… complicated… music was there for me. It was a source of comfort and strength. It helped me to process my emotions and to make sense of everything that was happening.

It's not an exaggeration to say that music saved my life. It gave me a voice when I didn't have one. It gave me hope when I felt hopeless. It gave me a reason to keep going.

So yeah. Music played a huge role in my life during my teenage years. It still does, actually. It's more than just a hobby. It's a part of who I am. It's a part of my soul. And I can't imagine my life without it.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. The stigma. It was *everywhere*. It felt like everyone in Maplewood was whispering about me. Pointing. Judging. It was awful.

I also started to realize that I didn't need their approval. I didn't need to justify my choices to anyone. I was making the best decision I could, given the circumstances. And that was all that mattered.

It helped to focus on the positive. On the fact that I was giving the baby a chance at a good life. On the fact that I was learning and growing as a person.

And honestly, a little bit of sarcasm helped too. I used it as a defense mechanism. If someone was being judgmental, I'd just fire back with a witty remark. It was a way of taking control of the situation.

It wasn't easy. There were still days when I felt ashamed and embarrassed. But I learned to ignore the haters. And I learned to focus on the people who loved and supported me.

And I realized that being a teenage mom didn't define me. It was just one part of my story. And it was a story I was determined to write on my own terms.

It still stings sometimes, though. The whispers. The stares. But I'm getting better at ignoring them. And I'm learning to be proud of who I am, even with all my flaws and imperfections. Because honestly, who isn't flawed?

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about, even now.)

It was… complicated. A lot more complicated than I thought it would be. Everyone kept telling me it was the right decision, and logically, I knew it was. But knowing something and *feeling* something are two very different things.

The day I gave birth… it was surreal. It didn't feel real. And holding him… he was so tiny, and perfect, and… mine. For a little while, at least.

But then Mark and Vanessa started sending me updates. Pictures, videos, little stories about how he was doing. And I started to feel… a little bit better.

Seeing him happy and healthy, knowing that he was loved and cared for… it made me feel like I'd done the right thing. It didn't erase the pain, but it made it a little bit easier to bear.

I still think about him all the time. I wonder what he's doing, what he's learning, what he's growing into. I hope he knows that I love him, even though I couldn't raise him myself.

It wasn't a fairytale ending. It was messy and sad and heartbreaking. But it was also… beautiful. It was a testament to the power of love and sacrifice.

And it taught me a lot about myself. About my strength, my resilience, and my capacity for compassion.

It's still something I'm processing, even now. But I'm learning to accept it. To embrace it as a part of my story. And to be grateful for the opportunity to have given him a good life.

It wasn't what I expected, but it was… right. And that's all that matters. It really is.

Ugh. Okay, you want the *real* story? Because it wasn't exactly a glamorous glow-up, let me tell you.

Physically? It was… rough. The morning sickness was the worst. It wasn't just in the morning, either. It was all day, every day. I basically lived on ginger ale and saltine crackers for months. And everything smelled weird. Like, *everything*.

I was exhausted all the time. I could sleep for twelve hours and still feel tired. And my body was changing in ways I wasn't prepared for. It was… unsettling.

Emotionally? That was even harder. I was scared, confused, and overwhelmed. I felt like my life was spinning out of control. I was angry at myself, and at the situation, and at the world.

I cried a lot. Like, a *lot*. And I had a lot of mood swings. One minute I'd be happy, the next minute I'd be completely devastated.

Bren was a lifesaver. She just… listened. She didn't judge me, she didn't try to fix things, she just let me vent. And she made me soup. A lot of soup.

I also started seeing a therapist. It helped to talk to someone who wasn't involved in the situation. Someone who could offer me a neutral perspective.

And I leaned on my friends. Leah, before… things got complicated. She was always there for me, even when I was being a mess.

I also found comfort in music. Listening to my favorite songs helped me to calm down and to feel less alone.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever gone through. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process.

I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that it's okay to ask for help. And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope.

It wasn't pretty, and it wasn't easy, but I survived. And that's all that matters. And honestly, I'm still processing it all. It's not something you just "get over." It's something you learn to live with. And I'm trying to do that, one day at a time.

Okay. That's… a direct question. And it's not one I usually talk about. It's complicated. Really complicated.

I didn't… I didn't *have* an abortion. I considered it. Seriously considered it. And that's where a lot of my views come from.

It wasn't about being pro or anti. It wasn't about politics. It was about… me. About what I could handle. About what was right for *my* life. And honestly, it was terrifying. The thought of it. The judgment. Everything.

I talked to a lot of people. Bren, mostly. And a counselor. And I realized that abortion wasn't the right choice *for me*. But that doesn't mean it's not the right choice for other people.

I think everyone deserves the right to make their own decisions about their own bodies. No one should be forced to have a baby they don't want. No one should be shamed or judged for their choices.

And it's not just about abortion. It's about access to contraception, to sex education, to prenatal care. It's about empowering women to take control of their own reproductive health.

Going through this whole experience – the pregnancy, the adoption – it made me realize how vulnerable women are. How much pressure they're under. And how important it is to have options.

I used to think reproductive rights were just… a political issue. Something people argued about on TV. But now I see it's a personal issue. It's about real people, with real lives, making difficult decisions.

And I think it's our responsibility to support them. To give them the resources they need. And to respect their choices, even if we don't agree with them.

It's not a simple issue. There are a lot of different perspectives. But I believe that everyone deserves the right to choose. And that's something I'll always stand for.

(She looks down at her hands, then back up, a flicker of vulnerability in her eyes.)

It's… a lot to process. And I'm still processing it. But it's definitely shaped who I am. And it's definitely made me a stronger advocate for reproductive rights.

And I talked about my fears. I talked to Bren, I talked to Leah (when we were talking again), I even talked to a counselor. Just getting my feelings out in the open helped me to process them.

I also reminded myself that this wasn't the end of my life. It was just a detour. I still had dreams and goals. I still wanted to go to college and travel and write music. And I could still pursue those things, even with everything that was happening.

Honestly, it was a lot of trial and error. There were days when I felt completely overwhelmed. But I kept going. I kept breathing. I kept putting one foot in front of the other.

And I learned that fear is just a feeling. It's not a fact. And you can choose how to respond to it. You can let it control you, or you can control it.

So yeah. Support, acceptance, control, communication, and a whole lot of stubbornness. That's how I overcame my fears. Or, at least, learned to live with them. It's still a work in progress, but I'm getting there. And I'm stronger for it. I think. Maybe.

Okay, you're circling back to *that*. It's still… a lot to unpack, even after all this time. But I'll try to explain it again.

It wasn't a quick decision, you know? It wasn't like I just woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, adoption sounds good." It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of talking to people.

The biggest thing was… I just wasn't ready. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not financially stable, I'm still in school, and I don't have a stable support system beyond my dad and Bren.

I wanted to give the baby the best possible life, and I knew I couldn't do that on my own. I wanted the baby to have parents who were ready and able to provide for them, emotionally and financially.

And honestly, I knew I wouldn't be a good mom right now. I wouldn't be able to give the baby the attention and care it deserves. I'd be too stressed and overwhelmed.

Adoption felt like the most selfless thing I could do. It was about putting the baby's needs first, even though it was incredibly difficult for me.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa helped a lot. They were just… so kind and genuine. They were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents, and they made me feel like they would love the baby unconditionally.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about *choosing* a family for the baby. It was about giving the baby a chance at a good life.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, and I still have moments where I question it. But I know, deep down, that it was the right one. For everyone involved.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered most. It still does. And it's something I'm trying to find peace with. It's… complicated. But it's the truth.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is… complicated. Like, really complicated. It's the stuff that keeps me up at night.

Let's start with Leah. That's the harder one. We were inseparable. Like, sisters. We shared everything. Secrets, dreams, embarrassing moments… everything. And then… I got pregnant. And everything changed.

It wasn't that she was mad about the pregnancy itself, exactly. It was more like… she didn't know how to deal with it. She didn't know how to deal with *me*. She started avoiding me, making excuses. And when we did talk, it was awkward and strained.

I think she was scared. Scared of what this meant for our friendship. Scared of what people would think. Scared of… me changing. And I get that. But it still hurt. A lot.

I tried to reach out, to explain things, but it didn't seem to matter. She just wasn't there for me anymore. And that's… devastating. I miss her. I miss our inside jokes, our late-night talks, our shared love of music. But I also know that sometimes, friendships just drift apart. And maybe that's what happened here. It sucks, but it's life.

Now, Paulie… that's a different kind of complicated. He's… Paulie. Sweet, clueless, a little bit immature. He was excited about the baby at first, but then he got scared. He wanted me to get an abortion, and when I refused, he kind of checked out.

He's not a bad guy, he's just… not ready to be a dad. And honestly, I don't think he ever will be. He's still figuring out his own life, and he doesn't want the responsibility of raising a child.

I'm not angry at him. I'm just… disappointed. I wish he would have been more supportive, more involved. But I understand. He's not the right person to raise this baby. And that's okay.

So, yeah. My relationship with Leah is broken, or at least severely strained. And my relationship with Paulie is… nonexistent. It's not ideal, but it's the reality. And I'm learning to accept it. And to move on. And to focus on the people who *are* there for me. Like Bren. And Mark and Vanessa. They're the ones who matter now. And that's enough. For now.

(A long pause. Juno shifts uncomfortably.)

Okay. That's… a loaded question. And it's not like I *decided* to become a teenage mother. It just… happened.

It wasn't a plan. It wasn't something I wanted. It was a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake.

Paulie Bleeker and I… we were just kids. We weren't thinking about the consequences. We were just… being kids. And we weren't careful.

I know that sounds stupid. And irresponsible. And it is. But it's the truth.

I didn't *choose* this. It chose me.

And once I found out I was pregnant, I had to make a decision. And it wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make.

I considered all my options. Abortion, raising the baby myself, adoption. And after a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking to Bren, I decided that adoption was the best choice.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about not being able to give the baby the life it deserved. I was sixteen. I was still figuring out who I was. I wasn't ready to be a mother.

So, I didn't *decide* to become a teenage mother. I *became* a teenage mother. And then I had to figure out what to do with it.

It's not a story I'm proud of. It's not a story I like to tell. But it's my story. And I'm learning to accept it. And to move forward.

And honestly? It's made me a stronger person. It's taught me a lot about myself. And it's made me appreciate the things I have.

So yeah. That's the story. It's not a happy story. But it's the truth. And that's all I can offer.

(A long pause. Juno shifts, looking down at her hands.)

That's… a really hard question. And honestly? It's one I still ask myself sometimes. Not like, every day, but… it comes up.

There were definitely moments, especially in the beginning, where I wondered if I'd made the right choice. When I was really sick, or when I was feeling overwhelmed, or when I was just scared about the future. It was easy to think, "What if?"

But regret… it's a strong word. And I don't think I truly *regret* it.

Because even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done, it also taught me so much about myself. About strength, and resilience, and compassion. It forced me to grow up, and to take responsibility for my actions.

And it led me to Mark and Vanessa. They are amazing people, and I know they're going to give the baby a wonderful life. Seeing them with the baby… it makes me feel good. It makes me feel like I did the right thing.

It's not easy knowing that I won't be the one raising him or her. There's a part of me that will always wonder what life would have been like if I'd kept the baby. But I also know that I wasn't ready. I wasn't prepared. And I wouldn't have been able to give the baby the life he or she deserves.

So, no. I don't regret my decision. It was a difficult one, and it was painful. But it was the right one. For everyone involved.

And honestly? I think I'm a better person because of it. I'm stronger, and more compassionate, and more grateful for the things I have. And that's something I wouldn't trade for anything.

(She looks up, a small, sad smile playing on her lips.)

It's just… complicated. Life is complicated. And sometimes, the best you can do is make the best decision you can, and hope for the best. And that's what I did. And I'm okay with that. I think. Mostly.

Ugh, don't even *ask*. It was… a feat. A monumental, sleep-deprived, emotionally exhausting feat.

Honestly, I almost didn't. There were days when I just wanted to give up. When I couldn't drag myself out of bed, when I couldn't focus in class, when I just felt completely overwhelmed.

But Bren wouldn't let me. She was relentless. She made sure I went to school, even when I didn't want to. She helped me with my homework, she drove me to appointments, she just… kept me going.

My teachers were surprisingly supportive, too. They gave me extra time on assignments, and they let me take breaks when I needed them. Mr. Believ, my English teacher, was especially good. He understood that I was going through a lot, and he didn't judge me.

I also had a few friends who stuck by me. Leah, before… things got complicated. And a couple of other kids who just wanted to help.

It was a lot of late nights, a lot of caffeine, and a lot of tears. I had to learn to prioritize, to manage my time, and to ask for help when I needed it.

And I had to learn to be okay with not being perfect. I didn't get straight A's. I missed a few classes. But I did my best. And that's all anyone could ask for.

The hardest part was dealing with the stares and the whispers. People were curious, and judgmental, and sometimes just plain mean. But I learned to ignore them. I learned to focus on my own goals, and to not let anyone else bring me down.

It wasn't easy. But I did it. I graduated. And it was one of the proudest moments of my life. It proved to me that I could overcome anything. And it gave me the confidence to pursue my dreams.

So yeah. It was a struggle. But I made it. And I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. It made me stronger, more resilient, and more grateful for the people who supported me. And it taught me that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope.

Okay, this is… the big one, isn’t it? Everyone always wants to know this. It’s not a simple answer, and it’s definitely not something I take lightly.

It wasn’t about what other people thought, or what was “right” or “wrong.” It was about what *I* felt. And honestly, the thought of… terminating the pregnancy… it just felt… wrong. Deep down.

I know a lot of people choose abortion, and I respect their decision. It’s their body, their choice. But for me, it just didn’t sit right. It felt like… ending something that had the potential to be something beautiful.

I know that sounds cheesy, but it’s true. Even though I wasn’t ready to be a mom, I couldn’t shake the feeling that this little person deserved a chance at life.

And then I started thinking about adoption. And it felt… like a good compromise. Like a way to give the baby a loving home, with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. And it allowed me to finish school and pursue my own dreams.

It wasn’t an easy decision. It was probably the hardest decision I’ve ever had to make. I cried a lot. I talked to Bren for hours. I weighed the pros and cons.

But ultimately, I knew that adoption was the right choice for me. It was the choice that felt the most… peaceful. The choice that allowed me to feel like I was doing something good, even though it was incredibly difficult.

It wasn’t about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby a life. And that’s something I can live with. It’s still hard, and it will be for a long time. But I know I made the right decision. For everyone involved.

And honestly, meeting Mark and Vanessa… seeing how excited they were… that sealed the deal. I knew they would love and cherish this baby, and that’s all I ever wanted. It’s not the life I expected, but it’s my life. And I’m trying to make the best of it.

Okay, this isn't even a question. Of *course* a child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements. Seriously?

Love is love, and family is family. It doesn't matter if you have a mom and a dad, or two moms, or two dads, or a single parent. What matters is that the child is loved and supported and cared for.

I'm giving my baby up for adoption, and I'm choosing Mark and Vanessa, a loving couple, to be his or her parents. They're not the "traditional" family, but they're going to be amazing parents. They're kind, and patient, and they're so excited to start a family.

And honestly, I think a child is better off with parents who love and cherish them, even if they don't fit the mold, than with parents who are just going through the motions.

It's not about the gender of the parents, or the number of parents, or the way the family is structured. It's about the quality of the relationships. It's about the love and support that the child receives.

Anyone who says otherwise is just… stuck in the past. They're clinging to outdated ideas about what a family should look like.

And frankly, it's none of their business.

A child needs love, and stability, and a safe environment. And those things can be provided by *anyone*, regardless of their sexual orientation or marital status.

So yeah. Absolutely. A child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements. And I'm living proof of that. I'm making the best decision for my baby, and that decision involves trusting him or her to a loving couple who will give him or her everything they need. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Don't make me do this. This is like, emotional excavation or something. But alright, fine. If I'm being brutally honest…

I think my biggest flaw is that I build walls. Really high, really thick walls. Around my heart. Around my feelings. Around everything.

It's a defense mechanism, I guess. I've been hurt before, and I don't want to get hurt again. So I keep people at arm's length. I use sarcasm and wit as a shield. I pretend I don't care.

And it works, to a certain extent. It protects me from getting too close to people. But it also prevents me from forming deep, meaningful connections. It keeps me from letting people in.

It's why I struggled so much with Leah, after everything happened. I pushed her away, because I was scared of being vulnerable. And I regret that.

It's also why I have trouble expressing my feelings. I'm good at analyzing things, at observing people, but I'm not good at talking about what's going on inside my own head.

I know it's not healthy. I know it's not fair to the people I care about. But it's hard to change. It's a habit, and habits are hard to break.

I'm working on it, though. I'm trying to be more open and honest with the people I trust. I'm trying to let go of my fear of vulnerability.

But it's a slow process. And I'm not always successful.

So yeah. Building walls. That's my biggest flaw. It's a weakness that I'm trying to overcome. But it's a tough one. And it's something I'll probably struggle with for a long time. It's just… who I am. A little bit broken, a little bit guarded, and a whole lot of sarcastic.

Okay, that's… a complicated question. It's not like Mark and I were *in* a relationship, you know? It was more… a connection. A shared experience. But it definitely changed how I thought about things.

Before, I had this really cynical view of relationships. Like, everyone was just trying to use each other, or they were just pretending to be something they weren't. I didn't really believe in "true love" or any of that stuff.

But getting to know Mark, and seeing how much he and Vanessa wanted a family… it made me realize that there *are* good people out there. People who are genuinely kind and compassionate and selfless.

They weren't looking for a perfect baby. They were looking for a baby to love. And they were willing to open their hearts and their home to someone else's child. That was… really beautiful.

It also made me realize that relationships aren't always about romance. They can be about friendship, and support, and shared values. Mark and Vanessa weren't just potential parents. They were also friends. They listened to me, they respected my decisions, and they made me feel like I wasn't alone.

It didn't make me suddenly believe in happily ever afters or anything. But it did make me a little bit more hopeful. It made me realize that there's good in the world, and that people are capable of great things.

And it made me realize that even though my relationship with the baby would be different, it didn't mean it wouldn't be meaningful. I'd always be the baby's first mother, and that's something no one can ever take away from me.

So yeah. Mark and Vanessa changed my perspective on relationships. They showed me that there's more to life than cynicism and sarcasm. And they reminded me that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. And that's something I'll never forget.

Okay, look. This is the real stuff, right? Someone's actually asking for advice, not just making small talk. Alright. Deep breath.

If you're in a situation like I was… pregnant and scared and unsure of what to do… the first thing I want you to know is: **you are not alone.** Seriously. So many people have been through this, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

Don't be afraid to **talk to someone you trust.** Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone who will listen without judgment. It's okay to ask for help. It's actually really brave.

Don't let anyone **pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with.** This is *your* life, and *your* body. You have the right to choose what's best for you.

**Take your time.** Don't rush into anything. Think about all your options, and weigh the pros and cons of each one.

**Be honest with yourself.** About your feelings, your fears, and your limitations. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers.

And **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of getting through this. Even when it feels like you can't.

It's going to be hard. There will be tears and doubts and moments when you want to give up. But you can't. You have to keep going.

And **don't be afraid to ask for help.** Seriously. There are people who care about you and want to support you. Lean on them. Let them help you.

This isn't the end of your story. It's just a chapter. And you have the power to write the rest of it.

It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be sad. But don't give up on yourself. You deserve happiness. And you deserve a future. And you are stronger than you think.

Just… breathe. And remember that you're not alone. Okay?

Oh, man. That's… a big question. My relationship with my dad, Mac, it's… complicated. But good. Mostly good.

When I was little, it was just him and me. My mom wasn't around much, so he was everything. He was my dad, my mom, my best friend, my everything. He tried his best, you know? He wasn't always the most emotionally available guy, but he always made sure I had what I needed.

As I got older, things got… trickier. I started to pull away, to become more independent. I wanted to define myself as separate from him. And I think he was a little bit hurt by that. He didn't understand why I needed space.

We had a lot of arguments. About everything. About my clothes, my music, my friends. About my life choices. It was… rough.

But then, when I got pregnant, everything changed. He was… surprisingly supportive. He didn't freak out, or yell, or anything like that. He just… listened. And he told me he loved me, no matter what.

That meant a lot to me. It made me realize that he wasn't just my dad, he was also my friend. And that he was willing to accept me for who I am, even when I make mistakes.

We still have our moments, of course. We still disagree about things. But we're better at communicating now. We're better at understanding each other.

I think this whole situation has brought us closer together. It's forced us to be honest with each other, and to rely on each other for support.

He's been really amazing throughout the adoption process. He's gone with me to appointments, he's talked to Mark and Vanessa, he's just been there for me every step of the way.

I'm really grateful for him. He's not perfect, but he's my dad. And I love him. And I think he loves me too. Even if he doesn't always know how to show it.

Our relationship has evolved over the years, from a simple father-daughter bond to a more complex and nuanced friendship. And I think it's stronger now than it's ever been. And that's something I really cherish.

Okay, so this is kinda embarrassing to admit, but it started with… fanfiction. Don't judge me! Everyone starts somewhere.

When I was like, twelve or thirteen, I was obsessed with this really obscure indie band. And there wasn't a lot of stuff written about them online. So I started writing my own stories about them. Ridiculous, angsty stories about love and heartbreak and the meaning of life.

It was terrible, honestly. Like, *really* terrible. But it was fun. And it forced me to think about plot and character and dialogue.

Then I started writing poetry. Mostly just as a way to vent my feelings. I didn't show it to anyone, of course. It was too personal.

In eighth grade, I took a creative writing class. The teacher, Mr. Peterson, was really cool. He didn't try to force us to write a certain way. He just encouraged us to experiment and to find our own voice.

He gave us a lot of prompts, and he gave us a lot of feedback. And he taught me the importance of revision. He said that writing is rewriting. Which is totally true.

I also read a lot. I read everything I could get my hands on. Novels, short stories, poems, plays. I paid attention to how different writers used language, and how they created characters and worlds.

And I just kept writing. Every day, even if it was just for a few minutes. I wrote in my journal, I wrote short stories, I wrote poems. I just kept practicing.

It's still a work in progress, of course. I'm not a professional writer or anything. But I'm getting better. And I enjoy it. It's a way for me to express myself, to make sense of the world, and to connect with others.

So yeah. Fanfiction, poetry, a good teacher, and a lot of practice. That's how I developed my creative writing skills. It's not a glamorous story, but it's mine. And I'm proud of it. Even the fanfiction part. Don't tell anyone.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big one. It wasn't fun. Not even a little bit. It felt like everyone was staring at me, whispering behind my back. Like I was some kind of… spectacle.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I just pretended it wasn't happening. But that didn't work. It just made me feel more isolated and alone.

Then, I got angry. I lashed out at people who were being judgmental. I was sarcastic and defensive. But that just made things worse. It just confirmed their stereotypes about me.

She encouraged me to surround myself with people who supported me. People who loved me for who I was, not for what I had done. And she reminded me that I wasn't defined by my pregnancy. I was still Juno. I was still a person with dreams and aspirations.

I also learned to be more assertive. I started speaking up for myself, and challenging people's assumptions. I didn't let them get away with being rude or judgmental.

And I found a lot of strength in my poetry. Writing about my feelings helped me to process my emotions and to find my voice.

It wasn't easy. There were days when I just wanted to hide under the covers and never come out. But I kept going. I kept reminding myself that I was strong, and that I deserved to be happy.

And I learned that most people's judgment says more about *them* than it does about *me*. They're projecting their own fears and insecurities onto me.

So yeah. It was a tough journey. But I got through it. And I'm stronger for it. And I learned that it's okay to be different. It's okay to make mistakes. And it's okay to ask for help. And that's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

(Sighs) Okay, that's a loaded question. It's something I think about a lot, actually.

The short answer is… sometimes. Yeah. Definitely sometimes.

Being outspoken and honest has gotten me into trouble more times than I can count. It's burned bridges, it's offended people, it's made things awkward. It's not always the easiest path.

There have been times when I've said something I regretted, or when my honesty has hurt someone's feelings. And those times are… rough. I feel terrible. I replay the conversation in my head a million times, wondering if I could have said things differently.

But then I remind myself that I'm not going to apologize for being myself. I'm not going to pretend to be someone I'm not, just to make other people feel comfortable.

I believe in being honest, even when it's difficult. I believe in speaking my mind, even when it's unpopular. I believe in standing up for what I believe in, even when it's scary.

It's not about being mean or insensitive. It's about being real. It's about being authentic. It's about refusing to compromise my values.

And honestly, I think the world needs more people who are willing to speak their minds. People who are willing to challenge the status quo. People who are willing to be honest, even when it's uncomfortable.

So yeah, I regret some of the things I've said. But I don't regret being honest. It's a part of who I am. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Besides, if I wasn't outspoken, I wouldn't be me. And that would be a tragedy. A really, really tragic tragedy.

Ugh. That's… the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's the thing I struggle with *constantly*.

Honestly, it's not easy. It's a constant battle between wanting to fit in and wanting to be myself. And sometimes, I slip up and try to be what other people want me to be. But it never feels right. It feels… fake.

I think the key is to **remember your values**. What's important to *you*? What do *you* believe in? And then to make decisions that are aligned with those values, even if they're not popular.

It also helps to **surround yourself with people who accept you for who you are**. People who don't try to change you, and who support your dreams. Bren is amazing at that. She just… gets me.

And you have to **learn to ignore the haters**. There will always be people who judge you, who criticize you, who try to bring you down. You can't let them get to you. You have to brush it off and keep moving forward.

It's also important to **be confident in your own skin**. To embrace your quirks and your imperfections. To know that you're worthy of love and respect, just as you are.

And sometimes, you just have to **tell people to mind their own business**. It's not always polite, but it's necessary. You don't owe anyone an explanation for your choices.

It's a process, though. It takes time and effort. And there will be setbacks. But it's worth it. Because at the end of the day, the only person you have to answer to is yourself.

So yeah. Remember your values, surround yourself with good people, ignore the haters, be confident, and tell people to mind their own business. It's not a perfect formula, but it's the best I've got. And it's helped me to stay true to myself, even when it's been really hard. And honestly, that's all that matters.

You're asking that again? Okay, fine. I guess it means it's important. I already kinda touched on this, but let's really break it down. If I had to pick just a few…

**Authenticity** is huge. I just… can't stand fake people. I want to be real, and I want to surround myself with people who are real too. No pretending, no masks, just genuine connection. It's why I connected with Mark and Vanessa, honestly. They were just… *them*.

**Kindness** is another big one. The world is a pretty messed up place, and a little bit of kindness can go a long way. I try to be kind to everyone, even people who aren't kind to me. It's not always easy, but I think it's important.
