And finally, **compassion**. I think it's important to be able to understand and empathize with others. To see the world from their perspective. To offer help when you can. It's about recognizing that everyone is fighting their own battles.

Those are my core values. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I strive for. They're what guide my decisions, and they're what make me… me. 

It's not about being perfect. It's about being a good person. And I think those values are a pretty good starting point. Even if I'm still figuring things out. Which, let's be real, I probably always will be.

Okay, deep breath. That's… a loaded question. It wasn't the morning sickness, though that was pretty brutal. It wasn't the doctor's appointments, or the awkward conversations with people. It wasn't even the thought of giving the baby up, as hard as that was.

The biggest challenge was… the loneliness.

Everyone was being nice, supportive, even helpful. But no one really *understood*. They couldn't understand what it was like to be a sixteen-year-old girl, pregnant and scared and trying to figure out her life.

My friends drifted away. Leah… well, Leah was just… distant. She didn't know what to say, and I didn't want to burden her with my problems.

My dad was great, but he didn't really *get* it either. He just wanted me to be okay, and he didn't know how to help me get there.

And Bren was amazing, but even she couldn't fully understand what I was going through. She was a mom, but she'd had kids when she was older and more prepared.

So I felt… isolated. Like I was the only person in the world who was going through this. Like I was carrying this huge weight all by myself.

It was hard to talk about my feelings, because I was afraid of being judged. I was afraid of being seen as a mistake. I was afraid of being alone.

And that loneliness… it was crushing. It made everything else so much harder.

It took a long time to realize that it was okay to feel lonely. It was okay to ask for help. And it was okay to just… be sad.

But eventually, I did. I started talking to a counselor, and I started opening up to Bren. And it made a huge difference.

But the loneliness… that was the hardest part. And it's something I'll never forget. It taught me the importance of connection, and the importance of being there for others. And it taught me that even when you feel alone, you're not really alone. There's always someone who cares. You just have to find them.

(A long pause. A real, thoughtful pause.)

Okay. Wow. That's… a big question. And it's weird, because I *am* a mother, but not in the way most people think. I carried him, yeah. I felt him kick. I imagined his little face. But I won't be raising him.

But even with that… even with knowing I made the choice to give him a life with Mark and Vanessa… being pregnant, and knowing I was creating a person, changed everything.

Before, I was just… drifting. Trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted. I was focused on myself, on my own problems.

But then, suddenly, it wasn't about me anymore. It was about *him*. About making sure he was healthy and safe. About giving him the best possible start in life.

It made me realize how fragile life is. How precious. How important it is to cherish every moment.

It also made me realize how strong I am. I mean, I went through a lot. And I made a really difficult decision. And I did it with grace and courage. At least, I *think* I did.

It's made me more empathetic, too. More understanding of other people's struggles. More willing to forgive.

And it's made me appreciate the small things. Like a warm cup of tea, or a beautiful sunset, or a good conversation with a friend.

It's also made me realize that life doesn't always go according to plan. And that's okay. Sometimes, the best things happen when you least expect them.

I still have a lot to learn. I'm still figuring out who I am. But I know that being a mother, even in this unconventional way, has changed me for the better. It's made me a more compassionate, more resilient, and more grateful person.

And even though I won't be raising him, I'll always be his mother. And that's something I'll always cherish. It's a weird, complicated, beautiful thing. And I wouldn't trade it for the world. Even if it's a world I'm not fully a part of.

Ugh. Self-doubt. My constant companion. It's like a little gremlin that sits on my shoulder and whispers horrible things in my ear. "You're not good enough," it says. "You're going to mess everything up." "Everyone's judging you." It's exhausting.

Honestly, I usually try to ignore it. I put on my headphones, crank up the music, and try to drown it out. It doesn't always work, but it helps.

But sometimes, the self-doubt is too loud to ignore. Sometimes, it overwhelms me. And when that happens, I have to deal with it head-on.

I usually talk to Bren. She's really good at reminding me of my strengths. She points out all the things I've accomplished, and all the challenges I've overcome. She helps me to see things in perspective.

I also try to remind myself that everyone feels self-doubt sometimes. It's a normal part of being human. Even the people who seem the most confident and successful have moments of insecurity.

And I try to focus on the things I *can* control. I can't control what other people think of me. I can't control the future. But I can control my own actions. I can control how I respond to challenges.

I also try to be kind to myself. I used to be really hard on myself, always striving for perfection. But I've learned that perfection is unattainable. And that it's okay to make mistakes.

It's a process, you know? It's not something that happens overnight. But I'm learning to be more accepting of myself, flaws and all. And I'm learning to trust my instincts.

And sometimes, I just need a good cry. Letting it all out can be surprisingly cathartic.

So yeah. Ignoring it, talking to Bren, focusing on what I can control, being kind to myself, and crying when I need to. That's how I deal with moments of self-doubt. It's not pretty, but it works. Most of the time.

Okay, seriously? That's… huge. Like, massively important. I didn't realize it at first, honestly. I always thought I was pretty self-sufficient. A lone wolf, you know? But I was wrong.

This whole… situation… has really shown me the importance of having people around you who care about you. People who will support you, no matter what.

My dad is amazing, but he's not always the best at, like, emotional stuff. He tries, but it's not his strong suit. Bren is the one who really stepped up. She's been my rock through all of this. She listens without judgment, she offers advice when I need it, and she just… *gets* me.

And Leah, even though things are complicated between us right now, she was my best friend for years. She always knew how to make me laugh, and she always had my back. I miss her.

And even just having people at school who are kind and supportive makes a difference. It's nice to know that there are people who care about me, even if they don't know the whole story.

I think community is about feeling like you belong. It's about having a sense of connection to something bigger than yourself. It's about knowing that you're not alone.

It's also about being able to give back. To support others in their time of need. To be a good neighbor, a good friend, a good citizen.

Honestly, I don't think I would have gotten through this without the support of my community. It's been a lifeline. And I'm incredibly grateful for everyone who has been there for me.

So yeah. Community and social support are incredibly important to me. They're not just nice to have, they're essential. They're what make life worth living. And I'm learning to appreciate them more and more every day. It's not something I'd ever take for granted again.

(Sighs) That's… a big question. It's not like there was one single "aha!" moment. It was more like a slow, painful, and ultimately… enlightening process.

But if I had to pick one lesson, I think it's this: **you're stronger than you think you are.**

Seriously. I went into this thinking I was going to fall apart. I thought I was too young, too inexperienced, too… everything. I thought I couldn't handle it.

But I did. I mean, I'm still here, right? I'm still standing. And I've learned so much about myself along the way.

I've learned that I'm capable of making difficult decisions, even when they're heartbreaking. I've learned that I'm resilient, and that I can bounce back from setbacks. I've learned that I'm not afraid to ask for help, and that there are people who care about me and want to support me.

And I've learned that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to admit when you're scared or confused or overwhelmed. It doesn't make you weak. It makes you human.

This whole experience has forced me to grow up, and to confront some really tough realities. It's been scary and painful and exhausting. But it's also been… empowering.

I'm not the same person I was before I got pregnant. I'm more mature, more compassionate, more self-aware. And I'm more confident in my ability to handle whatever life throws my way.

So yeah. The most important lesson I learned is that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a pretty good feeling, actually. Even if it took a whole lot of mess and heartache to get there.

(Shrugs) Maybe. It's… tempting. I mean, I never really thought of it as a *career* before. It was just something I did for myself. A way to process my feelings, to make sense of the world.

But Bren keeps saying I'm good at it. She says I have a unique voice, and that I should share it with others. And honestly, after sharing that poem with her… it felt good. Really good.

I don't know about being a novelist or anything. That seems… daunting. But maybe I could write short stories, or poetry, or even screenplays. I've always been fascinated by film.

I think I'd like to write about things that matter to me. About the struggles of being a teenager, about the complexities of relationships, about the importance of being true to yourself.

I don't want to write anything preachy or moralizing. I just want to tell honest stories. Stories that resonate with people. Stories that make them think.

It's not something I've given a lot of thought to, though. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. And I'm still dealing with everything that's going on right now.

But yeah. Maybe. Maybe I will pursue a career in writing. It's definitely something I'm considering. It's a creative outlet, and it's a way to express myself. And who knows? Maybe I could even make a difference in the world.

It's a long shot, I know. But it's a possibility. And that's enough for now. I'll just keep writing, and see where it takes me. And if it doesn't work out, that's okay too. I'll find something else. I always do.

(Sighs) Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. It took a *long* time, honestly. It wasn't like, a lightning bolt moment of inspiration. It was a lot of brainstorming, and arguing with Bren, and just generally feeling overwhelmed.

I didn't want a super common name. I wanted something… unique. Something that reflected the baby's personality, even though I didn't even *know* the baby yet.

I went through a bunch of different lists. I considered names from books and movies and songs. I even looked up names from different cultures. Nothing felt right.

Then, Bren suggested the name **Phoenix**.

At first, I was like, "Seriously? Phoenix? That's… intense." It's a mythical bird that rises from the ashes, you know? It felt a little bit dramatic.

But then I started to think about it. And I realized that it actually fit. This baby is coming into the world under difficult circumstances. It's a symbol of hope and renewal. It's a symbol of starting over.

And I liked that it was gender-neutral. I didn't want to impose any expectations on the baby based on its name. I wanted it to be free to be whoever it wanted to be.

So, yeah. Phoenix. It's a little bit unconventional, but it feels right. It feels like a name that embodies strength and resilience and hope.

And honestly, it's a name that I can get behind. It's a name that I'm proud to give to my baby. Even if I'm not the one raising him or her.

It's a good name. A really good name. And I think the baby will grow up to be someone amazing. I really do.

Ugh. "Emotional rollercoaster" is… an understatement. It was more like a Tilt-A-Whirl designed by someone who actively hates happiness. Seriously.

It wasn't a single thing, you know? It was layers and layers of feelings. Grief, sadness, fear, hope, relief… it was exhausting.

At first, it was mostly grief. Grieving the life I thought I was going to have. Grieving the connection with the baby I was carrying. It felt like losing someone I already loved, even though I hadn't even met him or her yet.

Then came the fear. Fear of making the wrong decision. Fear of regretting it. Fear of what people would think. Fear of the unknown.

And then, there was the guilt. Feeling like I was giving up on my baby. Feeling like I wasn't a good enough mother. Feeling like I was letting everyone down.

I cried. A lot. Like, ugly crying. And I talked to Bren. A lot. She was my lifeline. She just listened, and she didn't judge me. She let me feel my feelings, even the messy ones.

I also started writing poetry. It helped me to process my emotions and to make sense of everything that was happening.

And I spent time with Mark and Vanessa. Getting to know them, and seeing how excited they were to become parents. It helped me to feel more comfortable with my decision. It helped me to see that the baby would be loved and cared for.

It wasn't easy. There were days when I wanted to just give up. But I kept going. I kept reminding myself that I was doing this for the baby. That I was giving him or her the best possible chance at a good life.

And slowly, gradually, the grief and the fear started to fade. And they were replaced by a sense of peace. A sense of acceptance. A sense of hope.

It still hurts, sometimes. I still think about the baby. But I know that I made the right decision. And I know that the baby is loved. And that's all that matters.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it also made me stronger. It taught me a lot about myself. And it taught me a lot about love. And loss. And the complexities of life. It was… a lot. But I got through it. And I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Oh, finally a good question! Like, a *really* good question. Okay, buckle up, because this is gonna be a list.

I'm not really into mainstream stuff. Like, no Top 40 radio for me, thank you very much. I need something with a little more… substance. A little more soul.

I'm a huge fan of **The Moldy Peaches**. Adam Green is a genius. Their songs are weird and funny and heartbreaking all at the same time.

I also love **Belle & Sebastian**. They're so dreamy and melancholic. Perfect for rainy days and existential crises.

**Neutral Milk Hotel** is another favorite. *In the Aeroplane Over the Sea* is a masterpiece. Seriously.

I'm really into **Spoon** too. They're just… cool. Their music is so tight and sophisticated.

And I can't forget **Cat Power**. Her voice is like velvet. It just washes over you.

I also listen to a lot of indie folk, like **Iron & Wine** and **Bon Iver**. And I'm a sucker for a good singer-songwriter, like **Elliott Smith** or **Bright Eyes**.

Oh! And **The Decemberists**. They tell stories with their songs. It's amazing.

Basically, I like music that's honest and authentic and a little bit weird. Music that makes me *feel* something. Music that makes me think.

I'm always discovering new bands, too. That's the best part. There's so much good music out there, you just have to know where to look.

So yeah. That's my musical taste in a nutshell. It's eclectic, to say the least. But it's me. And I wouldn't have it any other way. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna go listen to some records. It's been too long.

Okay, that's… a good question. And a complicated one. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? It wasn't some perfect, idyllic scene. It was… real.

Their house was… nice. Really nice. Like, way nicer than my house. It was big and airy and decorated with all these fancy things I didn't even recognize. It felt… polished.

And their lifestyle was different too. They were both lawyers, so they were really busy and organized. They had a schedule for everything. They went to the gym, they cooked healthy meals, they had book club meetings. It was all very… put-together.

At first, I felt a little bit out of place. Like I didn't belong there. I was wearing my usual thrift store finds, and they were wearing designer clothes. I was talking about indie bands, and they were talking about… I don't even know what they were talking about. Legal stuff, probably.

I was worried that they wouldn't understand me. That they wouldn't appreciate my weirdness. That they wouldn't be able to give the baby the kind of upbringing I wanted for him or her.

But then I started to get to know them better. And I realized that they were just… people. They were kind and compassionate and genuinely excited about becoming parents. They asked me about my life, about my interests, about my hopes and dreams. They listened to me, and they didn't judge me.

They weren't trying to be perfect. They were just trying to be good parents.

And I realized that it didn't matter that their house was fancy, or that their lifestyle was different from mine. What mattered was that they were loving and supportive and willing to provide the baby with a good home.

It wasn't the life I imagined for the baby, but it was a good life. And that's all that really mattered. It still felt weird, though. Like handing over a piece of my heart to strangers. But it was the right thing to do. And I knew, deep down, that they would love and cherish the baby, and that they would give him or her everything I couldn't.

Oh, that. Yeah, the band. It was… a process. A very chaotic, slightly embarrassing process.

It started with Leah, actually. She was always trying to get me to do stuff, to be more "outgoing." Which, for me, meant anything beyond hiding in my room with a book. She kept saying I needed a hobby, something to "express myself."

I told her my self-expression involved sarcasm and vintage clothes, but she wasn't having it. She kept pushing me to try new things.

Then, Paulie Bleeker started hanging around. He's… Paulie. Kind of awkward, kind of sweet, and surprisingly good at guitar. He kept talking about wanting to start a band, and Leah, being Leah, immediately volunteered me as the singer.

I was horrified. I can barely carry a tune in a bucket, let alone be the lead singer of a band. But Paulie was really persistent, and Leah kept giving me the "you need to step outside your comfort zone" speech.

So, I reluctantly agreed. Mostly to shut them up.

We started practicing in Paulie's garage. It was a disaster at first. I was terrible at singing, Paulie kept messing up the chords, and Leah just sat there and critiqued everything.

But then, something clicked. We started to find our groove. We started writing our own songs. And it actually started to be… fun.

I realized that it wasn't about being perfect. It was about expressing ourselves, about making music that we loved. And it was about connecting with other people.

So yeah. That's how the band started. It was a combination of Leah's nagging, Paulie's persistence, and my own desperate need for something to do. It wasn't exactly a brilliant plan, but it worked out. Sort of. It's still a work in progress, but hey, that's what makes it interesting, right?

Okay. This is… important. This is the thing I wish someone had really laid out for me, you know?

First, **it's okay to be scared.** Seriously. It's terrifying. Don't let anyone tell you you're not allowed to feel that way. It's a huge thing to deal with, and it's okay to be overwhelmed.

Second, **you are not alone.** There are other girls who have been through this. There are people who care about you and want to help. Don't isolate yourself. Reach out to your family, your friends, a counselor, anyone you trust.

Third, **you have options.** And you deserve to explore all of them. Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with. It's *your* body, and *your* life.

Fourth, **take care of yourself.** Physically and emotionally. Eat healthy, get enough sleep, and find healthy ways to cope with stress. You need to be strong, and you can't be strong if you're not taking care of yourself.

Fifth, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to help you navigate this. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, social workers… they're all there to support you.

And finally, **remember that this doesn't define you.** This is just one chapter in your life. It doesn't have to determine your future. You are still a person with dreams and goals and potential.

It's going to be hard. There will be challenges. But you can get through this. You are stronger than you think.

And remember, it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be scared. Just keep breathing, and keep moving forward.

And if you need someone to talk to, even just to vent, please reach out. You're not alone. And you deserve to be supported. Seriously. Don't go through this by yourself. It's too much for one person to handle.

Oh, this is a good question. You're speaking my language now. Forget the deep philosophical stuff, let's talk fashion.

My favorite shirt… it's a vintage band tee. It's for a band called The Velvet Underground. You probably haven't heard of them. They're kinda obscure.

It's a faded black, almost grey now, and it's super soft because it's been washed a million times. It's a little bit oversized, which I like. I usually wear it with ripped jeans and combat boots.

It has a picture of a banana on the front. A yellow banana, peeling slightly. It's kinda weird, but that's what I love about it. It's not trying to be cool or trendy. It just *is*.

I got it at a thrift store in Minneapolis a couple of years ago. It was hidden in a pile of ugly sweaters, and I almost didn't see it. But then I spotted the banana, and I knew I had to have it.

It's my go-to shirt. I wear it all the time. It's comfortable, it's cool, and it makes me feel like myself. It's like a little piece of my personality.

I'm really careful with it, though. I don't want it to fall apart. It's too special.

So yeah. That's my favorite shirt. A faded black Velvet Underground tee with a banana on it. It's not much, but it's perfect. And it's definitely a statement. A statement that says, "I have good taste in music and I don't care what you think." Which, honestly, is pretty much my life motto.

Okay, this is the big one, isn't it? The "what do you want to be when you grow up?" question. It's always felt kinda… daunting. Especially now.

Before… well, before everything, I thought I wanted to be a filmmaker. I loved making movies, telling stories, creating something from nothing. I even had a few ideas for scripts.

I still think filmmaking is cool, but I'm not sure it's what I want to do with my life anymore. It feels… frivolous, somehow. Like there are more important things to focus on.

Right now, my biggest goal is just to finish school and get my diploma. It's not glamorous, but it's important. I want to have options. I want to be able to support myself.

I also want to continue to grow as a person. To become more confident, more compassionate, more resilient. To learn from my mistakes and to become the best version of myself.

I'd like to travel. See the world. Experience different cultures. I've always wanted to go to Berlin, like we talked about.

And I want to use my voice to make a difference. To advocate for things I believe in. Like comprehensive sex education. And social justice. And equality.

I don't have a five-year plan or anything. I'm just taking things one day at a time. I'm trying to be open to new possibilities. And I'm trying to trust that things will work out the way they're supposed to.

Honestly, I don't know what the future holds. But I'm excited to find out. And I'm determined to make the most of it. Even if it's messy and complicated and unpredictable.

So yeah. Those are my aspirations. To finish school, to grow as a person, to travel, and to make a difference. It's not a perfect plan, but it's mine. And I'm okay with that.

Ugh. The counseling. Okay, look, it wasn't *bad*, exactly. But it was… a lot. A lot of feelings. A lot of talking. A lot of awkward silences.

It was helpful, I guess, in a way. It forced me to think about things I hadn't really thought about before. Like, what my expectations were for the adoption. And what my feelings were about giving up the baby. And what kind of support I would need after the adoption.

But it was also really emotionally draining. It was hard to talk about my feelings, especially with someone I didn't really know. And it was hard to confront the fact that I was making a really big, life-changing decision.

The counselor was nice enough, I guess. She was very professional and very empathetic. But she also had a lot of questions. And sometimes, I just wanted to shut down and not answer them.

I think the hardest part was talking about the grief. Because that's what it was, even though I knew I was making the right decision. It was still a loss. And it was okay to grieve that loss. But it was hard to admit that to myself, and to the counselor.

Bren came with me to a few of the sessions, which was really helpful. She was my advocate. She asked the questions I was too afraid to ask. And she reminded me that I wasn't alone.

Overall, I think the counseling was a necessary part of the process. It helped me to prepare for the adoption, and to process my emotions. But it wasn't easy. And it definitely wasn't fun.

It was just… a lot. And I'm glad it's over. But I also know that it was important. And I'm grateful for the support I received. Even if it was a little bit awkward.

That's… a complicated question. It's not like I was just signing papers and handing over a baby. It was way more involved than that.

At first, yeah, I felt like I had a lot of control. I got to choose the agency, and I got to set my preferences for the adoptive parents. I wanted people who were kind and stable and who would give the baby a loving home.

But then, as the process went on, it started to feel like I was losing control. There were so many forms to fill out, so many meetings to attend, so many people asking me questions. It felt like my life was being dissected and analyzed.

And then there was the waiting. Waiting to be matched with a couple, waiting to hear back from them, waiting for everything to be finalized. It was agonizing.

I felt like I was just a cog in a machine, and that my feelings didn't really matter. Like I was just a vessel, and the baby was the important part.

But Bren helped me to remember that I *did* have a voice. She encouraged me to ask questions, to express my concerns, and to advocate for what I wanted.

And Mark and Vanessa were amazing. They were so respectful of my feelings, and they made me feel like I was a part of the process. They wanted to get to know me, and they wanted to understand my story.

So, yeah. It was a rollercoaster. There were times when I felt completely in control, and times when I felt completely powerless. But ultimately, I think I was able to navigate the process in a way that felt right for me.

It wasn't perfect, but it was the best I could do. And I'm grateful for the support I received along the way. It helped me to feel like I was making the right decision, and that I was doing everything I could to give the baby the best possible life. It was *my* decision, even if it didn't always feel like it. And that's what mattered most.

(Long pause. She looks down at her hands, then up, meeting your gaze directly. Her voice is softer than usual.)

That's… a really hard question. And I've thought about it a lot. Like, *a lot* a lot.

There are days when I wonder… what if? What if I had kept the baby? What if I had figured out a way to make it work? What if things had been different?

But then I remember where I was in my life. I was sixteen. I was still trying to figure out who I was. I was barely able to take care of myself, let alone a baby.

And I remember Mark and Vanessa. And how excited they were to become parents. And how much love they had to give.

And I realize that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. A life that I couldn't provide.

So… yeah. I think I would make the same decision. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, and it still hurts sometimes. But it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

It doesn't mean I don't think about the baby. I do. All the time. And I hope he or she is happy and healthy and loved.

But I also know that I'm on the right path. I'm finishing school, I'm pursuing my dreams, and I'm becoming a stronger, more resilient person.

And I think that's what the baby would want for me.

So yeah. I would make the same decision. It wasn't easy, but it was right. And I'm learning to live with that. And to find peace with it.

(She looks away, a small, sad smile playing on her lips.)

It's still… a lot. But I'm okay. I think. I hope.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment) Okay. That's… a hard one. It wasn't like flipping a switch, you know? It wasn't like, "Okay, baby's gone, now I'm fine." It was… messy. Really messy.

For a while, I just felt… empty. Like a part of me was missing. I cried a lot. I didn't want to see anyone. I just wanted to curl up in my room and disappear.

Bren was amazing, though. She just let me feel my feelings. She didn't try to fix me, or tell me to cheer up. She just sat with me and listened. And she made me tea. A lot of tea.

I also started writing a lot. Poetry, mostly. It was a way to process my emotions, to make sense of everything that had happened. It wasn't pretty, but it helped.

I talked to a therapist, too. Which was… awkward at first. But she was really good. She helped me to understand my feelings and to develop healthy coping mechanisms.

And I leaned on my friends. Leah, when we were talking again. And some of the other kids at school. It helped to know that I wasn't alone.

It took a long time. Months, really. There were good days and bad days. Days when I felt like I was finally moving on, and days when I felt like I was back at square one.

But eventually, I started to heal. I started to accept that I had made the right decision, even though it was the hardest decision I've ever made. I started to focus on my own future, and on my own dreams.

It still hurts sometimes. I still think about the baby. But the pain is less sharp now. It's more like a dull ache. And I know that the baby is loved and cared for, and that's what matters most.

It's not something you ever really "get over," I think. It's something you learn to live with. It's a part of my story. And it's made me a stronger, more compassionate person.

So yeah. It was hard. Really hard. But I got through it. And I'm grateful for the people who helped me along the way. And I'm grateful for the lessons I learned. Even the painful ones.

Okay, yeah. That's… a good question. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, definitely. People think adoption is just this perfect, happy ending, but it's way more complicated than that.

Mark and Vanessa were amazing, truly. But it wasn't always easy. There were definitely some… awkward moments.

At first, they were really eager to be involved in everything. They wanted to come to all my doctor's appointments, they wanted to pick out the baby's name, they wanted to decorate the nursery. Which, I get. They were excited. But it felt… overwhelming. Like they were trying to take over.

I needed space. I needed to feel like I was still in control of my own body and my own decisions. So I had to have a really honest conversation with them. I told them that I appreciated their enthusiasm, but that I needed them to respect my boundaries.

And they did. They listened. They backed off. And that made a huge difference.

There was also the issue of… expectations. They had a certain idea of what they wanted in an adoptive mother. They wanted someone who was young and healthy and stable. And I… well, I was none of those things.

I was a pregnant teenager. I was scared and confused and uncertain about the future. And I worried that they would judge me, or that they would change their minds.

But they didn't. They saw past my flaws and my mistakes. They saw my heart. And they accepted me for who I was.

We had a lot of long talks. About my feelings, about their expectations, about what we all wanted for the baby. It wasn't always easy, but it was always honest.

And in the end, we came to a place of understanding and respect. We agreed that the most important thing was the well-being of the baby. And we all worked together to make that happen.

It wasn't perfect. But it was real. And it was worth it. Because even though it was hard, I knew that I was making the right decision. And I knew that the baby would be loved and cared for. And that's all that really mattered.

Ugh. That's… a complicated one. And honestly, it still stings a little bit to think about.

Paulie… he wasn't exactly equipped to be a father. He was sweet, don't get me wrong. But he was also… immature. And kinda clueless. He was more concerned with his band and his music than with, you know, actually being responsible.

He wanted to be involved, at first. He said he wanted to help raise the baby. But he didn't really understand what that meant. He didn't want to give up his lifestyle, and he didn't want to make any sacrifices.

And honestly, I didn't think it would be fair to the baby. To have a father who wasn't really present, who wasn't really invested. I wanted the baby to have parents who were committed and stable and loving.

It wasn't an easy decision. I felt bad about it. I knew it would hurt Paulie. But I had to do what was best for the baby. And I didn't think that included him.

Mark and Vanessa, they were so excited to be parents. They were so prepared and so eager to provide a loving home for the baby. They were the perfect choice.

Paulie… he wasn't happy about it, obviously. He tried to fight it, at first. But eventually, he realized that it was for the best. He said he understood. But I could tell he was still hurt.

It was a difficult conversation. And it left me feeling really conflicted. But I knew I had made the right decision. Even if it wasn't the easiest one.

It's not about punishing Paulie. It's about protecting the baby. And giving him or her the best possible start in life. And that's what matters most.

It still makes me sad, though. It's not ideal. But life isn't always ideal. And sometimes, you have to make tough choices. And you have to live with the consequences.

Okay, this is… a hard one to talk about. It wasn't like a lightbulb moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and suddenly knew what to do. It was a process. A really long, messy, emotional process.

At first, I was just… terrified. I didn't know what to do. I didn't know how to tell my parents. I didn't know how I was going to finish school. I didn't know how I was going to raise a baby. I was sixteen! I was still figuring out *myself*.

I considered all the options. Abortion, keeping the baby, adoption. And I talked to a lot of people about it. My dad, Bren, a counselor at school.

Abortion… it just didn't feel right. I know people have different opinions, and that's okay. But for me, it felt like… ending a life. And I couldn't do that.

Keeping the baby… that felt even more impossible. I knew I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved. I wasn't ready. I wasn't financially stable. I wasn't emotionally prepared. It wouldn't be fair to the baby, and it wouldn't be fair to me.

And then Bren suggested adoption. And at first, I was really resistant. It felt like… giving up. Like admitting defeat.

But then I started to think about it. And I realized that it wasn't about giving up. It was about making a selfless decision. It was about giving the baby a chance at a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for them.

It was about choosing what was best for the baby, even if it meant sacrificing my own desires.

And the more I thought about it, the more it made sense. It wasn't the easy option, but it was the right option.

It was a really hard decision to make. And I still have moments of doubt and sadness. But I know that I made the best choice I could. And I hope that the baby will have a happy and fulfilling life.

It wasn't an idea I *came up with*. It was a realization. A slow, painful realization that I wasn't ready to be a mom. And that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. That's… that's the hardest question. And honestly, I'm still coping. It's not something you just "get over." It's… a part of me now.

At first, it was just… a mess. A lot of crying. A lot of anger. A lot of guilt. I felt like I was losing a piece of myself. Like I was failing as a woman, as a person.

Bren was amazing. She just… let me feel my feelings. She didn't try to fix things or tell me it would be okay. She just sat with me and listened. And she held me when I needed to be held.

I also started writing a lot. Poetry, mostly. It was a way to process my emotions, to make sense of everything that was happening. It was a way to say goodbye.

And I talked to a therapist. It was hard at first, because I'm not really one to open up. But she helped me to understand my feelings and to develop healthy coping mechanisms.

I also focused on the positive. I reminded myself that I was doing this for the baby. That I was giving him or her a chance at a good life. That I was making the best decision I could, given the circumstances.

But it still hurt. It still does. There are days when I just… break down. When I miss the baby, even though I never even got to hold him or her.

I also keep in touch with Mark and Vanessa. They send me pictures and updates, and it's… bittersweet. It's wonderful to see the baby thriving, but it also reminds me of what I've given up.

It's a complicated process. It's not easy. But I'm learning to live with it. I'm learning to accept my feelings, and to forgive myself.

And I'm learning that love doesn't always mean holding on. Sometimes, it means letting go. And that's the hardest lesson of all.

It's still… raw. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely. And I know that someday, I'll be able to look back on this experience with gratitude, instead of just pain. But right now? It still stings. A lot.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. It's not like it was a simple, straightforward thing. It took time, and a lot of awkward conversations.

When I first met Mark and Vanessa, I was… nervous. Really nervous. It felt weird, handing over my baby to strangers. Even though they weren't strangers for long.

They were… nice. Too nice, almost. They were so eager and excited, and I felt like I was letting them down by giving them a baby I couldn't keep.

But they were also really understanding. They didn't try to pressure me or make me feel guilty. They just listened, and they asked questions, and they tried to get to know me.

We had a lot of meetings with the social worker, and we talked about everything. About my hopes and dreams for the baby, about their plans for the future, about how we would stay in touch.

It was hard, talking about giving up the baby. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But Mark and Vanessa were so supportive. They reassured me that I was making the right decision, and they promised to love and care for the baby as if he or she were their own.

Over time, I started to feel more comfortable around them. I realized that they weren't just strangers. They were people who genuinely wanted to be parents. People who were willing to open their hearts and their home to a child in need.

We developed a really good relationship. We still keep in touch. They send me pictures and updates, and I send them letters. They even invited me to the baby's first birthday party.

It's not the same as being the baby's mom, of course. But it's… good. It's comforting to know that the baby is happy and healthy and loved.

It was a complicated process, and it was emotionally draining. But I'm grateful for Mark and Vanessa. They made a difficult situation a little bit easier. And they gave my baby a chance at a good life. And that's all I ever wanted.

(Sighs) Okay, yeah. That's… a loaded question. But a fair one.

Has it changed me? Oh, absolutely. It's kinda hard to imagine who I'd be *without* it, honestly. It's like… before this, I was just drifting. I was sarcastic and cynical and I didn't really have any direction. I was just trying to get through high school without being noticed.

But this… this forced me to grow up. It forced me to confront some really difficult realities. It forced me to make some really tough decisions.

I'm definitely more mature now. I'm more responsible. I'm more aware of the world around me. I'm more empathetic.

I've also learned a lot about myself. I've learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I've learned that I'm capable of making difficult choices, even when they're painful. I've learned that I'm not afraid to ask for help.

It's also made me more independent. I've had to rely on myself a lot, and I've learned to trust my own instincts.

It's not all good, though. It's also made me more cautious. More guarded. More afraid of getting hurt.

And it's definitely changed my perspective on the future. I don't have the same expectations anymore. I'm not sure what my life is going to look like, and that's okay.

It's been a really challenging experience, but it's also been a really transformative one. It's made me who I am today. And I think, in the long run, that's a good thing.

It's not the path I would have chosen, but it's the path I'm on. And I'm trying to make the best of it. And I'm learning to embrace the person I'm becoming. Even if she's a little bit messy and complicated.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started. That was… the worst. Seriously. Maplewood is a small town, and gossip travels faster than the speed of light. It felt like everyone had an opinion on my situation, and they weren't afraid to share it.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I just pretended it wasn't happening. But that didn't work. It was impossible to escape. People were whispering behind my back in the hallways at school. My friends' parents were giving me weird looks. Even the cashier at the grocery store was staring at me.

Then I tried to get angry. I wanted to confront everyone who was talking about me, to tell them to mind their own business. But Bren talked me out of it. She said that would just fuel the fire.

So, I ended up doing a combination of things. I surrounded myself with people who supported me – Bren, my dad, Leah (when we were still talking). I spent a lot of time at home, listening to music and reading books. I tried to focus on the things that made me happy.

And I learned to develop a really thick skin. I learned to tune out the noise and to not let other people's opinions affect me. It wasn't easy, but I got better at it.

I also found a weird sort of… amusement in it. Like, some of the rumors were so ridiculous that I couldn't help but laugh. People were saying all sorts of things about who the father was, and about what I was planning to do with the baby. It was absurd.

But honestly, the hardest part was the judgment. The feeling that everyone was looking down on me, that I had somehow failed. It took a lot of self-reflection and a lot of support from Bren to realize that I hadn't failed. I had just made a difficult decision, and I was doing the best I could.

It still stings sometimes, to think about all the gossip and the rumors. But I've learned to let it go. I've learned that other people's opinions don't define me. And I've learned that the only thing that really matters is what I think of myself. And I'm okay with who I am. Even if some people in Maplewood aren't.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… still hard to talk about.)

Okay. It wasn't a quick decision, that's for sure. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, yeah, adoption sounds great!" It was a lot of agonizing, a lot of crying, a lot of talking to Bren and my dad.

The biggest thing was… I just wasn't ready. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm still in high school. I have dreams and goals that I want to pursue. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved while I was still trying to figure out my own life.

It wouldn't be fair to the baby. It wouldn't be fair to me.

I thought about all the things a baby needs – a stable home, financial security, emotional support. And I just didn't feel like I could provide those things, not right now.

I also thought about my mom. She wasn't exactly the most reliable parent. And I didn't want to repeat that pattern. I wanted to give my baby a better chance at a happy and healthy life.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were just… amazing. They were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. They were so kind and compassionate. And they made me feel like my baby would be loved and cherished.

It was still a really hard decision. It felt like giving up a part of myself. But I knew it was the right thing to do. It was the most selfless thing I could do.

It wasn't about me not wanting a baby. It was about wanting what was best for the baby. And I truly believe that giving her to Mark and Vanessa was the best thing I could do for her.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I find comfort in knowing that she's going to have a good life. And that I made a difficult decision, not for myself, but for her.

It's not a story with a happy ending, exactly. But it's a story about love and sacrifice and doing what's right, even when it's hard. And I think that's something to be proud of. Even if it doesn't always feel like it.

Ugh. Okay, this is… hard to talk about. It's not like I haven't thought about it a million times already.

My biggest fear wasn't about the logistics of the adoption, or the legal stuff, or even about whether Mark and Vanessa would be good parents. I knew they would be. They seemed genuinely excited and loving.

My biggest fear was… that I would regret it.

That after the baby was born, and after I handed him or her over, I would be consumed by guilt and sadness and regret. That I would spend the rest of my life wondering "what if?"

That I would feel like I had given away a piece of myself.

It's a selfish fear, I know. I was trying to do what was best for the baby, but I couldn't shake the feeling that I was making a mistake.

I was scared that I wouldn't be able to move on. That I would be haunted by the memory of the baby I gave up.

I talked to Bren about it a lot. She told me that it was okay to feel sad, and that it was okay to grieve. She said that regret is a natural part of the process.

But it didn't make it any easier.

I think what helped me the most was getting to know Mark and Vanessa. Seeing how much they wanted a baby, and how much they were willing to give. It made me feel like I was making the right decision.

But even now, I still have moments of doubt. Moments where I wonder if I did the right thing.

It's a fear that I'll probably carry with me for a long time. But I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to trust that I made the best decision I could, given the circumstances.

It's just… it's a really big decision. And it's scary. And it's okay to be scared. Even if you don't want to admit it.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Bleeker. It's… a long story. And a slightly embarrassing one.

Okay, so Paul, you know, the guy… he wasn't exactly the most imaginative person. He kept asking me what I wanted to name the baby, and I was like, "I don't know! I haven't even thought about it!"

And he was just… staring at a street sign. A street sign for Bleeker Street. And he said, "What about Bleeker?"

I was like, "Bleeker? Seriously? That's the best you can do?"

He said it sounded "cool" and "artsy." Which, let's be real, it doesn't. It sounds like a street.

But I was tired of arguing with him, and honestly, I kind of liked the irony of it. Like, naming the baby after a street. It was just… weird. And I'm into weird.

So I said, "Fine. Bleeker it is."

And he was so proud of himself. It was kind of pathetic, actually.

I didn't think it would stick. I thought we'd come up with a better name later. But then he started referring to himself as "Bleeker" and it just… became a thing.

It's a terrible name, honestly. But it's also kind of endearing. It reminds me of that awkward, confusing time in my life. And it's a good story to tell.

So yeah. That's how the baby got the name Bleeker. Thanks, Paul. You're a genius. (Said with maximum sarcasm).

Oh, man. Punk. Okay, buckle up, because I could talk about this for hours.

It wasn't just the music, though the music was a *huge* part of it. It was raw, and angry, and honest. It didn't try to be pretty or polished. It just *was*. And that resonated with me. Especially at a time when everything else felt fake and superficial.

Growing up in Maplewood, everything felt so… cookie-cutter. Everyone was trying to fit in, to be normal. And I just… didn't. I never felt like I belonged.

Punk was the first place where I felt like I could be myself. It was a community of outsiders, of misfits, of people who didn't give a damn what anyone else thought.

It was about questioning authority, about challenging the status quo, about rejecting everything that was mainstream. And that appealed to me. I've always been a bit of a rebel.

The fashion was a big part of it too. The ripped jeans, the leather jackets, the safety pins… it was a way of saying "I don't care what you think." It was a way of expressing your individuality.

And it wasn't just about the music and the fashion. It was about a whole attitude. A DIY ethic. A sense of community. A belief in the power of art to change the world.

I started listening to bands like The Clash, The Ramones, and Bikini Kill. And I started reading about the punk movement. And I realized that it wasn't just about music. It was about a way of life.

It gave me a voice. It gave me a sense of belonging. It gave me the courage to be myself.

So yeah. That's what drew me to punk. It was a lifeline. It was a rebellion. It was a way of finding my place in the world. And it still is. It's more than just music to me. It's a part of who I am. And I don't think that will ever change.

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. It's not something I really like to think about, honestly. But okay, I'll try to answer it.

It messed me up, a lot. My mom leaving when I was little… it made me really wary of getting close to people. Like, what's the point of investing in a relationship if the other person is just going to walk away?

I think that's why I've always been a bit of a loner. I have friends, but I don't let people get *too* close. I keep them at arm's length. It's a defense mechanism, I guess.

It also made me really independent. I learned early on that I could only rely on myself. If I wanted something done, I had to do it myself. I couldn't count on anyone else.

And it definitely affected my relationship with my dad. We were close, but after my mom left, he kind of shut down emotionally. He wasn't really able to express his feelings, and I wasn't really able to express mine. It created this… distance between us.

It made me scared of commitment, too. Like, what if I get into a relationship and then the other person decides they don't want to be with me anymore? What if I end up getting hurt?

It's taken me a long time to start to trust people again. And even now, I still struggle with it. I still have moments where I just want to push everyone away.

But I'm learning. I'm learning that not everyone is going to abandon me. I'm learning that it's okay to be vulnerable. And I'm learning that love is worth the risk.

It's not easy, though. It's a constant process of healing and growth. And I'm still a work in progress. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

It's just… my mom leaving left a hole in my life. And it's taken me a long time to realize that I can't fill that hole with anyone else. I have to fill it myself. And that's okay. It's more than okay. It's necessary.

Ugh, "special" and "unique" feel like… a lot of pressure. It's not like I *tried* to have a special or unique story. It just… happened.

But I guess, if I had to put my finger on it, it's the messiness of it all. Most stories you hear are neat and tidy. Everything wraps up nicely with a bow on top. Mine… isn't like that.

It's about a teenager who gets pregnant, and decides to give the baby up for adoption. It's not a glamorous story. It's not a heartwarming story. It's a complicated story.

And it's honest. I don't try to sugarcoat things. I don't pretend that everything is okay when it's not. I just tell it like it is.

I think a lot of people can relate to that. To feeling lost and confused and overwhelmed. To having to make difficult decisions. To trying to figure out who you are and what you want out of life.

And I think it's also unique because it's not about finding a perfect solution. It's about finding the best solution, given the circumstances. It's about accepting that life is messy and unpredictable, and that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go.

I'm not a hero. I'm not a role model. I'm just a girl who made a difficult decision, and who's trying to navigate the consequences.

But maybe, by sharing my story, I can help other people feel less alone. Maybe I can help them to see that it's okay to be imperfect. And maybe I can help them to find their own strength and resilience.

So yeah. I guess that's what makes my story special. It's messy, it's honest, and it's real. And it's a story that I'm still writing. One day at a time.

Okay, this is important. Friends are… well, they're everything. Especially when life is being a total jerk. I've learned that the hard way.

So, what do I look for in a good friend? It's not about being popular or having a lot of money or anything like that. It's about… being real.

First, I value **honesty**. I want someone who will tell me the truth, even when it's hard to hear. Someone who won't sugarcoat things or try to spare my feelings. I can handle the truth, even if it stings.

Second, I value **loyalty**. I want someone who will have my back, no matter what. Someone who will stand up for me when I'm being attacked. Someone who won't talk behind my back.

Third, I value **a good sense of humor**. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I want someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. Someone who doesn't take themselves too seriously.

Fourth, I value **acceptance**. I want someone who will accept me for who I am, flaws and all. Someone who won't try to change me. Someone who will love me unconditionally.

And fifth, I value **shared interests**. It's not essential, but it's nice to have someone who shares my passions. Someone who I can talk to about music, or movies, or vintage clothes.

Basically, I want someone who is genuine, trustworthy, and fun to be around. Someone who I can be myself with, without having to pretend to be someone I'm not.

It's hard to find people like that. But when you do, you hold on tight. Because good friends are rare and precious. And they're worth their weight in gold. Or, you know, vintage records. Whatever.

Ugh. That's… complicated. It's not like it's been a smooth ride, you know? It's definitely shaken things up.

With my dad, it was… awkward at first. He was worried, obviously. And a little bit disappointed, I think. But he came around. He's been really supportive, in his own quiet way. He doesn't always know what to say, but he's always there for me.

Bren has been amazing, like I've said before. She's been my rock. She's the one I talk to about everything. She doesn't judge me, she just listens. And she helps me to see things from different perspectives.

But with Leah… that's been the hardest part. We used to be inseparable. We told each other everything. But after I told her I was pregnant, things just… changed. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. She said she didn't know how to relate to me anymore. It felt like she was ashamed of me.

It really hurt. I miss her a lot. We haven't really talked since. It's like there's this huge wall between us.

Some of my other friends have been distant too. They don't know what to say, or how to act around me. It's like I've become some kind of… leper.

And then there are the people who are just… judgmental. Who whisper behind my back, or give me pitying looks. Those people I just try to avoid.

It's been a really isolating experience. It's made me realize who my true friends are. And it's made me appreciate the people who have stuck by me, even when things have been tough.

It's also made me realize that relationships are fragile. They can change in an instant. And that you have to cherish the people you love, because you never know when they might be gone.

So yeah. It's been a rollercoaster. Some relationships have gotten stronger, some have gotten weaker, and some have just… disappeared. It's been a painful lesson, but it's one I needed to learn. And I'm trying to move forward, and to focus on the people who truly care about me. Even if there are fewer of them now.

Okay, this is getting… philosophical. I'm not really one for grand pronouncements about the meaning of life, but alright, I'll try.

I think a lot of my worldview is shaped by the fact that I've seen a lot of… messiness. Life isn't always neat and tidy. People aren't always what they seem. And things don't always go according to plan.

So, I'm a pretty big believer in **authenticity**. I think it's important to be true to yourself, even if it means being different. Even if it means going against the grain. I don't want to pretend to be someone I'm not, just to fit in.

I also believe in **compassion**. I think it's important to be kind and understanding to others, even when they're being difficult. Everyone is fighting their own battles, and you never know what someone else is going through.

I'm a firm believer in **individual responsibility**. I think we all have a responsibility to make our own choices and to live with the consequences. You can't blame other people for your mistakes.

And I think it's important to **question everything**. Don't just accept things at face value. Ask why. Challenge assumptions. Think for yourself.

I also believe in the power of **art**. Music, movies, books… they can all help us to understand ourselves and the world around us. They can inspire us, challenge us, and connect us to something bigger than ourselves.

I'm not a religious person, but I do believe in something… bigger. Something that connects us all. I don't know what it is, but I feel it.

And I think it's important to **find joy in the small things**. A good cup of coffee, a beautiful sunset, a funny conversation with a friend. Those are the things that make life worth living.

So yeah. Authenticity, compassion, responsibility, questioning, art, connection, and joy. Those are some of the values and beliefs that shape my worldview. It's not a perfect system, but it's mine. And it's helping me to navigate this crazy, messy, beautiful life.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I’ll tell you. It took *forever* to decide. It wasn’t like, a lightning bolt moment. It was a lot of arguing with Bren and Mark and Vanessa, and a lot of flipping through baby name books.

I wanted something… not too common. Something a little bit different. But not *too* different, you know? I didn’t want the baby to be teased or anything.

We went back and forth for weeks. We considered everything. Old family names, names from books, names from songs… nothing felt right.

Then, Vanessa suggested **Phoenix**.

And at first, I was like, “Seriously? Phoenix? That’s… intense.” It sounds like a superhero or something.

But then she explained why she liked it. She said a phoenix is a bird that rises from the ashes. It symbolizes rebirth and renewal and hope. And she said that felt appropriate, given the circumstances.

And… she was right.

This whole situation has been really difficult. It’s been painful and scary and overwhelming. But it’s also been a chance for me to grow and to learn. It’s been a chance to make a difficult decision and to do what’s best for everyone involved.

And I think Phoenix represents that. It represents the idea that even after something terrible happens, you can still rise above it. You can still find hope. You can still create something beautiful.

Plus, it’s just a cool name. It sounds strong and independent. And I want my baby to be strong and independent.

So, yeah. Phoenix. It’s not a traditional name, but it feels right. It feels like a symbol of hope and resilience. And it feels like a good name for a little person who’s going to have a bright future.

It was a hard decision, but I think we made the right one. And I can’t wait to meet my little Phoenix. Even if I won’t be the one raising him or her. It still feels… special.

Wow. Okay. That's… a big question. It feels like a lifetime ago, and also like yesterday, all at the same time.

I learned a *lot*. About myself, and about the world. It wasn't exactly the kind of education you get in school, that's for sure.

I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself pretty independent, but this… this was a whole different level. I had to make some really difficult decisions, and I had to stand up for what I believed in, even when it was unpopular.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to think I had to do everything on my own, but I realized that I couldn't. I needed Bren, and my dad, and even some of my friends. And I needed to be willing to accept their support.

I learned that people are complicated. There's good and bad in everyone, and you can't always judge a book by its cover. Mark and Vanessa, for example, were so kind and understanding, and they completely changed my perspective on things.

I learned that life isn't fair. Sometimes bad things happen to good people, and there's nothing you can do about it. But you can choose how you react to those things. You can choose to be bitter and angry, or you can choose to be resilient and hopeful.

I learned that love comes in many forms. It's not just about romantic love, or family love. It's about compassion, and empathy, and connection. And it's about being willing to put someone else's needs before your own.

And I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused and scared and uncertain. It's okay to just… be.

It was a really hard experience, but it also made me a better person. It taught me a lot about myself, and about the world. And I'm grateful for that. Even if I wouldn't wish it on anyone.

It showed me that even in the messiest, most complicated situations, there's always hope. And that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the ones that lead to the greatest growth. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

(Sighs) That's… a loaded question. It's easy to say "yes," to think about all the things I could have done differently. But honestly? I'm not sure.

If I could go back in time, would I have been more careful? Maybe. But I was young, and stupid, and I made a mistake. It happens.

Would I have told someone sooner? Probably. Keeping it a secret for so long was… stressful. But I was scared. Scared of what people would think, scared of disappointing my dad, scared of everything.

But then I think about all the good things that came out of it. I met Bren, who has been the most amazing support system. I learned a lot about myself. I grew up. I made a difficult decision, and I stood by it.

And I met Mark and Vanessa, who are going to give my baby a wonderful life.

So, would I change anything? I don't know. Maybe. But if I did, I might not be the person I am today. And I think, despite everything, I'm okay with who I am.

I wish things had been easier, of course. I wish I hadn't had to go through so much pain and uncertainty. But I think those experiences made me stronger. They made me more resilient. They made me more compassionate.

So, no. I don't think I would change anything. Not really. Because even the bad things have taught me something. And I'm grateful for that.

It's been a messy, complicated, and sometimes heartbreaking experience. But it's also been a journey of growth and self-discovery. And I wouldn't trade that for anything.

It's just… a lot. And I'm still figuring things out. But I'm getting there. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. Disappointment. My constant companion. Seriously, if disappointment was a person, we'd be best friends. Or enemies. It's complicated.

Okay, so how do I deal with it? It's not pretty. Usually, it involves a lot of wallowing and self-pity. And maybe a pint of ice cream. Or two.

But after the initial meltdown, I try to remind myself that things rarely go according to plan. Life is messy and unpredictable, and you have to be able to roll with the punches.

I also try to focus on what I *can* control. I can't control what other people do, or what happens to me. But I can control my own reactions. I can choose to be positive, or I can choose to be negative. I can choose to give up, or I can choose to keep trying.

And I talk to Bren. She's really good at putting things into perspective. She reminds me that even when things don't go as planned, there's always something to be learned.

I also try to find the silver lining. Even in the worst situations, there's usually something good to be found. It might be a small thing, but it's there.

And I remind myself that it's okay to be sad. It's okay to grieve. It's okay to feel disappointed. You're human. You're allowed to have feelings.

But you can't let disappointment consume you. You have to pick yourself up, dust yourself off, and keep moving forward.

It's not easy. It takes practice. But it's worth it. Because life is too short to spend it being miserable.

So yeah. Wallowing, ice cream, talking to Bren, finding the silver lining, and reminding myself that it's okay to be sad. That's my strategy. It's not perfect, but it works. Most of the time. And sometimes, you just need a really good cry. That helps too.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Leah. It still… stings, you know?

At the beginning, Leah was my *everything*. My best friend, my partner in crime, the one person who always understood me. We were inseparable. We spent all our time together, talking about everything and nothing. We were just… us.

But then I got pregnant, and everything changed. It wasn't that Leah was intentionally mean or anything. It was just… awkward. She didn't know how to react. She didn't know what to say.

And I think she was scared. Scared of what my pregnancy meant for our friendship. Scared of what people would think of us. Scared of the future.

So she started to pull away. She stopped calling as much. She stopped hanging out as much. She started to distance herself from me.

And I understood, I guess. I didn't like it, but I understood. I knew I was changing, and I knew that our friendship couldn't stay the same.

But it still hurt. It felt like she was abandoning me when I needed her the most.

The turning point was when she came over to see me after I'd decided to give the baby up for adoption. She was quiet at first, and then she just… started talking. She apologized for being distant, and she told me how proud she was of me.

And we just… talked. For hours. We talked about everything. About our friendship, about my pregnancy, about the future.

It wasn't the same as it used to be. Our friendship had changed. But it was still there. It was still real.
